	<li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-248">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/eea6293d3dd8da3d73c962939e4d64a1?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/eea6293d3dd8da3d73c962939e4d64a1?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Shinji</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-04-10T07:31:37+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-248" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-04-10 at 07:31</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim, this is a great post!</p>
<p>I&#8217;m interested in the actual PCIe bandwidth in the deep learning process. Are PCIe 16 lanes needed for deep learning? Of course x16 PCIe gen3 is ideal for the best performance, but I&#8217;m wondering if x8 or x4 PCIe gen3 is also enough performance.</p>
<p>Which do you think better solution if the system has 64 PCIe lanes?</p>
<p>*  4 GPGPUs connected with 16 PCIe lanes each<br />
* 16 GPGPUs connected with  4 PCIe lanes each</p>
<p>Which is important factor, the number of GPGPU (calculation power) or PCIe bandwidth?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-248' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-248", "248", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Shinji'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment even depth-2" id="comment-249">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-04-10T08:50:33+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-249" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-04-10 at 08:50</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Each PCIe lane for PCIe 3.0 has a theoretical bandwidth of about 1 GB/s, so you can run GPUs also with 8 lanes or 4 lanes (8 lanes is standard for at least one GPU if you have more than 2 GPUs), but it will be slower. How much slower will depend on the application or network architecture and which kind of parallelism is used. </p>
<p>64 PCIe lanes are only supported by two CPU motherboards and these boards often have a special PCIe switching architecture which connects the two separate PCIe systems (one for each CPU) with each other; I think you can only run up to 8 GPUs with such a system (the BIOs often cannot handle more GPUs even if you have more PCIe slots). But if you take this as a theoretical example it is best to just do some test calculations:<br />
16 GPUs means 15 data transfers to synchronize information; 4 PCIe lanes / 15 transfers = 0.2666 GB/s for a full synchronization. If you now have a weight matrix with say 800&#215;1200 floating point numbers you have 800x1200x1024^-3= 0.0036 GB. This means you could synchronize 0.2666/0.0036 = 74 gradients per second. A good implementation of MNIST with batchsize 128 will run with about 350 batches per second. So the result is that 16 GPUs with 4 PCIe lanes will be 5 times slower for MNIST. These numbers are better for convolutional nets, but not much better. Same for 4 GPUs/16 lanes:<br />
16/3 = 5.33; 5.33/0.0036 = 647; so in this case there would be a speedup of about 2 times; this is better for convolutional nets (you can except a speedup of 3.0-3.9 depending on the implementation). You can do similar calculations for model parallelism in which the 16 GPU case would fare a bit better (but it is probably still slower than 1 GPU).</p>
<p>So the bottom line is that 16 GPUs with 4 PCIe lanes are quite useless for any sort of parallelism — PCIe transfer rates are very important for multiple GPUS.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-249' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-249", "249", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="comment-250">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/eea6293d3dd8da3d73c962939e4d64a1?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/eea6293d3dd8da3d73c962939e4d64a1?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Shinji</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-04-10T10:07:39+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-250" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-04-10 at 10:07</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Thank you for explanation.<br />
Regarding your description, it depends on application, but the data transfer time among GPUs is dominant in multiple GPUs environment.</p>
<p>However, I have another question.<br />
In your assumption, the GPU processing time is always shorter than data transfer time. In 16 GPUs case, GPU processing must take less than 14 msec to process one batch. In 4 GPUs case, it must take less than about 2 msec.</p>
<p>If the GPU processing time is longer enough than data transfer time,  the data transfer time for synchronization is negligible. In that case, it is important to have many GPUs rather than PCIe bandwidth.<br />
Is my assumption unlikely in usual case?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-250' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-250", "250", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Shinji'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment even depth-4" id="comment-251">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-04-10T11:02:45+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-251" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-04-10 at 11:02</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>This is exactly the case for convolutional nets, where you have high computation with small gradients (weight sharing). However, even for convolutional nets there are limits to this; beyond eight GPUs it can quickly become difficult to gain near-linear speedups, which is mostly due low interconnections between computers. A 8 GPU system will be reasonably fast with speedups of about 7-8 times for convolutional nets, but for more than 8 GPUs you have to use normal interconnects like infiniband. Infiniband is similar to PCIe but its speed is fixed at about 8-25 GB/s (8GB/s is the affordable standard; 16 GB/s is expensive; 25 GB/s is very, very expensive): So for 6 GPUs + 8GB/s standard connection this yields a standard bandwidth of 1.6 GB/s which is much worse than the 4 GPU 16 lanes example; for 12 GPUs this is  0.72 GB/s; 24 GPUs 0.35GB/s; 48 GPUs 0.17GB/s. So pretty quickly it will be pretty slow even for convolutional nets.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-251' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-251", "251", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="comment-263">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-05-06T05:57:19+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-263" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-05-06 at 05:57</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>I overlooked your comment, but it is actually a very good question. It turns out that you exactly hit the mark: The less communication is needed the better are more GPUs compared to more bandwidth. However, in deep learning there are only few cases where it makes sense to trade bandwidth for more GPUs. Very deep recurrent neural networks (time dimension) would be an example, and to some degree (very) deep neural networks (20+ layers) are of this type. However, even for 20+ layers you still want to look at maximizing your bandwidth to maximize your overall performance. </p>
<p>For dense neural networks, anything above 4 GPUs is rather impractical. You can make it work to run faster, but this required much effort and several compromises in model accuracy.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-263' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-263", "263", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

8gb ram<br />
SSD</p>

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="comment-253">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-04-26T08:12:15+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-253" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-04-26 at 08:12</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>It is difficult to estimate the performance boost if your previous GPU is a ATI GPU; but for the other hardware pieces you should see about a 5-10% increase in performance. </p>
<p>1. I never had any problems with my motherboards, so I cannot give you any advice here on that topic.<br />
2. I also had this idea once, but it is usually impossible to do this: CUDA and virtualized GPUs do not go together, you will need specialized GPUs (GRID GPUs, which are used on AWS); even if they would go together there would be a stark performance decrease. </p>
<p>It it a great change to go from windows to ubuntu, but it is really worth doing if you are serious about deep learning. A few months in ubuntu and you will never want to go back!</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-253' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-253", "253", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment even depth-2" id="comment-256">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-04-28T09:42:24+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-256" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-04-28 at 09:42</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>If it is possible that you will have a second GPU at anytime in the future definitely get a PCIe 3.0 CPU and motherboard. If you use additional GPUs for parallelism, then in the case of PCIe 2.0 you will suffer a performance loss of about 15% for a second GPU, and much larger losses (+40%) for your third and fourth GPU. If you are sure that you will stay with one GPU in the future, then PCIe 2.0 will only give you a small or no performance decrease (0-5%) and you should be fine.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-256' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-256", "256", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="comment-257">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/c643521d2d6018b6a107baf26d065caa?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/c643521d2d6018b6a107baf26d065caa?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Mark</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>This may not make much difference if you care about a new system now or about having a more current system in the future. However, if you want to keep it around for years and use it for other things besides ML then wait a few months.</p>
<p>Intel&#8217;s Skylake CPU will be released in a few months along with it&#8217;s new chip set, new socket, new motherboards etc. All PCI 3, ddr4, etc. It&#8217;s considered a big change compared to prior CPU&#8217;s. Skylake prices are suppose to be similar to current offerings but retailers say they expect the price of ddr4 to drop. Don&#8217;t really understand why but gamers are also waiting for the release &#8230; maybe just because &#8220;new and improved&#8221; since it doesn&#8217;t seem to translate into a big plus for the gaming experience.</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="comment-259">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-05-01T04:45:08+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-259" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-05-01 at 04:45</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Although your data set is very small and you will only be able to train a small convolutional net before you overfit the size of the images is huge. Unfortunately, the size of the images is the most significant memory factor in convolutional nets. I think a GTX 970 will not be sufficient for this. </p>
<p>However, keep in mind, that you can always shrink the images to keep them manageable. for a GTX 970 you will need to shrink them to about 250*190 or so.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-259' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-259", "259", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-261">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/7ba3a572a860f63bdc4b702582072ddc?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/7ba3a572a860f63bdc4b702582072ddc?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">sacherus</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-05-05T22:44:22+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-261" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-05-05 at 22:44</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim,<br />
thank you for your great article. I think it&#8217;s cover everything that you need to know to start your journey with DL.</p>
<p>I&#8217;m also grad student (but instead of image processing, I&#8217;m in speech processing) and want to buy some machine (I thinking also about Kaggle, but for beginning I could take 20-40 place 🙂 ).  I want to buy (East Europe) used workstation (without graphics) + used graphics. Probably  I will end up with 2 cards in my computer&#8230; Maybe 3&#8230;.</p>
<p>Questions:<br />
1) You wrote that you need to have 7 3.0 slots motherboard for 3 GPUs. Isn&#8217;t possible to have<br />
16 x | 1x | 16x | 1x (etc) setup? Like in <a href="http://www.msi.com/product/mb/Z87-G45-GAMING.html#hero-overview" rel="nofollow">http://www.msi.com/product/mb/Z87-G45-GAMING.html#hero-overview</a>?<br />
2) So there do not exist setups that support 16x/16x (or are to expensive)?<br />
3) I see that computation compatibility also matters. I can buy geforce 780 ti in similar price to gtx 970. 780 ti has better bandwith + more GFLOPS (you never mentioned about FLOPS), but 970 has newer CC + more memory.<br />
4) Maybe I should let go and buy what&#8230; 960 or 680 (just start)&#8230; However, 970 is not much expensive than those 2. Or just buy whole used PC.?</p>
<p>Tim, what do you think?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-261' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-261", "261", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to sacherus'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment even depth-2" id="comment-262">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-05-06T05:50:31+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-262" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-05-06 at 05:50</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>1. You are right, a 16x | 1x | 16x | 1x setup will work just as well; I did not thought about that in this way, and I will update my blog with that soon — thanks!<br />
2. I hope I understand you right: You have a total of 40x PCIe lanes supported by your CPU (not the physical slots, but this is sort of the communication wires that are layed from the PCIe slots to the CPU) and your GPUs will use up to 16x (standard mainboards) for that; so 16x 16x is standard if you use 2 GPUs, for 3 GPUs this is 16x8x16 and for 4 GPUs 16x8x8x8. If you mean physical slots, then a 16x | Yx | 16x setup will do, where Y is any size; because most GPUs have a width of two PCIe slots you most often cannot run 2 GPUs on 16x | 16x mainboard slots, sometimes this will work if you use watercooling though (reduces the width to one slot)<br />
3. GFLOPS do not matter in deep learning (its virtually the same for all algorithms), your algorithms will always be limited by bandwidth; the 780 TI has higher bandwidth, but inferior architecture and the GTX 970 would be faster. However, the GTX 780 TI has no gliches, and so I would go with the GTX 780 TI<br />
4. The GTX 680 might be a bit more interesting than the GTX 780 TI if you really want to train a lot of convolutional nets; otherwise a GTX 780 TI is best; if you only use dense networks you might want to go with the GTX 970</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-262' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-262", "262", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="comment-264">

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-05-11T13:49:09+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-264" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-05-11 at 13:49</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Tim,</p>
<p>Thanks for the excellent guide! It has helped us a lot. However, a few questions remain&#8230;</p>
<p>We plan to build a deep-learning machine (in a server rack) based on 4 Titan cards. We need to select other hardware. Ideally we would put all four cards on a single board with 4x PCIe 3.0 x16. The questions are:</p>
<p>1. If I understand correctly, GPU intercommunication is the bottleneck. Should we go for dual 40-lane CPUs (Xeons only, right?), or take a single i7 and connect the cards with SLI?<br />
2. Will any 4x PCIe 3.0 x16 motherboard do? Is socket 2011 preferable?</p>

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="comment-266">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-05-11T14:38:30+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-266" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-05-11 at 14:38</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>2 CPUs will typically yield no speedup because usually the PCIe networks of each CPU (2 GPUs for each CPU) are disconnected which means that the GPU pairs will communicate through CPU memory (max speed about 4 GB/s, because a GPU pair will share the same connection to the CPU on a PCIe-switch). While it is reasonable for 8 GPUs, I would not recommend 2 CPUs for a 4 GPU setup.</p>
<p>There are motherboards that work differently, but these are special solutions which often only come in a package of a whole 8 GPU server rack ($35k-$40k).</p>
<p>If you use a single GPU then any motherboard with enough slots and which supports 4 GPUs will do; choose the CPU so that it supports 40 PCIe lanes and you will be ready to go. Socket 2011 has no advantage over other sockets which fulfill these requirements.</p>
<p>Regarding SLI: SLI can be used for gaming, but not for CUDA (it would be too slow anyways); so communication is really all done by PCI Express.</p>
<p>Hope this helps!</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-266' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-266", "266", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="comment-268">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-05-12T11:58:03+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-268" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-05-12 at 11:58</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>It is quite difficult to say which one is better, because I do not know the PCIe switch layout of the dual CPU motherboard. The most common PCIe switch layout is explained in <a href="http://www.cirrascale.com/blog/index.php/exploring-the-pcie-bus-routes" title="this article" rel="nofollow">this article</a> and if the dual CPU motherboard that you linked behaves in a similar way, then for deep learning 2 CPUs will be definitely be slower than 1 CPU if you want to use parallel algorithms across all 4 GPUs; in that case the 1 CPU board will be better. However, this might be quite different for other computing purposes than deep learning and a 2 CPU board might be better for those tasks.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-268' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-268", "268", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="comment-270">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-05-13T14:45:47+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-270" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-05-13 at 14:45</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>There are some GPUs which are integrated (embedded) in regular CPUs and you can run your monitors on these processors. The effect of this is some saved memory (about a hundred MB for each monitor) but very little computational resources (less than 1 % for 3 monitors). So if you are really short on memory (say you have a GPU with 2 or 3GB and 3 monitors) then this might make good sense. Otherwise, it is not very important and buying a CPU with integrated graphics should not be a deciding factor when you buy a CPU.</p>
<p>As I said in the article, you have a wide variety of options for the CPU and motherboard, especially if you will stick with one GPU. In this case you can really go for very cheap components and it will not hurt your performance much. So I would go for the cheapest CPU and motherboard with a reasonable good rating on pcpartpicker.com if I were you.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-270' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-270", "270", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="comment-272">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/6bd7d604287033fec66fd126c154b88c?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/6bd7d604287033fec66fd126c154b88c?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Richard</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim,</p>
<p>First can I say thanks very much for writing this article &#8211; it has been very informative. </p>
<p>I&#8217;m a first year PhD student. My research is concerned with video classification and I&#8217;m looking into using convolutional nets for this purpose.</p>
<p>My current system has a Gt 620 which takes about 4 hours to run a lenet5 based network built using theano on MNIST. So I&#8217;m looking to upgrade and I have about £1000 to do it with. </p>

Also there&#8217;s the 780 which although would be slower than the 980 it has more ram which would be beneficial For convolutional nets. I looked into buying second hand as you suggested however I&#8217;m buying through my university so that isn&#8217;t an option.</p>

<p> Cheers,<br />
Richard</p>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-272' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-272", "272", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Richard'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment even depth-2" id="comment-273">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-05-17T15:39:28+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-273" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-05-17 at 15:39</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>That is really a tricky issue, Richard. If you use convolutional on the spatial dimensions of an image as well as the time dimension, you will have 5 dimensional tensors (batch size, rows, columns, maps, time) and such tensors will use a lot of memory. So you really want a memory card. If you use the <a href="https://github.com/NervanaSystems/neon" rel="nofollow">Nervana Systems 16-bit kernels</a> you would be able to reduce memory consumption by half; these kernels are also nearly twice as fast (for dense connections there are more than twice as fast). To use the Nervana Systems kernels, you will need a Maxwell GPU (GTX Titan X, GTX 960, GTX 970, GTX 980). So if you use this library a GTX 980 will have &#8220;virtually&#8221; 8GB of memory, while the GTX 780 has 6GB. The GTX 980 is also much faster than the GTX 780, which further adds to the GTX 980 options. However, the Nervana Systems kernels still lack some support for natural language processing, and overall you will have a far more thorough software if you use torch and a GTX 780. If you think about adding your own CUDA kernels, the Nervana Systems + GTX 980 option may be not so suitable, because you probably will need to handle the custom compiler and program 16-bit floating point kernels (I have not looked at this, but I believe there will be things which makes it more complicated than regular CUDA programming). </p>
<p>I think both, GTX 780 and GTX 980 are good options. The final choice is up to you!</p>
<p>Hope this helps!</p>
<p>Cheers,<br />
Tim</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-273' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-273", "273", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="comment-274">

			<p>Thanks for the detailed response Tim,</p>
<p>Think i&#8217;ll go with the 780 for now due to the extra physical memory. Quick follow up question: if I have the money for an additional card in the future would I need to buy the same model. Could I for example have both a GTX 780 and a GTX 980 running in the same machine so that I can have two different models running on each card simultaneously? Would there be any issues with drivers etc? Going to order the parts for my new system tomorrow will post some benchmarks soon.</p>

Richard</p>

	<li class="comment even depth-4" id="comment-275">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-05-20T14:01:04+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-275" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-05-20 at 14:01</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>GPUs can only communicate directly if they are based on the same chip (but brands may differ). So for parallelism you would need to get another GTX 780, otherwise a GTX 980 is fine for everything else. Also remember, that new Pascal GPUs will hit around Q3 2016 and those will be significantly faster than any Maxwell GPU (3D memory) — so waiting might be an option as well.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-275' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-275", "275", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="comment-276">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/c643521d2d6018b6a107baf26d065caa?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/c643521d2d6018b6a107baf26d065caa?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Mark</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-05-26T12:21:02+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-276" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-05-26 at 12:21</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>FYI on Pascal chip from NVIDIA. Speed up over Titan is &#8220;up to 5x.&#8221; Of this, a 2x speed up will come from the option of switching to using 16 bit floating point in Pascal.</p>
<p>The rest of the &#8220;up to 10x speed up&#8221; comes from the 2x speed up you get from NVLink. Here the comparison is two Pascal versus two Titans. I don&#8217;t know what the speed up would be if the Pascals used the same PCI interlink as the Titans or if they could even use the PCI interlink. Hopefully so then a new motherboard would not be necessary.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-276' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-276", "276", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Mark'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>I do not have a Haswell G3258 and I would not recommend one, as it only runs 16 PCIe 3.0 lanes instead of the typical 40. So if you are looking for a CPU I would not pick Haswell — too new and thus too expensive, and many Haswells do not have full 40 PCIe lanes.</p>
		</div>

The 980 Ti has the same Memory Bandwidth as the Titan X, 2GB more memory than a 980 (which should make it better for big convnets), only a few CUDA cores less. And the price difference is 549 USD for a 980 Ti vs 999 USD for the Titan X.</p>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">

If you will be working on video classification or want to use memory-expensive data sets I would still recommend a Titan X over a 980 Ti.</p>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hey Tim! Thanks for these posts, they&#8217;re highly, highly appreciated! I&#8217;m just starting to get my feet wet in deep learning &#8211; is there any way to hook up my Laptop to a GPU (maybe even an external one?) without having to build a PC from scratch so I could start GPGPU programming on small datasets with less of an investment? Does the answer depend on my motherboard?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-283' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-283", "283", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Kai'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment even depth-2" id="comment-284">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-06-15T11:49:58+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-284" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-06-15 at 11:49</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>In that case it will be best to use AWS GPU spot instances which are cheap and fast. External GPUs are available, but they are not an option because the data transfer, CPU -&gt; USB-like-interface -&gt; GPU, is too slow for deep learning. Once you have made some experiences with AWS I would then buy a dedicated deep learning PC.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-284' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-284", "284", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-287">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/c46ee397f8e90f47a724aae169c5ee31?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/c46ee397f8e90f47a724aae169c5ee31?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Sergii</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-06-18T12:08:00+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-287" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-06-18 at 12:08</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim!<br />
Thanks for your helpful and detailed write-up.</p>
<p>It seems from this blog post (<a href="http://devblogs.nvidia.com/parallelforall/how-overlap-data-transfers-cuda-cc/" rel="nofollow">http://devblogs.nvidia.com/parallelforall/how-overlap-data-transfers-cuda-cc/</a>) that for concurrent kernel execution and data transfer the memory must be pinned.</p>
<p>You wrote &#8220;&#8230;one might be able to prevent that when one uses pinned memory, but as you shall see later, it does not matter anyway&#8230;&#8221; and AFAIU you don&#8217;t use pinned memory in the async batch allocation process  (`clusternet` project).</p>
<p>Also, pinned memory is mentioned in the documentation (<a href="http://docs.nvidia.com/cuda/cuda-c-best-practices-guide/index.html#asynchronous-transfers-and-overlapping-transfers-with-computation" rel="nofollow">http://docs.nvidia.com/cuda/cuda-c-best-practices-guide/index.html#asynchronous-transfers-and-overlapping-transfers-with-computation</a>), but at the same time this (<a href="http://docs.nvidia.com/cuda/cuda-runtime-api/group__CUDART__MEMORY.html#group__CUDART__MEMORY_1g85073372f776b4c4d5f89f7124b7bf79" rel="nofollow">http://docs.nvidia.com/cuda/cuda-runtime-api/group__CUDART__MEMORY.html#group__CUDART__MEMORY_1g85073372f776b4c4d5f89f7124b7bf79</a>) document says  &#8220;&#8230;the copy may overlap with operations in other streams&#8230;&#8221; and no mention about pinned memory. </p>
<p>These contradictory facts are a bit confusing to me. So my question is:<br />
&#8211; Do you have the code that can confirm overlapping between transfer process of pageable host memory to the device memory and kernel execution?<br />
&#8211; And what is actually going on with cudaMemcpyAsync?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-287' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-287", "287", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Sergii'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="comment-288">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-06-18T12:30:50+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-288" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-06-18 at 12:30</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>What you write is all true, but you have to look at it in two different ways, (1) CPU -&gt; GPU, and (2) GPU -&gt; GPU.</p>
<p>For CPU -&gt; GPU you will need pinned memory to do asynchronous copies; however, for GPU -&gt; GPU the copy will be automatically asynchronous in most use cases — no pinned GPU memory needed (cudaMemcpy and cudaMemcpyAsync are almost always the same for GPU -&gt; GPU transfers).</p>
<p>I turns out that I use pinned memory in my clusterNet project, but it is a bit hidden in the source code: I use it only for batch buffers in my BatchAllocator class, which has an embarrassingly poor design. There I transfer usual CPU memory, to a pinned buffer (while the GPU is busy) and then transfer it in another step asynchronously to the GPU, so that the batch is ready when the GPU needs it.</p>
<p>You can also allocate the whole data set as pinned memory, but this might cause some problems, because once pinned, the OS cannot &#8220;optimize&#8221; the locked in memory anymore which may lead to performance problems if one allocated a chunk of memory too large.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-288' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-288", "288", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="comment-289">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/c46ee397f8e90f47a724aae169c5ee31?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/c46ee397f8e90f47a724aae169c5ee31?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Sergii</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-06-18T13:36:02+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-289" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-06-18 at 13:36</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Thank you for the reply.<br />
Do you know what is the reason for the inability to have overlapping pageable host memory transfer and kernel execution?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-289' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-289", "289", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Sergii'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="comment-290">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-06-18T13:42:14+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-290" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-06-18 at 13:42</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>It has all to do with having a valid pointer to the data. If your memory is not pinned, then the OS can push the memory around freely to make some optimizations, so you are not certain to have a pointer to CPU memory and thus such transfers are not allowed by the NVIDIA software because they easily run into undefined behaviour. With pinned memory, the memory no longer is able to move, and so a pointer to the memory will stay the same at all times, so that a reliable transfer can be ensured.</p>
<p>This is different in GPUs, because GPU pointers are designed to be reliable at all times as long as they stay on some GPU memory, so these problems do not exist for GPU -&gt; GPU transfers.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-290' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-290", "290", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment even depth-3" id="comment-291">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/c46ee397f8e90f47a724aae169c5ee31?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/c46ee397f8e90f47a724aae169c5ee31?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Sergii</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-06-18T14:11:12+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-291" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-06-18 at 14:11</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Thanks for the wonderful explanation. But I still have a question. Your previous reply can explain why data transfer with pageable memory can&#8217;t be asynchronous with respect to a host thread, but I still do not understand why a device can&#8217;t execute kernel while copying data from a host. What is the reason for that?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-291' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-291", "291", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Sergii'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="comment-292">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-06-18T14:57:21+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-292" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-06-18 at 14:57</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Kernels <em>can</em> execute concurrently, the kernel just needs to work on a different data stream. In general, each GPU can have 1 Host to GPU, and 1 GPU to GPU transfer active, <em>and</em> execute a kernel concurrently on unrelated data in another stream (by default all operations use a default stream and are thus not concurrent).</p>
<p>But you are right that you cannot execute a kernel and a data transfer in the same stream. I assume there are issues with the hardware not being able to resume a kernel once the end of a steam that is being transferred at the very moment is reached (the kernel would need to wait, then compute, then wait, then compute, then wait&#8230; — this will not deliver good performance!). So it will be because of this that you cannot run a kernel on partial data.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-292' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-292", "292", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-293">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/c46ee397f8e90f47a724aae169c5ee31?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/c46ee397f8e90f47a724aae169c5ee31?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Sergii</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-06-19T12:11:53+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-293" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-06-19 at 12:11</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Sorry that my question was confusing.<br />
I write simple code which runs axpy cublas kernels and memcpy. As you can see from the profiler ![](<a href="http://imgur.com/dmEOZTY,q2HhqlX#1" rel="nofollow">http://imgur.com/dmEOZTY,q2HhqlX#1</a>), in case of pinned memory the kernels that were launched after cudMemcpyAsync run in parallel (with respect to transfer process).</p>
<p>However, in case of pageable memory, ![](<a href="http://imgur.com/dmEOZTY,q2HhqlX" rel="nofollow">http://imgur.com/dmEOZTY,q2HhqlX</a>) cudMemcpyAsync blocks the host, and I can&#8217;t launch the next kernel.</p>
<p>In the chapter `Direct memory access (DMA)` you say &#8220;&#8230;on the third step the reserved buffer is transferred to your GPU RAM without any help of the CPU&#8230;&#8221;, so why does cudMemcpyAsync block the host until the end of the copy process? What is the reason for that?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-293' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-293", "293", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Sergii'>Reply</a></div>

	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="comment-294">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-06-19T13:07:04+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-294" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-06-19 at 13:07</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>The most low-level reason I can think of is, as I said above, that pageable memory is inherently insecure and may be swapped/pushed around at will. If you start a transfer and want to make sure that everything works, it is best to wait until the data is fully received. I do not know about the low level details how the OS and its drivers and routines (like DMA) interact with the GPU. If you want to know these details, I think it would be best to consult with people from NVIDIA directly, I am sure they can give you a technical accurate answer; you might also want to try the developer forums.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-294' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-294", "294", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->

			<p>Do you think if you have too many monitors, it will occupy too much resources of your GPU already? If yes, how to solve this issue?</p>

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="comment-296">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-06-26T07:48:02+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-296" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-06-26 at 07:48</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>I have three monitors with 1920&#215;1080 resolution and the monitors draw about 400 MB. For me I never had any issues with this, but I also had 6GB cards and I did not train models that maxed out my GPU RAM. If you have a GPU with less memory (GTX 980 or GTX 970) then there might be some problems for convolutional nets. The best way to circumvent this problem is to buy a really cheap GPU for the monitors (a GT210 costs about $30 and can power two (three?) monitors), so that your main deep learning GPU is not attached to any monitor.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-296' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-296", "296", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-299' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-299", "299", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Sameh Sarhan'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="comment-302">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-07-08T07:24:44+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-302" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-07-08 at 07:24</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Sameh! If you have multivariate time series a common CNN approach is to use a sliding windows over your data on X time steps. Your convolutional net would then use temporal instead of spatio-temporal convolution which would use much less memory. As such, 6GB of memory should probably be sufficient for such data and I would recommend a GTX 980 Ti, or a GTX Titan. If you need to run your algorithms on very large sliding windows (an important signal happened 120 time steps ago, to which the algorithm should be sensitive to) a recurrent neural network would be best for which 6GB of memory would also be sufficient. If you want to use CNNs with such large windows it might be better to get a GTX Titan X with 12GB memory.<br />
Regards,<br />
Tim</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-302' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-302", "302", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Tim,</p>
<p>I am new to deep NN. I discovered its tremendous progress after seeing the excellent 2015 GTC NVidia talk. Deep NN will be very useful for my Phd which is about electrical brain signal classification (Brain Computer Interface).</p>
<p>What a joy I found your blog! Just wished if you wrote more.<br />
All your post are full of  interesting ideas. I have checked the comments of the posts which are not less interesting than the posts themselves and full of important hints too. </p>
<p>I read a lot, but did not find most of your interesting hints on hardware elsewhere. Your posts were just brilliant. I believe your posts filled a gap in the web, especially on the performance and the hardware side of deep NN.</p>
<p>I think on the hardware side, after reading your posts I have enough knowledge to build a good system.</p>
<p>On the software side, I found a lot of resources. However, I am still a bit confused. Perhaps, because it wasn&#8217;t your posts 😉 . Why do you only write on hardware? Your can write very well, and we love to hear from your experience on software too..</p>
<p>From where should I begin?</p>
<p>I&#8217;m very fond of Matlab and didn&#8217;t program much in other languages. And I don&#8217;t know anything about python, which seems very important to learn for machine learning. I don&#8217;t mind to learn python if you advise me to do so. But if it is not necessary, then maybe I can spare my time to learn other deep NN stuff, which are overwhelming already. My excitement crippled me. I have opened ~600 tabs and want to see them all.</p>
<p>If you were in my shoes, what platform you will begin to learn with? Caffe, Torch or Theano ? Why? </p>
<p>And please, tell me too about your personal preference. I learned from your posts that you are making your own programs. But in case you are picking one of these for you, what will be. And in case you were like me with no python experience, what will you pick in that case?</p>
<p>I am very interested to hear your opinion. I am not in hurry.. When you feel like writing please answer me with some details.</p>
<p>I thank you sincerely for all the posts and comment replies in your blog and eager to see more posts from you Tim!<br />
Thank you!</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="comment-301">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-07-08T07:14:03+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-301" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-07-08 at 07:14</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Thank you for all this praise — this is encouraging! I wrote about hardware mainly because I myself focused on the acceleration of deep learning and understanding the hardware was key in this area to achieve good results. Because I could not find the knowledge that I acquired elsewhere on a single website, I decided to write a few blog posts about this. I plan to write more about other deep learning topics in the future. </p>
<p>In my next posts I will compare deep learning to the human brain: I think this topic is very important because the relationship between deep learning and the brain is in general poorly understood. </p>
<p>I also wanted to make a blog post about software, but I did not have the time yet to do that — I will do so probably in this month or the next.</p>
<p>Regarding your questions, I would really recommend Torch7, as it is the deep learning library which has the most features and which is steadily extended by facebook and deepmind with new deep learning models from their research labs. However, as you posted above, it is better for you to work on windows and Torch7 does not work well on windows. Theano is the best option here I guess, but also Minerva seems to be okay.</p>
<p>Caffe is a good library when you do not want to fiddle around to much within a certain programming language and just want to train deep learning models; the downside is that it is difficult to make changes to the code and the training procedure/algorithm and few models are supported.</p>
<p>In the case of brain signals per se, I thin python offers a lot of packages which might be helpful for your research.</p>
<p>However, if you just want to get started quickly with the language you know, Matlab, then you can also use the neural network bindings from the Oxford research group, with which you can use your GPU to train neural networks within Matlab.</p>
<p>Hope this helps, good luck!</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-301' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-301", "301", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/56cf25c0c1fc6f87f853b2239dfeffce?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/56cf25c0c1fc6f87f853b2239dfeffce?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Jon</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-07-16T17:09:10+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-305" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-07-16 at 17:09</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Will Ecc RAM make Convolution NN or deep learning more efficient or better? In another word, if the same money can buy me one PC with Ecc RAM vs TWO PC without Ecc RAM, which should I pick for deep learning?</p>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-305' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-305", "305", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Jon'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="comment-306">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-07-16T17:47:42+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-306" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-07-16 at 17:47</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>I think ECC memory only applies to 64 bit operations and thus would not be relevant to deep learing, but I might be wrong. </p>
<p>ECC corrects if a bit is flipped in the wrong way due to physical inconsistencies at the hardware level of the system. Deep learning was shown to be quite robust to inaccuracies, for example you can train a neural network with 8-bits (if you do it carefully and in the right way); training a neural network with 16-bit works flawlessly. Note that training on 8 bit for example, will decrease the accuracy for all data while ECC is relevant only for some small parts of the data. However, a flipped bit might be quite severe while a conversion from 32 to 8-bits might still be quite close to the real value. But overall I think an error in a single bit should not be so detrimental to performance, because the other values might counterbalance this error or in the end softmax will buffer this (an extremely large error value sent to half the connections might spread to the whole network, but in the end for that sample the probability for the softmax will be just 1/classes for each class). </p>
<p>Remember that there are always a lot of samples in a batch, and that the error gradients in this batch are averaged. Thus even large errors will dissipate quickly, not harming performance.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-306' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-306", "306", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="comment-307">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/619a40d84cd49d490cb5f17775492627?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/619a40d84cd49d490cb5f17775492627?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Charles Foell III</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-07-24T16:06:00+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-307" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-07-24 at 16:06</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim,</p>
<p>1) Great post.  </p>
<p>2) Do you know how motherboards with dedicated PCI-E lane controllers shuffle data between GPUs with deep learning software?  For example, the PLX PEX 8747 purports control of 48 PCI-E lanes beyond the 40 lanes a top-shelf CPU controls, e.g. allowing five x16 connections, but it&#8217;s not clear to me if deep learning software makes use of such dedicated PCI-E lane controllers.  </p>
<p>I ask since going beyond three x16 connections with CPU control of PCI-E lanes only requires dual CPU, but such boards along with suitable CPUs can be in sum be thousands of dollars more expensive than a single CPU motherboard that has a PLX PEX 8747 chip.  If the latter has as good performance for deep learning software, might as well save the money!</p>
<p>Thanks!</p>
<p>-Charles</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-307' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-307", "307", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Charles Foell III'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="comment-308">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-07-24T16:21:21+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-308" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-07-24 at 16:21</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>That is very difficult to say. I think the PLX PEX 8747 chip will be handled by the operating system after you installed some driver, so that deep learning software would use it automatically in the background. However, it is unclear to me if you really can operate three GPUs in 16/16/16 when you use this chip, or if it will support peer-to-peer GPU memory transfers. I think you will need to get in touch with the manufacturer for that.</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment even depth-3" id="comment-309">

<p>I&#8217;ll need to dig more.  I&#8217;ve seen various GPU-to-GPU benchmarks for server-grade motherboards (e.g. in HPC systems), including a raw ~ 7 GB/s using a PLX PEX chip (lower than host-to-GPU), but I&#8217;ve had difficulty finding benchmarks for single-CPU boards, let alone for more than three x16 GPU connections. </p>
<p>If you come across a success story of a consumer-grade single-CPU system with exceptional transfer speed (better than 40 PCI-E 3.0 lanes worth in sum) between GPUs when running common deep learning software/libraries, or even a system with such benchmarks for raw CUDA functions, please update.</p>

<p>Best,<br />

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="comment-15001">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Nikos Tsarmpopoulos</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-05-14T18:58:29+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-15001" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-05-14 at 18:58</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>AMD&#8217;s Naple CPU is expected to provide 128 lanes: 64 lanes for 4 PCIe expansion cards at x16 and the remaining for CPU-to-CPU interconnect (called Infinity Fabric).<br />
Source:<br />
<a href="https://arstechnica.co.uk/information-technology/2017/03/amd-naples-zen-server-chip-details/" rel="nofollow">https://arstechnica.co.uk/information-technology/2017/03/amd-naples-zen-server-chip-details/</a></p>
		</div>
