	<li class="comment even depth-4" id="comment-15002">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Nikos Tsarmpopoulos</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-05-14T19:08:49+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-15002" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-05-14 at 19:08</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>In another article, it is implied that with 1xCPU systems, 128 lanes will be available for I/O, presumably allowing for full x16 lanes on up to 8 GPUs, or for use with NVLink bridges. </p>
<p>Source:<br />
<a href="http://www.anandtech.com/show/11183/amd-prepares-32-core-naples-cpus-for-1p-and-2p-servers-coming-in-q2" rel="nofollow">http://www.anandtech.com/show/11183/amd-prepares-32-core-naples-cpus-for-1p-and-2p-servers-coming-in-q2</a></p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-15002' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-15002", "15002", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Nikos Tsarmpopoulos'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-310">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/b8bb0f4282b89ff3fd5b2ce87484d2f1?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/b8bb0f4282b89ff3fd5b2ce87484d2f1?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Xardoz</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-07-30T09:16:35+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-310" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-07-30 at 09:16</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Very Useful information indeed, Tim.</p>
<p>I have a newbie question: If the motherboard has integrated graphics facility, and if the GPU is to be dedicated to just deep learning, should the display monitor be connected directly to the motherboard rather than the GPU?</p>
<p>I have just bought a machine with GeForce Titan X card and they just sent me a e-mail saying: </p>
<p> &#8220;You have ordered a graphics card with your computer and your motherboard comes supplied with integrated graphics. When connecting your monitor it is important that you connect your monitor cable to the output on the graphics card and NOT the output on the motherboard, because by doing so your monitor will not display anything on the screen.&#8221;</p>
<p>Intuitively,it seems that off-loading the display duties to the motherboard will free the GPU to do more important things. Is this correct? If so, do you think that this can be done simply? I would ask the supplier, but they sounded lost when I started talking about deep learning on Graphics cards.</p>
<p>Regards</p>
<p>Xardoz</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-310' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-310", "310", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Xardoz'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment even depth-2" id="comment-311">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-07-30T10:41:40+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-311" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-07-30 at 10:41</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Xardoz! You will be fine when you use connect your monitor to your GPU especially if your using a GTX Titan X. The only significant downside of this is some additional memory consumption which can be a couple of hundred MB. I have 3 monitors connected to my GPU(s) and it never bothered me doing deep learning. If you train very large convolutional nets that are on the edge of the 12GB limit, only then I would think about using the integrated graphics.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-311' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-311", "311", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim, very nice sharing. I just would like to comment on the &#8216;silly&#8217; parts (smile): the monitors. Since I only have one monitor, I just use NoMachine and put the screen in one of my virtual workspaces in ubuntu to switch between the current machine and our deep learning servers. Surprisingly this is more convenient and energy efficient both for the electricity and our neck movement. Just hope this would help especially those who only have single monitor. Cheers.</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-314">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/61da508f948415bb86e7860e5f23ef95?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/61da508f948415bb86e7860e5f23ef95?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://www.facebook.com/app_scoped_user_id/1691380981083432/" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Vu Pham</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-08-04T16:07:15+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-314" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-08-04 at 16:07</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>So, I do a research on deep learning hardware, I assume the most appropriate Part list is:</p>
<p>Motherboard: X10DRG-Q &#8211; This is an dual socket board which alow you to double the lane of the cpu. It has 4x fully functional x16 PCI Ex 3.0 Slot and an extra 4 x PCI Ex 2.0 Slot for a Mellanox card. </p>
<p>CPU: 2X E5-2623</p>
<p>Network card: Mellanox ConnectX-3 EN Network Adapter MCX313A-BCBT</p>
<p>Star of the show: 4x TitanX</p>
<p>Assume the other parts are $1000, total cost would be $7,585, half the price of the Nvidia Dev box. My god NVIDIA.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-314' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-314", "314", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Vu Pham'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="comment-316">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-08-04T16:44:26+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-316" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-08-04 at 16:44</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>This sounds like a very good system. I was not aware of the X10DRG-Q motherboard; usually such mainboards are not available for private customers — this is a great board! </p>
<p>I do not know the exact topology of the system compared to the Nvidia Dev box, but if you have two CPUs this means you will have an additional switch between the two PCIe networks and this will be a bottleneck where you have to transfers GPU memory through CPU buffers. This makes algorithms complicated and prone to human error, because you need to be careful how to pass data around in your system, that is, you need to take into account the whole PCIe topology (on which network and switch the infiniband card sits etc., on which network the GPU sits etc.). Cuda convnet2 has some 8 GPU code for a similar topology, but I do not think it will work out of the box. </p>
<p>If you can live with more complicated algorithms, then this will be a fine system for a GPU cluster.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-316' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-316", "316", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="comment-325">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/61da508f948415bb86e7860e5f23ef95?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/61da508f948415bb86e7860e5f23ef95?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://www.facebook.com/app_scoped_user_id/1691380981083432/" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Vu Pham</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-08-08T15:18:01+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-325" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-08-08 at 15:18</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim<br />
Fortunately, Supermicro provides me X10DRG-Q mobo diagram, and it would be also a gerneral diagram for other 2011 dual socket mobo which has 4 or morethan 4 PCIEX slot. 2 CPU are connected by 2 QPI &#8211; Intel QuickPath Interconnect.   If cpu1 has 40 lanes, then 32 lane for 2 PCI ex 16, 4x for 10Gigabit Lan, 4x for a 4x PCI ex (8x slot shape, which will be cover if you install 3rd graphic card). The 2nd cpu also provide 32 lane for pci express, then 8x will be 8x slot on the top slot (nearest cpu socket). Pretty complicated.<br />
The point when I build a perfect 4&#215;16 PCIex3.0 is that I though the performence gonna be half if the bandwidth go from 16x down to 8x. Do you have any infomation how much performnce different, said a single titan x, on a 16x 3.0 and 16x 2.0?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-325' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-325", "325", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Vu Pham'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment even depth-4" id="comment-326">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-08-08T15:43:45+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-326" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-08-08 at 15:43</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Yes, that sounds complicated indeed! A 16x 2.0 will be as fast as a 8x 3.0, so the bandwidth is also halved by stepping down to 2.0. I do not think there exists a single solution which is easy and at the same time cheap. In the end I think the training time will not be that much slower if you run 4 GPUs on 8x 3.0 and with that setup you would not run in any programming problems for parallelism and you will be able to use standard software like Torch7 with integrated parallelism — so I would just go for a 8x 3.0 setup.</p>
<p>If you want a less complicated system that is still faster, you can think about getting a cheap InfiniBand FDR card on eBay. That way you would buy 6 cheap GPUs and all hook them up via InfiniBand at 8x 3.0. But probably this will be a bit slower than straight 4x GTX Titan X on 8x 3.0 on a single board.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-326' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-326", "326", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-317">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4b07a187faff62e04bd020080b848b72?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4b07a187faff62e04bd020080b848b72?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">gac</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-08-05T04:19:14+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-317" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-08-05 at 04:19</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim,</p>
<p>First of all, excellent blog! I&#8217;m putting together a gpu workstation for my research activities and have learned a lot from the information you&#8217;ve provided so &#8230;. thanks!! 🙂</p>
<p>I have a pretty basic question. So basic I almost feel stupid asking it but here goes &#8230;</p>
<p>Given your deep learning setup which has 3x GeForce Titan X for computational tasks, what are your monitors plugged in to?</p>
<p>I would like a very similar setup to yours (except I&#8217;ll have two 29&#8243; monitors) and I was wondering if it&#8217;s possible to plug these into the Titan cards and have them render the display AND run calculations.</p>
<p>Or is it better to just have another, much cheaper, graphics cards which is just for display purposes?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-317' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-317", "317", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to gac'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="comment-318">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-08-05T05:42:56+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-318" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-08-05 at 05:42</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>I have my monitors plugged into a single GTX Titan X and I experience no side effects from that other than a couple of hundreds MB memory that is needed for the monitors; the performance for CUDA compute should be almost the same (probably something like 99.5%). So no worries here, just plug them in where it works for you (on windows, one monitor would also be an option I think).</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-318' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-318", "318", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-323">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/8d2ceff9c4f4168b7c08315273d27117?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/8d2ceff9c4f4168b7c08315273d27117?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="http://howtobeahacker.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">howtobeahacker</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-08-08T08:19:13+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-323" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-08-08 at 08:19</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi, I intend to plug in 2 GPU Titan X in my workstation. In the spec of my workstation, it said that it is possible to have up 2 NVIDIA K20 GPUs. In fact, K20 and TitanX are the same size. However, when I get the first Titan X GPU, I measure that if I plug the second in, there is a tiny space between 2 GPUs. I wonder if it is safe for the cooling of the GPU system.<br />
Hope to have your opinion.<br />
Thanks</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-323' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-323", "323", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to howtobeahacker'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="comment-324">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-08-08T09:15:16+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-324" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-08-08 at 09:15</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>A very tiny space between GPUs is typical for non-tesla cards and your cards should be safe. The only problem is, that your GPUs might run slower because they reach their 80 degrees temperature limit earlier. If you run a unix system, flashing a custom BIOS to your Titans will modify the fan regulation so that your GPUs should be cool (&lt; 80 degrees C) at all times. However, this may increase the noise and heat inside the room where your system is located. Flashing a BIOS for better fan regulation will most and foremost only increase the lifetime of your GPUs, but overall everything should be fine and safe without any modifications even if you operate your cards at maximum temperature for some days without pause (I personally used the standard settings for a few years and all my GPUs are still running well).</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-324' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-324", "324", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-329">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/db9bf310727783f21361446a13354b09?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/db9bf310727783f21361446a13354b09?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="http://www.csc.kth.se/~roelof/" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Roelof</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-08-09T20:42:01+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-329" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-08-09 at 20:42</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim,<br />
Thanks a lot for your great hardware guide!</p>
<p>I&#8217;m planning to build a 3 x Titan X GPU setup, which will be more or less running on a constant basis: would you say that water cooling will make a big impact on performance (by keeping the temperatures always below the 80 degrees)?</p>
<p>As the machine will be installed remotely, where I don&#8217;t have easy access to it, I&#8217;m a bit nervous about installing a water cooling system in such a setup, with the risk of cooling leakage, so the &#8220;risk&#8221; has to be worth the performance gain 🙂<br />
Do you have any experience with water cooled systems, and would you say that it would be a useful addition ?</p>
<p>Also would you advise a nice tightly fit chassis, or a bigger one which allows better airflow ? </p>
<p>Finally (so many questions :P), would you think 1500 watt with 92-94% efficiency at 100% load should suffice in the case I might use 4 Titan X GPUs, or would it be better to go for a 1600W PSU ?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-329' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-329", "329", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Roelof'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment even depth-2" id="comment-330">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-08-10T04:55:16+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-330" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-08-10 at 04:55</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>If your operate the computer remotely, another option is to flash the BIOS of the GPU and crank up the fan to max speed. This will produce a lot of noise and heat, but your GPUs should run slightly below 80 degrees, or at 80 degrees with little performance lost.</p>
<p>Water cooling is of course much superior but if you have little experience with it it might be better to just go with an air cooled setup. I have heard if installed correctly, water cooling is very reliable, so maybe this would be an option when somebody else, how is familiar with water cooling helps you to set it up.</p>
<p>In my experience, the chassis does not make such a big difference. It is all about the GPU fans, and getting the heat out quickly (which is mostly towards the back and not through the case). I installed extra fans for better airflow within the case, but this only make a difference of 1-2 degrees. What might help more are extra backplates and small attachable cooling pads for your memory (both about 2-5 degrees).</p>
<p>I used a 1600W PSU with 4 GTX Titans which need just as much power as a GTX Titan X and it worked fine. I guess 1500W would also work well and 92-94% efficiency is really good. I would try with the 1500W one and if it does not work just send it back.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-330' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-330", "330", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="comment-331">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/db9bf310727783f21361446a13354b09?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/db9bf310727783f21361446a13354b09?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="http://www.csc.kth.se/~roelof/" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Roelof</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-08-10T16:57:16+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-331" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-08-10 at 16:57</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Thanks for the detailed reponse, I&#8217;ve decided to go for:</p>
<p>&#8211; Chassis: Corsair Carbide Air 540<br />
&#8211; Motherboard: ASUS X99-E WS<br />
&#8211; Cpu: Intel(Haswell-e) Core i7 5930K<br />
&#8211; Ram: 64GB DDR4 Kingston 2133Mhz<br />
&#8211; Gpu: 3 x NVIDIA GTX TITAN-X 12GB<br />
&#8211; HD1: 2 X 500GB SSD Samsung EVO<br />
&#8211; HD2: 3 X 3TB WD Red in RAID 5<br />
&#8211; PSU: Corsair AX1500i (1500Watt) </p>
<p>With a custom build water cooling system for both the Cpu and the 3 Titan X&#8217;s, which I hope will let me crank up these babies while keeping the temperature all times below the 80 degrees.</p>
<p>The machine is partly (at least the chassis is) inspired by Nvidia&#8217;s recently released DevBox for Deep Learning (<a href="https://developer.nvidia.com/devbox" rel="nofollow">https://developer.nvidia.com/devbox</a>), but for almost 1/2 of the price. Will post some benchmarks with the newer cuDNN v3 once its build and all setup.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-331' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-331", "331", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Roelof'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="comment-333">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/54e1dfcdaecc1c551082000be42597fb?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/54e1dfcdaecc1c551082000be42597fb?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://plus.google.com/106235545478807004040" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Florijan Stamenković</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-08-11T12:34:14+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-333" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-08-11 at 12:34</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim!</p>
<p>We&#8217;ve already asked you for some advice, an it was helpful&#8230; We put together a dev-box in the meanwhile, with 4 Titans inside, it works perfectly.</p>
<p>Now we are considering production servers for image tasks. One of them would be classification. Considering the differences between training and runtime (runtime handles a single image, forward prop only), we were wondering if it would be more cost effective to run multiple weaker GPUs, as opposed to fewer stronger ones&#8230;. We are reasoning that a request queue consisting of single-image tasks could be processed faster on two separate cards, by two separate processes, then on a single card that is twice as fast. What are your thoughts on this?</p>
<p>We&#8217;ve run very crude experiments, comparing classification speed of a single image on a Titan machine, vs. 960M equipped laptops. The results were more or less as we expected: Titans are faster, but only about 2x, whereas Titans are 4x more expensive then a GTX960 (which has significantly more GFLOPS then the 960M). In absoulte terms, classification speed on a weaker card is acceptable, we&#8217;re wondering about behavior under heavy load.</p>
<p>F</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-333' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-333", "333", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Florijan Stamenković'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment even depth-2" id="comment-334">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-08-11T14:01:35+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-334" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-08-11 at 14:01</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Florijan!</p>
<p>I think in the end this is a numbers game. Try to overflow a GTX 960M and a Titan with images and see how fast they go and compare that with how fast you need to be. Additionally, it might make sense to run the runtime application on CPUs (might be cheaper and more scalable to run them on AWS or something) and only run the training on GPUs. I think a smart choice will take this into account, and how scalable and usable the solution is. Some AWS CPU spot instances might be a good solution until you see where your project is headed to (that is if a CPU is fast enough for your application).</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-334' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-334", "334", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-08-13T08:13:29+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-338" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-08-13 at 08:13</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>I think this will depend somewhat on how the PSU is designed, but I think you should be able to power two GTX Titan X with one double 6-pin cable, because the design makes it seem that it was intended for just that. Why would they put two 6-pin connectors on a cable if you cannot use them? I think you can find better information if you look up your PSU and see if there is a documentation, specification or something like that.</p>

	<li class="comment even depth-2" id="comment-341">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-08-16T09:39:21+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-341" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-08-16 at 09:39</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>The speedup should be about 4x when you go from a GTX 560 Ti to a GTX 980. The 4GB ram on the GTX 980 might be a bit restrictive for convolutional networks on large image datanets like ImageNet. A GTX Titan X or GTX 980 Ti will only be 50% faster than a GTX 980. If you wait about 14-18 months you can get a new Pascal card which should be at least 12x faster than your GTX 560 Ti. I personally would value getting additional experience now as more important than getting less experience now and faster training in the future — or in other words, I would go for the GTX 980.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-341' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-341", "341", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="comment-342">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/c97c3be7cdfdbb1e7ead5df0ddbcbcd2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/c97c3be7cdfdbb1e7ead5df0ddbcbcd2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Peter</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-08-17T15:36:29+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-342" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-08-17 at 15:36</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>How exactly would I be restricted by the 4GB of ram? Would I simply not be able to create a network with as many parameters, or would there be other negative effects (compared to the 6GB of the 980 Ti)?<br />
You&#8217;ve mentioned in the past that bandwidth is the most important aspect of the cards, and the 980 Ti has 50% higher bandwidth than the regular 980; would that mean it&#8217;s 50% faster too, or are there other factors involved?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-342' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-342", "342", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Peter'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment even depth-4" id="comment-343">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-08-17T16:56:10+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-343" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-08-17 at 16:56</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Yes, thats correct, if your convolutional network has too many parameters it will not fit into your RAM. Other factors besides memory bandwidth only play a minor role, so indeed, it should be about 50% better performance (not the 33% I quoted earlier (I edited this for correctness just now)).</p>
		</div>

<p>Thank you so much for this great writeup, it&#8217;s been pivotal in helping me and my co-founder understand the hardware.  We&#8217;re a duo from MIT currently working on a venture backed startup bringing deep learning to education, hoping to help at least improve, if not fix, the US education system.  </p>
<p>Our first build is aiming to be cheap where it can (since both of us are beginners and we need to be frugal with our funding) but future proof enough for us to do harder things.  </p>
<p>My current build consists of these parts:</p>
<p>Mobo: Asus X99-E WS SSI CEB LGA2011-3 Motherboard<br />
CPU: Intel Core i7-5820K 3.3GHz 6-Core Processor<br />
Vide Card: EVGA GeForce GTX 960 4GB SuperSC ACX 2.0+ Video Card<br />
PSU: EVGA 850W 80+ Gold Certified Fully-Modular ATX Power Supply</p>
<p>RAM: Corsair Vengeance LPX 16GB (2 x 8GB) DDR4-3000<br />
Storage: Sandisk SSD PLUS 240GB 2.5&#8243; Solid State Drive<br />
Case: Corsair Air 540 ATX Mid Tower Case</p>
<p>Could you look over these and offer any critique?  My logic was to have a Mobo and CPU that could handle upgrading to better hardware later, things like the PSU, Ram, and the 960 I&#8217;m willing to replace later on.  </p>
<p>Thank you in advance!  Also is there a way we could exchange emails and chat more?  </p>
<p>Would love any advice we can get from you while we build out our product.  </p>
<p>Best,</p>
<p>Mike Xia</p>

				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/226ba7bfa9851c0616a0e9a9d370e2b2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/226ba7bfa9851c0616a0e9a9d370e2b2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Colin McGrath</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>What are your opinions on RAID setups in a deep learning rig? Software-based RAID is pretty crappy in my experience and can cause a lot more problems than it solves. However, RAID controllers take a PCI-E slot which will, fortunately/unfortunately, all be taken by 4 x Gigabyte GTX 980 TI cards. Is it worth running RAID with the software controller? Or is it better just to do full copy clone backups?</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="comment-351">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-09-02T08:26:03+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-351" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-09-02 at 08:26</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>I do not think it is worth it. Usually, a common SATA SSD will be fast enough for most kinds of data; in come cases there will be a decrease in performance because the data takes too long to load, but compared to the effort and money spend on a RAID system (hardware) it is just not worth it.</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="comment-353">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/20ad794d46207f8bfd5a689853faa521?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/20ad794d46207f8bfd5a689853faa521?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Sascha</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi,</p>
<p>thanks a lot for all this information. After stumbling across a paper from Andrew Ng et al (&#8220;Deep learning with COTS HPC systems&#8221;) my original plan was to also build a cluster (to learn how it is done). I wanted to go for two machines with a bunch of GTX Titans but after reading your blog I settled with only one pc with two GTX 980s for the time being. My first thought after reading your blog was to actually settle for two 960s but then I thought about the energy consumption you mentioned. Looking at the specifications of the nvidia cards I figured the 980 were the most efficient choice currently (at least as long as you have to pay German energy prices).<br />
As I am still relatively fresh to machine learning I guess this setup will keep me busy enough for the next couple of months, probably until the pascal architecture you mentioned is available (I read somewhere 2nd half of 2016). If not then I guess I will buy another PC and move one of the 980s into it so that I can learn how to setup a cluster (my current goal is learning as much as fast as possible).</p>
<p>The configuration I went for is as follows:</p>
<p>CPU: Intel i7-5930k (I chose this one instead of the much cheaper 5920 as it has the 40 PCI lanes you mentioned, which gives the additional flexibility of handling 4 graphics cards)<br />
Mainboard: ASRock Fatal1ty X99 Professional (supports up to 4 graphics cards and has a M.2 slot)<br />
RAM: 4&#215;8 GB DDR4-3000<br />
Graphics Card: 2x Zotac  GTX 980 AMP! Edition<br />
Hard Disk: Samsung SSD SM951 with 256 GB (thanks to M.2 it offers 2 GB/s of sequential read performance)<br />
Power Supply: be quiet! BN205 with 1200 Watts</p>
<p>I hope that installing Linux on the ssd works as I read that the previous version of this ssd mad some problems.</p>
<p>Thanks again<br />
Sascha</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-353' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-353", "353", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Sascha'>Reply</a></div>

	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="comment-354">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-09-06T06:35:57+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-354" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-09-06 at 06:35</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Sascha! Your reasoning is solid and it seems to got a good plan for the future. Your build is good, but as you say, the PCIe SSD could be a bit problematic to set up. Another fact to be aware of is that your GPUs will have a slower connections with that SSD, because the SSD takes away bandwidth from your GPUs (your GPUs will run at 16x/8x instead of 16x/16x). Overall the PCIe SSD would be much faster for common applications, but slower when you use parallelism on two GPUs, it might be better to go for a SATA SSD (if you do not use parallelism that much a PCIe SSD is a solid choice). A SATA SSD will be slower than the PCIe one, but it should be still be faster enough for any deep learning task. However, preprocessing will be slower on this SSD, and this is probably the main advantage of the PCIe SSD.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-354' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-354", "354", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment even depth-3" id="comment-355">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/20ad794d46207f8bfd5a689853faa521?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/20ad794d46207f8bfd5a689853faa521?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Sascha</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-09-06T09:49:24+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-355" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-09-06 at 09:49</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>That is an interesting point you make regarding the M.2. I did not realise that this is how the board will distribute the lanes. I figured that as the M.2 only uses 4 lanes the two cards could each run with 16 and if I actually decided to scale up to a quad setup each card eventually would only get 8 lanes.</p>
<p>My first idea after reading the comment was to just try the ssd in the additional M.2 PCI 2.0 slot, which is basically a SATA 6 connection but that will not work, as it will not fit because one has the Key B and the other the Key M layout.</p>
<p>Do you have an idea about what this actually means for real life performance in deep learning tasks (like x% slower)?</p>
<p>Greetings<br />
Sascha</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-355' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-355", "355", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Sascha'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="comment-356">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-09-06T10:23:26+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-356" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-09-06 at 10:23</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>When I think about it again, I might be wrong about what I just said. How two GPUs and the PCIe SSD will work depends highly on your motherboard and how the PCIe slots are wired and how the PCIe-switches are distributed. I think with a 40 PCIe lane CPU and a mainboard that supports 16x/16x/8x layout, it should be possible to configure that to use 16 lanes for your GPUs and 8 lanes for your SSD; to use that setup you only need to make sure to plug everything into the right slot (your mainboard manual should state how to do this). I have not looked at your hardware in detail, but I think your hardware supports this.</p>
<p>If your motherboard does not support 16x/16x/8x, then your GPU parallelism will suffer from that. Convolutional nets will have a penalty of 5-15% depending on the architecture, recurrent networks may have a low or no penalty (LSTMs) or a high penalty (20-50%) for recurrent nets with many parameters like vanilla RNNs.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-356' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-356", "356", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-357">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/e926a7fa7752748f8666d28c47340cf4?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/e926a7fa7752748f8666d28c47340cf4?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">vinay</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-09-08T15:25:29+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-357" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-09-08 at 15:25</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Does anyone know what would be the requirements for prediction clusters?  Most articles focus on training aspects but inference/prediction is also important and compute demand for these are little discussed. Can anyone comment on compute demands for prediction?  Also, what do you recommend, CPU only, CPU+GPU, or CPU+FPGA, etc for such tasks?</p>
<p>Thanks,<br />
Vinay</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-357' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-357", "357", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to vinay'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="comment-358">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-09-08T17:15:23+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-358" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-09-08 at 17:15</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>It depends on many factors which is a suitable solution. If you build a web application, how long do you want your user to wait for a prediction (response time)? How many predictions are requested per second in total (throughput)?</p>
<p>Prediction is much faster than training, but still a forward pass of about 100 large images (or similar large input data) takes about 100 milliseconds on a GPU. A CPU could do that in a second or two.</p>
<p>If you predict one data point at a time a CPU will probably be faster than a GPU (convolution implementations relying on matrix multiplication are slow if the batch sizes are too small), so GPU processing is good if you need high throughput in busy environments, and a CPU for single predictions (1 image should take only 100 milliseconds for a good CPU implementations). Multiple CPU servers might also be an option, and usually they are easier to maintain and cheaper (AWS spot instances for example, also useful for GPU work). Keep in mind that all these these numbers are reasonable estimates only and will differ from the real results; results from a testing environment that simulates the real environment will make it clear if CPU servers or GPU servers will be optimal.</p>
<p>I do not recommend FPGA for such tasks since over time, interfaces to FPGA are not easy to maintain and cloud solutions do not exist (as far as I know).</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-358' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-358", "358", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

<p> &#8211; ASRock X99 WS-E<br />
 &#8211; 1x Gigabyte G1 980 ti<br />
 &#8211; 16GB Corsair Vengeance RAM 2133<br />
 &#8211; i7-5930k<br />
 &#8211; 2x Samsung 850 Pro 256GB SSDs (boot drives)<br />
 &#8211; 2x Seagate Barracuda 3TB HDDs (storage drives)</p>
<p>My windows install is fine, but I want to be able to store currently unused data in the HDD, stage batches in the SSD then send the batches from SSD to RAM to fully leverage the IOPS gain in a SSD.</p>
<p>I currently have Ubuntu partitioned this way, however I&#8217;m not entirely sure this will fit my needs. I&#8217;m thinking I might want to allocate /home on the HDD due to how ubuntu handles the /home directory in the UI, but I&#8217;m unsure if that will be a problem with deep learning:</p>
<p>SSD (boot):<br />
 &#8211; swap area &#8211; 16GB<br />
 &#8211; / &#8211; 20GB<br />
 &#8211; /home &#8211; 20GB<br />
 &#8211; /var &#8211; 10GB<br />
 &#8211; /boot &#8211; 512MB<br />
 &#8211; /tmp &#8211; 10GB<br />
 &#8211; /var/log &#8211; 10GB</p>
<p>HDD<br />
 &#8211; /store 1TB</p>

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="comment-545">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-09-25T19:30:28+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-545" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-09-25 at 19:30</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Three monitors will use up some additional memory (300-600MB) but should not affect your performance greatly (&lt; 2% performance loss). I recommend getting a cheap GPU for your monitors only if you are short on memory.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-545' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-545", "545", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

	<li class="comment even depth-2" id="comment-547">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-09-28T17:33:35+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-547" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-09-28 at 17:33</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>I looked at some performance reviews and they state about 70-90% performance for gaming. For deep learning the only performance bottleneck will be transfers from host to GPU and from what I read the bandwidth is good (20GB/s) but there is a latency problem. However, that latency problem should not be too significant for deep learning (unless it&#8217;s a HUGE increase in latency, which is unlikely). So if I put these pieces of information together it looks as if an external graphics card via Thunderbolt should be a good option if you have an apple computer and have the money to spare for the suitable external adapter.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-547' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-547", "547", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment even depth-2" id="comment-551">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-10-05T07:45:26+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-551" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-10-05 at 07:45</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>A GTX 750 should be better, and both support cuDNN. However, I would also suggest that you have a look at AWS GPU instances. The instance will be a bit faster and may suit your budget well.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-551' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-551", "551", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim..</p>
<p>Recently I have had a ton of trouble working with Ubuntu 14.04 &#8230;installing Cuda, caffe etc.  Ubuntu has password locked me out of my system twice and getting all dependencies installed to make caffe to install has been a real problem.  It works sometimes &#8230;other times it doesn&#8217;t work.  Ubuntu 14.04 is clearly an unstable OS.  </p>
<p>I would like your opinion TIm on moving from Linux to Windows for deep learning?   What are your thoughts?</p>
<p>Thanks in advance&#8230;</p>
<p>-Greg</p>

	<li class="comment even depth-2" id="comment-553">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="https://timdettmers.wordpress.com" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Tim Dettmers</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-10-07T10:34:31+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-553" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-10-07 at 10:34</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>I can feel your pain — I have been there too! Ubuntu 14.04 is certainly not intuitive when you are switching from Windows and a simple unseemingly command can ruin your installation. However, I found once you understand how everything is connected in Linux things get easier, make sense, and you no longer will run into errors which break your installations or even our OS. After this point, programming in Linux will be much more comfortable than in Windows due to the ease to compile and install any library. So it may be painful but it is well worth it. You will gain a lot of if you go through the pain-mile — keep it up!</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-553' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-553", "553", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

I think the Cuda driver slammed Unity resetting the root password to something other than the password I gave it.  I search the web and this is a common problem and there seems to be no fix.</p>
<p>I&#8217;m running x99 MB, I7 5930, 64 GB ram, and one Titan x.  I&#8217;ll get a second Titan x when I&#8217;m ready for it. I want to create my own NN and nodes but for now I have a ton of learning to do and I need to follow what&#8217;s been done so far.  </p>
<p>Do you use standard libraries and algorithms like Caffe, Torch 7 and Theano via Python?  I feel I need to wade through everything to see how it works before using it.  Nvidia Digits looks pretty simple working from the GUI but it also looks, from my limited experience, like it&#8217;s pretty limited.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Is this because of your x99 board? I never had any problems like that. As for the software, Torch7 and Theano (Keras and derivatives) works just fine for me. I have tried Caffe once and it worked, but I also heard some nightmare stories about installing Caffe correctly. NVIDIA Digits will be just as you described: Simple and fast, but if you want to do something more complex it will just be an expensive fast PC with 4 GTX Titan X.</p>
		</div>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-10-07T20:36:40+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-556" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-10-07 at 20:36</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Just to tag onto this, I have an X-99 E board, and had some problems on the initial install when trying to boot into ubuntu&#8217;s live installer, nothing with the password though.  After installing everything worked fine at the OS level.  In case this is relevant, reflashing to the latest BIOS helped a lot, but probably won&#8217;t help your password problem.  </p>
<p>Cheers and best of luck!</p>
<p>Mike</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-571">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-10-08T18:42:15+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-571" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-10-08 at 18:42</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Brent, I think in terms of the price, you could definitely do better on the 1U model with 4 GTX Titan X. A normal board with 1 CPU will not have any disadvantage compared to the 1U model for deep learning.</p>
<p>However, the 4U model is different because it can use 8 GTX Titan X with a fast CPU-to-CPU switch which makes parallelization of 8 GPUs easy and fast. There are only few solutions available that are build like this and come with 8 GTX Titan X — so while the price is high, this will be a rather unique and good solution.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-571' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-571", "571", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="comment-803">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="comment-693">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/6a996f5a44b32a421edc6d1cf0f55054?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/6a996f5a44b32a421edc6d1cf0f55054?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">BK</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-10-21T16:50:52+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-693" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-10-21 at 16:50</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim,</p>
<p>Great post; In general all of the content on your blog has been fantastic.<br />
I&#8217;m a little curious about your thoughts on other types of hardware for use in deep learning. I&#8217;ve heard a number of people suggest FPGAs to be potentially useful for deep learning(and parallel processing in general) due to their memory efficiency vs. GPUs. This is often mentioned in the context of Xeon Phi&#8230;.what are your thoughts on this? If true, where does the usefulness lie, in the &#8216;tracking&#8217; or &#8216;scoring&#8217; part of deep learning(my perhaps incorrect understanding was GPUs advantage was their use for training as opposed to scoring)? </p>
<p>My apologies for what I&#8217;m certain are sophomoric questions; I&#8217;m trying to wrap my head around these matters as someone new to the subject!</p>
<p>Regards,</p>
<p>BK</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-693' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-693", "693", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to BK'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-755">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-10-26T22:02:55+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-755" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-10-26 at 22:02</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Nonsense, these are great questions! Keep them coming!</p>
<p>FPGAs could be quite useful for embedded devices, but I do not believe they will replace GPUs. This is because (1) their individual performance is still worse than an individual GPU and (2) combining them into sets of multiple FPGAs yields poor performance while GPUs provide very efficient interfaces (especially with NVLink which will be available at the end of 2016). GPUs will make a very big jump in 2016 (3D memory) and I do not think FPGAs will ever catch up from there.</p>
<p>Xeon Phi is potentially more powerful than GPUs, because it is easier to optimize them at the low level. However, they lack the software for efficient deep learning (just like AMD cards) and as such it is unlikely that one will see Xeon Phis be used for deep learning in the future (unless Intel creates a huge deep learning initiative that rivals the initiative of NVIDIA).</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-755' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-755", "755", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-987">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-11-21T11:18:53+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-987" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-11-21 at 11:18</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>The GTX 950 2GB variant might be a bit short on RAM for speech recognition if you use more powerful models like LSTMs. The cheapest solution might be to prototype on your CPU and use AWS GPU instances to run the model if everything looks good. This way you need no new computer/PSU and will be able to run large LSTMs and other models. If this does not suit you, a GTX 950 with 4GB of memory might be a good choice.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-987' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-987", "987", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
