	<li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="comment-1204">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/22361e99407210fb46e8690b003822fa?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/22361e99407210fb46e8690b003822fa?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Rohit Mundra</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-12-22T02:48:54+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-1204" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-12-22 at 02:48</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hey Tim,</p>
<p>Thanks for the great article; I have a more specific question though &#8211; I&#8217;m building an entry-level Kaggle-worthy system using an i7-5820K processor. Since I want to keep my GTX 960&#8217;s 4GB memory solely for deep learning, would you recommend I buy an additional (cheaper) graphic card for display or not? I&#8217;m considering the GT 610 for this purpose since it&#8217;s cheap enough. Also, if I were to do this, where would I specify such a setting (e.g. use GT 610 for display)? </p>
<p>Thanks again!<br />
Rohit</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-1204' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-1204", "1204", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Rohit Mundra'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-1209">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2015-12-22T14:06:10+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-1209" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2015-12-22 at 14:06</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>For most datasets on Kaggle your GPU memory should be okay and using another small GPU for you monitors will not do much. However, if you are doing one of the deep learning competitions and you find yourself short on memory and you think you could improve your score by using a model that is a bit larger then this might be worth it. So I would only consider this option if you really encounter problems where you are short on memory.</p>
<p>Also remember that the memory requirements of convolutional nets increases most quickly with the batch-size, so going from a batch-size of 128 to 96 or something similar might also solve memory problems (although this might also decrease your accuracy a bit, its all quite dependent on the data set and problem). Another option would be to use the Nervana system deep learning libraries which can run models in 16-bit, thus halving the memory footprint.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-1209' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-1209", "1209", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-1430">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/2eb5573692e5835d4f529f1da626910f?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/2eb5573692e5835d4f529f1da626910f?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">JB</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-01-10T22:01:16+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-1430" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-01-10 at 22:01</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Tim,</p>
<p>First of all, thank you for writing this!  This post has been extremely helpful to me.</p>
<p>I&#8217;m thinking about getting a gtx 970 now and upgrading to pascal when it comes out.  So, if I never use more than 3.5gb vram at a time, then I won&#8217;t see performance hits, correct?  I&#8217;m building my rig for deep reinforcement learning (mostly atari right now), so my minibatches are small (&lt;2MB), and so are my convnets (&lt;2mill weights).  Should I be fine until pascal?</p>
<p>I&#039;m trying to decide between these two budget builds: [Intel Xeon e5](<a href="http://pcpartpicker.com/p/dXbXjX" rel="nofollow">http://pcpartpicker.com/p/dXbXjX</a>) and [Intel i5](<a href="http://pcpartpicker.com/p/ktnHdC" rel="nofollow">http://pcpartpicker.com/p/ktnHdC</a>).  I&#039;m thinking about going with the Xeon, since it has all 40 pcie lanes if I wanted to do more than two gpus in the future, and it&#039;s a beefier processor.  However, I start grad school in the fall, so I&#039;d have university hardware then, and think I&#039;d be more than fine with two gpus for personal experiments in the future. (Or could 4 lanes be enough bandwidth for a gpu?)  If I get the i5 I could upgrade the processor without having to upgrade the motherboard if I wanted.  The processor just needs to be good enough to run (atari) emulations and preprocess images right now.  I can&#039;t really imagine anything but the GPU being the bottleneck, right?  </p>
<p>Thank you for the help.  I&#039;m trying to figure out something that will last me awhile, and I&#039;m not very familiar with hardware yet.</p>
<p>Thanks again,<br />
&#8211; JB</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi JB,</p>
<p>the GTX 970 will perform normally if you stay below 3.5GB of memory. Since your mini-batches are small and you seems to have rather few weights this should fit quite well into that memory. So in your case the GTX 970 should give you optimal cost/performance.</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-1651">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-01-25T14:08:42+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-1651" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-01-25 at 14:08</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Linux based system are currently best for deep learning since all major deep learning software frameworks support linux. Another advantage is, that you will be able to compile almost anything without any problems while on other systems (Mac OS, Windows) there will always be some problems or it may be nearly impossible to configure a system well.</p>
<p>Ubuntu is good, because it is widely used, easy to install and configure, and it has some support for their LTS versions which makes it attractive for software developers which target linux systems. If you do not like Ubuntu you can use Kubuntu, or other X-buntu variants; if you like a clean slate and to configure everything they way you like I recommend Arch Linux, but be beware that it will take a while until you configured everything the way it is suitable for you.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-1651' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-1651", "1651", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-1938">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/22b5efe909e560a7cffdb28f0ceaa079?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/22b5efe909e560a7cffdb28f0ceaa079?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Lawrence</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-02-06T22:36:25+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-1938" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-02-06 at 22:36</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim,<br />
Great website ! I am building a Devbox, <a href="https://developer.nvidia.com/devbox" rel="nofollow">https://developer.nvidia.com/devbox</a>.<br />
My machine has 4 Titan X cards, Kingston Digital HyperX Predator 480 GB PCIe Gen2 x 4 , Intel Core i7-5930K Haswell-E, and G.SKILL 64GB. I am using ASUS RAMPAGE V extreme motherboard. When I place the last Titan X card on the last slot, my SSD gets disapered from bios. I am not sure I have a PCIe conflict ? Does M.2 can interfere with PCIE_X8_4. What should I do to fix this issue ? Should I change the motherboard, any advice ?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-1938' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-1938", "1938", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Lawrence'>Reply</a></div>

	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-1950">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-02-07T11:46:23+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-1950" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-02-07 at 11:46</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Your motherboard only supports 40 PCIe lanes, which is standard, because CPUs only support a maximum of 40 PCIe lanes. Your 4 Titan X will run in 16x/8x/8x/8x lane mode. You might be able to switch the first GPU to 8x manually, but even then CPUs and motherboards usually do not support a 8x/8x/8x/8x/8x mode (usually two PCIe switches are supported for a single GPU, and a single PCIe switch supports two devices, so you can only run 4 PCIe devices in total). This means that there is probably no possibility to get your PCIe SSD working with 4 GPUs. I might be wrong. To check this it is best to contact your ASUS tech support and ask them if the configuration is possible or not.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-1950' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-1950", "1950", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-4" id="comment-2213">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-02-19T16:00:35+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-2213" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-02-19 at 16:00</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Bobby,</p>
<p>I have no experience with RAID 5, since usual datasets will not benefit from increased read speeds as long as you have a SSD. I think you will need to change some things in BIOS and then setup a few things for your operating system with a raid manager. I think you will be able to find a tutorial for your OS online so you can get it running.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-2213' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-2213", "2213", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-2243">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/f1bbd3b2b39d7e2e4d56eae32c7db962?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/f1bbd3b2b39d7e2e4d56eae32c7db962?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">viper65</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-02-22T22:20:10+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-2243" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-02-22 at 22:20</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Nice article!<br />
What do you think about HBM? Apart from the size of ram, do you think that fury x has any advantage comparing to 980Ti?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-2243' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-2243", "2243", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to viper65'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-2256">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-02-23T13:05:16+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-2256" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-02-23 at 13:05</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>The Fury X definitely has the edge over the GTX 980 Ti in terms of hardware, though in terms of software the AMD still lags behind. This will change quite dramatically once NVIDIA Pascal hits the marked in a few months. HBM is definitely the way to go to get better performance. However, the HBM of NVIDIA offers double the memory bandwidth from the Furx X and Pascal will also allows for 16-bit computations which effectively doubles the performance further. So I would not recommend getting a Fury X, but instead to wait for Pascal.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-2256' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-2256", "2256", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-2702">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-03-18T13:22:05+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-2702" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-03-18 at 13:22</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>You can resolve the compatibility issue by choosing a larger mainboard. A larger mainboard should give you better RAM voltage and also fixes the PCIe issue. Although the GTX 680 might be a bit limiting for training state of the art models, it is still a good choice to learn on the Data Science Bowl dataset. Once Pascal hits the market you can easily upgrade and will be able to train all state-of-the-art networks easily and quickly.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-2702' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-2702", "2702", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-4" id="comment-2746">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-03-20T22:02:56+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-2746" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-03-20 at 22:02</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Pascal will be the new chip from NVIDIA which will be released in a few months. It should be designated as GTX 10xx. The xx80 refers to the most powerful GPU consumer model of a given series, e.g. the GTX 980 is the most powerful the 900s series. The GTX Titan is usually the model for professionals (deep learning, computer graphics for industry and so forth).</p>
<p>And yes I would wait for Pascal rather than buy a GTX 980. You could buy a cheap small card and sell it once Pascal hits the market.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-2746' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-2746", "2746", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/51f255d405a0b3dddbbb3bd29282512c?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/51f255d405a0b3dddbbb3bd29282512c?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Phong</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-2686' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-2686", "2686", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Phong'>Reply</a></div>

	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-2700">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-03-18T13:15:26+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-2700" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-03-18 at 13:15</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>There is also a 4GB GTX 680 variant which is quite okay. Of course a GTX 980 with 6GB would be better, but it is also way more expensive. However, I would recommend one GTX 980 over multiple GTX 680. It is just not worth the trouble to parallelize on these rather slow cards.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-2700' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-2700", "2700", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Certain Haswells do not support the full 40 PCIe lanes. So if you buy a Haswell make sure it support it if you want to run with multiple GPUs.</p>

		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-04-04T07:46:15+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-3024" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-04-04 at 07:46</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>That is an AOC E2795VH. Unfortunately they are not sold anymore. But I think any monitor with a good rating will do.</p>
		</div>

	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-04-05T04:49:45+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-3035" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-04-05 at 04:49</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Everyone seems to be using an Intel CPU, but they seem prohibitively expensive if actual clock speed or cache isn&#8217;t that important&#8230;  Would an AMD cpu with 38 lane support work just as well paired with two GPUs?</p>
<p>Also, have you experimented with builds using two different GPUs?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-3035' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-3035", "3035", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Matt'>Reply</a></div>

	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-3046">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-04-05T20:09:17+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-3046" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-04-05 at 20:09</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Yes, a AMD CPU should work just as well on 2 GPUs as an intel one. However, using two different GPUs will not work if the have different chipsets (GTX 980 + GTX 970 will not work); what will work if you have different vendors (EVGA GTX 980 + ASUS GTX 980 will work with no problems).</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-3046' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-3046", "3046", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim,</p>
<p>This post was amazingly useful for me. I&#8217;ve never built a machine before and this feels very much like jumping in the deep end. There are two things I&#8217;m still wondering about:</p>
<p>1. If I&#8217;m using my GPU(s) for deep learning, can I still run my monitor off of them? If not should I get some (relatively) cheap graphics card to run the monitor, or do something else?</p>
<p>2. Do you have any opinion about Intel&#8217;s i7-4820K CPU vs. the i7-5820K CPU? There seems to be a speed vs. cache size &amp; cores trade-off here. My impression is that whatever difference there is will be small, but the larger cache size should lead to fewer cache misses, which should be better. Is this accurate?</p>
<p>Thanks</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-3451">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-04-24T08:03:07+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-3451" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-04-24 at 08:03</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Dorje,<br />
I also thought about buying a TX1 instead of a new laptop, but then I opted against it. The overall performance on the TX1 is great for a small, mobile, embedded device, but not so great compared to desktop GPUs or even laptop GPUs. There might also be issues if you want to install new hardware because it might not be supported by the Ubuntu for Tegra OS. I think in the end the money is better spend to get a small, cheap laptop and buy some credit for GPU instances on AWS. Soon there will also be high performance instances (featuring the new Pascal P100), so this would also be a good choice for the future.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-3451' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-3451", "3451", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-3205">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/8ddbd819d4f94e298a5bfd021ac6ce55?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/8ddbd819d4f94e298a5bfd021ac6ce55?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Yi</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-04-14T07:52:32+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-3205" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-04-14 at 07:52</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim,</p>
<p>Thanks for the great post. Sorry to bother you again. I just want to ask sth about coolbits option of the GPU cards. Right now, I set it to 12 and I can manually control the fan speed. It works nicely. But I won&#8217;t check the temperature all the time and change the fan speed accordingly. So during training, how much percentage of fan speed should I use? 50%, or 80% or an aggressive 90% maybe? Thanks a lot.</p>
<p>And if I keep the fan always running at 80% speed, will it reduce the lifecycle of the card? Thanks.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-3205' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-3205", "3205", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Yi'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-3449">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-04-24T07:56:37+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-3449" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-04-24 at 07:56</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>The life expectancy of the card will increase the cooler you keep it. So if you can you can keep the fan at 100% at all times. However, this of course can problems with noise if the machine is nearby you or other people. For my desktop I keep the fan as low as possible to keep the GPU below 80 degrees C and if I leave the room I just set the fan speed to 100%.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-3449' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-3449", "3449", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment even depth-3" id="comment-3473">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/8ddbd819d4f94e298a5bfd021ac6ce55?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/8ddbd819d4f94e298a5bfd021ac6ce55?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Yi</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-04-25T06:25:38+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-3473" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-04-25 at 06:25</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-3473' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-3473", "3473", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Yi'>Reply</a></div>

	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="comment-5508">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a8c5c3bcc2558403832582d29d002929?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a8c5c3bcc2558403832582d29d002929?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Spuddler</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-06-11T17:41:53+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-5508" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-06-11 at 17:41</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Keep in mind that running your fans at 100% constantly will wear out the fans much faster &#8211; although that is better than a dead GPU chip. It can be difficult to find cheap replacement fans for some GPUs, so you should look for cheap ones on alibaba etc. and have a few spares lying around in advance since shipping from china takes weeks.</p>
<p>Also, when a fan stops running smoothly, you can usually just buy cheap &#8220;ball bearing oil&#8221; ($4 on ebay or so) and remove the sticker on the front side of the fan. There will be some tiny holes beneath into which you can simply squirt some of the oil and most likely the fan will run as good as new. Worked out for me so far</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-5508' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-5508", "5508", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Spuddler'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="comment-3354">

		<header class="comment-header">

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-04-18T15:12:55+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-3354" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-04-18 at 15:12</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Thanks for the great blog, i learned a lot.<br />
For me getting a 40 lane or even 28 lane CPU-MB is out of budget. In my country these parts are rare.<br />
I am planning to get a 16 lane CPU. With this i can get MB which has 2xPCIe 3.0 x16. I plan to use single GPU initially. If i want to use 2 GPU&#8217;s it has to be x8/x8 configuration. With this configuration is it practical to use 2 GPU&#8217;s in the future?<br />
My system will likely have i7 6700, Asus Z170-A and Titan X.</p>
<p>Cheers,<br />
RK</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-3354' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-3354", "3354", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Raj'>Reply</a></div>

	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-3361">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-04-18T19:55:39+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-3361" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-04-18 at 19:55</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi RK,<br />
16 lanes should still work good with 2 GPUs (but make sure the CPU supports x8/x8 lanes — I think every CPU does, but I never used them myself). The transfer to the GPU will be slower, but the computation on the should still be as fast. You probably see a performance drop of 0-5% depending on the data that you have.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-3361' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-3361", "3361", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-3463">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/3f183afbf7a6a1676c77110f9a579f1c?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/3f183afbf7a6a1676c77110f9a579f1c?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Eduardo</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-04-24T10:02:27+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-3463" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-04-24 at 10:02</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi, I am a Brazilian student, so everything is way too expensive for me. I will buy a gtx 960 and start of with a single GPU and expand later on. The problem is that intel CPUs with 30+ lanes are WAY too expensive. So I HAVE to go with AMD, but the motherboards for AMD only have PCIe 2.0.</p>
<p>My question is: can I get a good performance out of 2 x 960  GPUs on a PCIe 2 .0 x16 mobo? By good I mean equal to a single 960 with x16 on a PCIe 3.0, maybe even a single gtx 980.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-3463' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-3463", "3463", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Eduardo'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-3465">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-04-24T13:23:22+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-3465" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-04-24 at 13:23</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi, both a Intel CPU with 16 lanes or less (as long as your motherboard supports 2 GPUs) as well as AMD with PCIe 2.0 will be fine. You will not see large decreases in performance. It should be about 0-10% depending on task and deep learning software.<br />
If you are short on money it might also be an option to use AWS GPU instances. If you do not train every day this might be cheaper in the end. However, for tinkering around with deep learning a GTX 960 will be a pretty solid option.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-3465' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-3465", "3465", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-3914">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">

		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/453c590ec2d29b7502d96b99bd7a6283?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/453c590ec2d29b7502d96b99bd7a6283?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">DD Sharma</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-05-13T15:15:36+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-4214" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-05-13 at 15:15</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hello Tim,</p>
<p>Comparing two cards for GPGPU (Deep Learning being an instance of a GPGPU) what is more important: # of cores or memory? For learning purposes and may be some model dev I am considering a low end card (512 cores, 2GB) .. will this seriously cripple me? Other than giving-up  performance gains, will it seriously be constraining? I checked research work of folks from 5+ years ago and many in academia used processors with even weaker specs and still got something done. Once I discover that I am doing something real serious I can go to Amazon cloud or get an external GPU (connect via Thunderbolt 3) or build a machine.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-4214' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-4214", "4214", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to DD Sharma'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-4828">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-05-26T11:12:49+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-4828" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-05-26 at 11:12</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Neither cores nor memory is important per se. Cores do not matter really. Bandwidth is important and FLOPS second most important. You need a certain memory to training certain networks. For state of the art models you should have more than 6GB of memory.</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="comment-5419">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/02bdb0d8ccbb17de17c57d4036c44000?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/02bdb0d8ccbb17de17c57d4036c44000?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Adrian Sarno</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-06-09T18:48:18+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-5419" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-06-09 at 18:48</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Tim,</p>
<p>I&#8217;m looking for information on which GPU cards have support for convolutional layers, in particular I was considering a laptop with the GTX 970, but according to your blog above it does not support convolutional nets.  Would you ind to explain what does that mean in terms of features and also time performance? Is there a way to know from the spec whether the card is good for conv nets?</p>
<p>thanks in advance</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-5419' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-5419", "5419", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Adrian Sarno'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-5506">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-06-11T16:16:41+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-5506" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-06-11 at 16:16</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Maybe I have been a bit unclear in my post. The GTX 970 supports convolutional nets just fine, but if you use more then 3.5GB of memory you will be slowed down. If you use 16-bit networks though you can still train relatively well sized networks. So a GTX 970 is okay for most non-research, non-I-want-to-get-into-top5-kaggle use-cases.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-5506' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-5506", "5506", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->

	<li class="comment even depth-2" id="comment-5548">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a8c5c3bcc2558403832582d29d002929?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a8c5c3bcc2558403832582d29d002929?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Spuddler</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-06-12T21:48:37+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-5548" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-06-12 at 21:48</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>as far as I know, quadro cards are usually optimized for CAD applications, you can use them for deep learning but they will not be as cost efficient as regular geforce cards. </p>
<p>Your problem with Ubuntu not booting is a strange one, does not really look like a graphics driver issue since you get a screen. Before googling for more difficult troubleshooting procedures I would try other Ubuntu 14.04 LTS flavours if I were you, like Xubuntu (windows-like, lightweight), Kubuntu (windows-like, fancy) or even Lubuntu (very lightweight). It may just be some arcane issue with Ubuntu&#8217;s Gnome Desktop and your hardware.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-5548' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-5548", "5548", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Spuddler'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-5698">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-06-16T16:29:01+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-5698" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-06-16 at 16:29</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>This is a good build for a general computation machine. A bit expensive for deep learning, as the performance is mostly determined by the GPU. Using more GPUs and cheaper CPU/Motherboard/RAM would be better for deep learning, but I guess you want to use the PC also for something different than deep learning :). This would be a good PC for kaggle competitions. If you plan on running very big models (like doing research) then I would recommend a GTX Titan X for memory reasons.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-5698' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-5698", "5698", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Thanks for all the info.   If I plan to use only one GPU for computation, then would I expect to need two GPUs in my system: one for computation and another for driving a couple of displays?  Or can a single GPU be used for both jobs?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-5670' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-5670", "5670", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Glenn'>Reply</a></div>

	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-5697">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-06-16T16:25:36+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-5697" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-06-16 at 16:25</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>A single GPU is fine for both. A monitor will use about 100-300MB of your GPU memory and usually draw an insignificant amount (&lt;2%) of performance. It is also the easier option, so I would just recommend to use a single GPU.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-5697' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-5697", "5697", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-5700">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-5767">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-06-18T22:37:21+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-5767" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-06-18 at 22:37</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>A GTX 970 is an excellent option to explore deep learning. You will not be able to train the very largest models, but that is also not something you want to do when you explore. It is mostly learning how to train small networks on common and easy problems, such as AlexNet and similar convolutional nets on MNIST, CIFAR10 and other small data sets, until you get a &#8220;feel&#8221; for training convolutions nets so that you then can go on with larger models and larger data sets (ResNet on ImageNet for example). So everything is good.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-5767' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-5767", "5767", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-5842">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/b858a687510ec83af790800f4f0716a1?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/b858a687510ec83af790800f4f0716a1?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Milan Ender</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-06-21T00:12:20+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-5842" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-06-21 at 00:12</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hey,<br />
first of all thanks for the guide, helped me immensely to get some clarity in this puzzle! 🙂<br />
Couple of questions as I&#8217;m a bit too impatient to wait for 1080/70 reviews on this topic:<br />
As you stated, bandwidth, memory clock and memory size seem to be one of the most important factors so would it even make sense to put some more money in a solidly overclocked custom GPU? So far I&#8217;ll just pick the cheapest solidly cooled one (EVGA ACX 3.0 probably).<br />
Also my initial analysis between 1070GTX vs 1080GTX was heavily in favor for the 1080 GTX based on the benchmarks from <a href="http://www.phoronix.com/scan.php?page=article&#038;item=nvidia-gtx-1070&#038;num=4" rel="nofollow">http://www.phoronix.com/scan.php?page=article&#038;item=nvidia-gtx-1070&#038;num=4</a> . Though the theoretical TFLOPS SP MIXBENCH results were closely in favor for the 1070 (76.6 €/TFLOP 1080GTX vs 73.9 €/TFLOP 1070GTX) the SHOC on CUDA results  in terms of price efficiency were closely in favor for the 1080GTX but more or less the same . However the GDDRX5 on the 1080 GTX seem to seal the deal I guess for deep learning applications? Also I found the 1080 around 6 Watt/TFlops more cost efficient. Am I on the right track here? Maybe the numbers help some others here searching for opinions on that :).<br />
Anyways after reading through your articles and some others I came up with this build:<br />
<a href="http://pcpartpicker.com/list/LxJ6hq" rel="nofollow">http://pcpartpicker.com/list/LxJ6hq</a> . Some comments would be very appreciated 🙂 . I feel like the CPU is a bit overkill but it was the cheapest with DDR4 ram and 40 lanes. Maybe not needed though I&#8217;m a bit unsure of that.<br />
Best regards</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-5842' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-5842", "5842", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Milan Ender'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-6403">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/50bd5ad01d082658574a34f8f480eb52?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/50bd5ad01d082658574a34f8f480eb52?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Simon</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-07-04T15:49:41+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-6403" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-07-04 at 15:49</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi<br />
Asus spec X99-E WS shows that has a PLX chip that provides a additional 48 PCIe lanes. Getting a i7-6850K with a X99-E WS theoretically gives you 88PCIe lanes in total and that is still plenty to run 4 GPUs all at x16.<br />
Is that true for deep learning ?<br />
Thx for reply.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-6403' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-6403", "6403", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Simon'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-6406">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-07-04T19:14:32+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-6406" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-07-04 at 19:14</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>I am not exactly sure how this feature maps to the CPU and to software compatibility. From what I heard so far, you can quite reliably access GPUs from very non-standard hardware setups, but I am not so sure about if the software would support such a feature. If the GPUs are not aware of each other on the CUDA level due to the PLX chip, then this feature will do nothing good for deep learning (it would probably be even slower than a normal board, because probably you would need to go through the CPU to communicate between GPUs).</p>
<p>But the idea of a PLX chip is quite interesting, so if you are able to find out more information about software compatibility, then please leave a comment here — that would not only help you and me, but also all these other people that read this blog post!</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-6406' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-6406", "6406", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Yes that is very true. There is basically no advantage from newer CPUs in terms of performance. The only reason really to buy a newer CPU is to have DDR4 support, which comes in handy <em>sometimes</em> for <em>non-deep learning</em> work.</p>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>A laptop with such a high end graphics card is a huge investment and you will probably use that laptop much longer than people use their desktops (it is much easier to sell your GPU and upgrade for a desktop). I would thus recommend to wait for the 1000M series. It seems it will arrive in some months ahead and the first performance figures show that they are slightly faster than the GTX Titan X — that would be well worth the wait in my opinion!</p>

I recently started shifting my focus from conventional machine learning to Deep Learning.  I work in medical imaging domain and my application has a dataset of 50000 color images (5000 per class, 10 classes, size &#8211; 512&#215;512). I have a system with Quadro k620 gpu.  I want to train state of the art CNN model architectures like Googlenet InceptionV3, VGGnet16, alexnet from scratch.  Do the QuadroK620 will be sufficient for training these models. 	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-6524">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-07-09T17:01:05+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-6524" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-07-09 at 17:01</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>A QuadroK620 will not be sufficient for these tasks. Even with very small batch sizes you will hit the limits pretty quickly. I recommend getting a Titan X on eBay. Medical imaging is a field with high resolution images where any additional amount of memory can make a good difference. Your dataset is fairly small though and probably represents a quite difficult task; it might be good to split up the images to get more samples and thus better results (quarter them for example if the label information is still valid for these images) which then in turn would consume more memory. A GTX Titan X should be best for you.</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="comment-6943">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/2cc8abf9f9ba0a151b01eeef8ec9a560?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/2cc8abf9f9ba0a151b01eeef8ec9a560?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">David Selinger</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-07-24T19:17:05+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-6943" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-07-24 at 19:17</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hey there Tim,</p>
<p>Thanks for all the info!<br />
I was literally pushing send on an email that said &#8220;ORDER IT&#8221; to my local computer build shop when nVidia announced the new Titan X Pascal.<br />
Do you have any initial thoughts on the new architecture? Especially as it pertains to cooling the NVRAM which usually requires some sort of custom hardware (cooling plate? my terminology is likely wrong here) will that add additional delay after purchasing the new hardware?</p>
<p>Thank you sir!</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-6943' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-6943", "6943", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to David Selinger'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-6953">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-07-25T06:02:40+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-6953" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-07-25 at 06:02</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>There should be no problems with cooling for the GDDR5X memory with the normal card layout and fans. I know for HBM2 NVIDIA actually designed the memory to be actively cooled, but HBM2 is stacked while GDDR5X is not. Generally GDDR5X is very similar to GDDR5 memory. It will consume less power but also offer higher density, so that on the bottom line GDDR5X should run on the same temperature level or only slightly hotter than GDDR5 memory — no extra cooling required. Extra cooling makes sense if you want to overclock the memory clockrate, but often you cannot get much more performance out of it for how much you need to invest in cooling solutions.</p>
<p>Overall the architecture of Pascal seems quite solid. However, most features of the series are a bit crippled due to manufacturing bottlenecks (16nm, GDDR5X, HBM2 all these need their own factories). You can expect that the next line of Pascal GPUs will step up the game by quite a bit. The GTX 11 series probably will feature GDDR5X/HBM2 for all cards and allow full half-float precision performance. So Pascal is good, but it will become much better next year.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-6953' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-6953", "6953", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="comment-6965">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/2cc8abf9f9ba0a151b01eeef8ec9a560?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/2cc8abf9f9ba0a151b01eeef8ec9a560?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">David Selinger</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-07-25T22:23:34+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-6965" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-07-25 at 22:23</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Cool thanks. That gave me something to chew on.</p>
<p>Last question (hopefully for at least a week : ) ): Do you think that a standard  hybrid cooling closed-loop kit (like this one from Arctic: <a href="https://www.arctic.ac/us_en/accelero-hybrid-iii-140.html" rel="nofollow">https://www.arctic.ac/us_en/accelero-hybrid-iii-140.html</a>) will be sufficient for deep learning or is a custom loop the only way to go?<br />
&#8211; VRM: heatsink + fan<br />
&#8211; VRAM: Heatsink ONLY<br />
&#8211; GPU: closed-loop water cooled</p>
<p>Obviously will have to confirm the physical fit once those specs become more available, but insofar as the approach, I was a little bit concerned about the VRAM.</p>
<p>The use case is convolutional networks for image and video recognition.</p>
<p>Thanks,<br />
Selly</p>

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-6975">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/c9de886c545dc6c37c6406ae1dbd46e8?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/c9de886c545dc6c37c6406ae1dbd46e8?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">bmahak</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-07-26T01:18:46+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-6975" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-07-26 at 01:18</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>I want to build my own deep learning machine using skylake motherboard and cpu. I am planing not to use more then 2 GPUS (GTX 1080). Starting with one GPU first and upgrading to a second one if needed.<br />
here is my setup in pcpartpiker: <a href="http://pcpartpicker.com/user/bmahak2005/saved/Yn9qqs" rel="nofollow">http://pcpartpicker.com/user/bmahak2005/saved/Yn9qqs</a></p>
<p>Please tell me what you think about it.</p>
<p>Thanks again for a great article .</p>
<p>HB.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-6975' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-6975", "6975", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to bmahak'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-7206">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-08-04T06:30:06+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-7206" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-08-04 at 06:30</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>The motherboard and CPU combo that you chose only supports 8x/8x speed for the PCIe slots. This means you might see some slowdown in parallel performance if you use both of your GPUs at the same time. The decrease might vary between networks with roughly 0-10% performance loss. Otherwise the build seems to be okay. Personally I would go with a bit more watts on the PSU just to have a save buffer of extra watts.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-7206' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-7206", "7206", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

			<p>hi tim,</p>
<p>thanks for some really useful comments.  i have a hardware question.  i&#8217;ve configured a Windows 10 machine for some GPU computing (not DL) at the moment.  I think the hardware issues overlap with your blog, so here goes:<br />
the system  has a GTX 980 Ti card and a K40 card on an ASUS X-99 Deluxe motherboard.  When the system boots up, the 980 (which runs the display as well) is fine, but the K40 gives me &#8220;This device cannot start. (Code 10).  Insufficient system resources exist to complete the API&#8221;.  I have the most up-to-date drivers (354.92 for K40, 368.81 for 980).</p>
<p>Has anyone configured a system like this, and did they have similar problems?  Any ideas will be greatly appreciated.</p>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-7210">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-08-04T06:45:28+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-7210" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-08-04 at 06:45</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>It might well be that your GPU driver is meddling here. There are separate drivers for Tesla and GTX GPUs and you have the GTX variant installed and thus the Tesla card might not work properly. I am not entirely sure to go around this problem. You might want to configure the system as a headless (no monitor) server with Tesla drivers and connect to it using a laptop (you can use remote desktop using Windows, but I would recommend installing ubuntu).</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-7210' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-7210", "7210", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>How do the new NVIDIA 10xx compare? I followed through with this guide and ended up getting a GTX Titan. The bandwidth looks slightly higher for the Titan series. Does the architecture affect learning speeds?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-7193' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-7193", "7193", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Michael Lanier'>Reply</a></div>
