	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-7214">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-08-04T06:51:37+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-7214" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-08-04 at 06:51</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>The bandwidth is high for all Titans, but their performance is different from architecture to architecture, for example Kepler (GTX Titan) is much slower than Maxwell (GTX Titan X) even though the have comparable bandwidth. So yes the architecture does affect learning speed — quite significantly so!</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-7214' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-7214", "7214", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-7269">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-08-06T18:09:22+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-7269" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-08-06 at 18:09</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>There are several reasons:<br />
&#8211; I led a team of 250 in an online community and people often asked me for help and guidance. At first I sometimes lend support and sometimes I did not. However, over time I realized that not helping out can produce problems: Demotivate people from something which they really want to do but do not know how to do, produce defects in the social environment (when I do not help out, others would take example from my actions and do the same) among others. Once I start lending a hand always, I found that I do not lose as much time as I thought I would lose. Due to my vast background knowledge in this online community, it often was faster to help than thinking about if some question or request was worth of my help. I now always help without a second thought or at least start helping until my patience grows tired<br />
&#8211; Helping people makes me feel good<br />
&#8211; I was born with genes which make me smart and which make me understand some things easier than others. I feel that I have a duty to give back to those which were less fortunate in the birth lottery<br />
&#8211; I believe everybody deserves respect. Answering questions which are easy for me to answer is a form of respect</p>
<p>I hope that answers your question 🙂</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-7269' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-7269", "7269", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Thanks for the great guide.<br />
I had a question. What is the minimum build that you recommend for hosting a Titan X pascal?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-7290' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-7290", "7290", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Arman'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-7295">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-08-08T06:48:41+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-7295" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-08-08 at 06:48</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>For a single Titan X Pascal and if you do not want to add another card later almost any build will do. The CPU does not matter; you can buy the cheapest RAM and should have at least 16 GB of it (24 GB will be more than enough). For the PSU 600 watts will do; 500 watts might be sufficient. I would buy a SSD if you want to train on large data sets or raw images that are read from disk.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-7295' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-7295", "7295", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->

	<li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="comment-7361">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/539117b2ae32e747160df42872711e4e?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/539117b2ae32e747160df42872711e4e?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Wajahat</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-08-11T15:27:36+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-7361" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-08-11 at 15:27</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim</p>
<p>Thanks a lot for your useful blog.</p>
<p>I am training CNN on CPU and GPU as well.<br />
Although the weights are randomly initialized , but I am setting the random seed to zero in the beginning of the training. Still, I am getting different weights learnt  for CPU than GPU. The difference is not huge (e.g. -0.0009 and -0.0059, or 0.0016 and 0.0017), but there is a difference that I can notice. Do y ou have any idea how this could be happening?  I know it is a very broad question, but what I want to ask is, is this expected or not?</p>
<p>I am using MatlabR2016a with MatConvNet 1.0 beta20  (Nvidia Quadro 410 GPU in Win7 and GTX1080 in Ubuntu 16.04), Corei7 4770  and Corei7 4790.<br />
Exactly same data with same network architecture used.</p>
<p>Best Regards<br />
Wajahat</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-7361' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-7361", "7361", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Wajahat'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-7404">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-08-13T21:45:03+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-7404" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-08-13 at 21:45</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>This can well be true and normal. The seed itself can produce different random numbers on CPU and GPU if different algorithms are used. Convolution on GPUs mal also include some non-deterministic operations (cuDNN 4). When using unit tests to compare CPU and GPU computation, I also often have some difference in output given the same input, thus I assume that there are also small differences in floating point computation (although very small). All this might add up to your result.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-7404' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-7404", "7404", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-7365">

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>The K40C should be compatible with any standard motherboard just fine. The compatibility that hardware vendors stress if often assumed for datasets where the cards run hot and need to do so permanently for many months or years. The K40 has a standard PCIe connector and that is all that you need for your server motherboard.</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-7519">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-08-18T03:37:42+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-7519" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-08-18 at 03:37</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>The servers have a slow interconnect, that is the servers only have a gigabit Ethernet which is a bit too slow for parallelism. So you can focus on setting up each server separately. It depends on your dataset size, but you might want to have the SSD drive dedicated for your datasets, that is, install the OS on the hard drive. If your datasets are < 200GB, you could also install the OS on the SSD to have a smoother user experience.

The frameworks all have their pros and cons. In general I would recommend TensorFlow, since it has the fastest growing community.
</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-7519' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-7519", "7519", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment even depth-2" id="comment-8075">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/0e5cb4073c72e1c0822acf1aa7bc151b?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/0e5cb4073c72e1c0822acf1aa7bc151b?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Juan</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-09-05T00:24:33+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-8075" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-09-05 at 00:24</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi, </p>
<p>I am not Tim (obviously), but as far as I understood from his other post on GPU (<a href="http://timdettmers.com/2014/08/14/which-gpu-for-deep-learning/" rel="nofollow">http://timdettmers.com/2014/08/14/which-gpu-for-deep-learning/</a>) he states that for research level of work it actually is a difference, maxime when you are are using videosets. But for example &#8230; &#8220;While 12GB of memory are essential for state-of-the-art results on ImageNet on a similar dataset with 112x112x3 dimensions we might get state-of-the-art results with just 4-6GB of memory.&#8221;</p>
<p>Hope this can help you.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-8075' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-8075", "8075", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Juan'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="comment-8228">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4045a5c4ca3e6a8284003ba56ae44b25?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4045a5c4ca3e6a8284003ba56ae44b25?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">DarkIdeals</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-09-10T05:55:25+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-8228" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-09-10 at 05:55</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>If you can afford it the TITAN X is DEFINITELY worth it over the 1080 in most cases. Not only does it have that 12GB of VRAM to work with but it also has features like INT8 (the way i understand it, is that you can store floats as 8 bit integers which helps efficiency etc.. Potentially quite useful) and has 44 TOP units (kinda like ROPs but not for graphic rendering, they are beneficial to Deep Learning though)</p>
<p>Basically the TITAN X is literally identical to the $7000 Tesla P100 just without the Double Precision FP64 capability and without HBM2 memory (The TITAN X uses GDDR5X instead, however it&#8217;s not much of a difference as the P100&#8217;s memory bandwidth even with the HBM is only 540 GB/second whereas the TITAN X is very close at 480 GB/second and hits 530 GB/second when you overclock the memory from 10,000mhz to 11,000mhz so it&#8217;s literally no difference really)  Other than those things and the certified Tesla Drivers there&#8217;s literally no real difference between the P100 and the TITAN X Pascal; which is very important as the Tesla P100 is literally THE most powerful graphic card on the planet right now!</p>
<p>The important thing to mention is that Double Precision isn&#8217;t really important for Neural nets etc.. that you deal with in Deep Learning; so for $1,200 you are getting the power of the $7,000 monster supercomputer chip of the Tesla P100 just without all the unnecessary server features that Deep Learning doesn&#8217;t use. </p>
<p>Also, in comparison to the GTX 1080, the TITAN X has a significant advantage in both memory capacity (12GB vs 8GB on 1080), memory bandwidth (530 GB/s when overclocked on the TITAN X, vs 350 GB/s on the 1080 when overclocked&#8230;that&#8217;s a FIFTY PERCENT increase in memory bandwidth!), and has a massive increase in CUDA cores which is very beneficial (40% more, which when combined with the double memory capacity and 50% higher bandwidth easily nets you ~60% more performance in some scenarios over the 1080)</p>
<p>Hope this helps, the TITAN X is a GREAT chip for Deep Learning, the best in the world currently available in my opinion. Which is why i bought two of them.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-8228' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-8228", "8228", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to DarkIdeals'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment even depth-2" id="comment-9546">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4045a5c4ca3e6a8284003ba56ae44b25?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4045a5c4ca3e6a8284003ba56ae44b25?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">DarkIdeals</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-11-09T01:32:16+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-9546" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-11-09 at 01:32</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>(sorry for the long post but it is important to your decision so try to read it all if you have time) </p>
<p>Hey, correcting an error in my earlier post.  LIke i said i wasn&#8217;t quite sure if i understood the INT8 functionality properly. and i was wrong about it.  Apparently there was a typo in the spec pages of the Pascal TITAN X, it said &#8220;44 TOPs&#8221; and made me think it was an operation pipeline of sorts similar to a &#8220;ROP&#8221; which is responsible for displaying graphical images etc..  </p>
<p>It actually was referring the the INT8, which is basically just 8 bit integer support.  The average GPU runs with 32 bit &#8220;full precision&#8221; accuracy, which is a measurement of how much time and effort is put into each &#8220;calculation&#8221; made by the GPU. For example, with 32 bit it may only go out to 4 decimal points when calculating for the physics of water in a 3d render etc..  which is plenty good for things like Video Games and your average video editing and rendering project; but for things like advanced physics calculations by big universities that are trying to determine the 100% accurate behavior of each individual molecule of H2O within the body of water to see EXACTLY how it moves when wind blows etc..  you would need &#8220;double precision&#8221; which is a 64 bit calculation that would have much more accuracy, going to more decimal points before deciding that the calculation is &#8220;close enough&#8221; compared to what 32 bit would. </p>
<p>Only special cards like Quadro&#8217;s and Tesla&#8217;s have high 64 performance, they usually have half the Teraflops of performance at 64 bit mode compared to 32 bit, so a Quadro P6000 (same GPU as the TITAN XP but with full 64 bit support) it has 12 Teraflops of power at 32 bit mode and ~6 Teraflops of power in 64 bit mode.  But there is also 16 bit mode, &#8220;half precision&#8221; for things requiring even less accuracy,  INT8 to my understanding is basically &#8220;8 bit quarter precision&#8221; mode, with even less focus on total mathematical accuracy; and this  is useful for Deep Learning as some of the work done doesn&#8217;t require that much accuracy,.</p>
<p>So, in other words, in 8 bit mode, the TITAN X has &#8220;44 Teraflops&#8221; of performance.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-9546' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-9546", "9546", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to DarkIdeals'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-3" id="comment-9585">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-11-10T23:09:40+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-9585" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-11-10 at 23:09</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Your analysis is very much correct. However, for some games there are already some elements which make heavy use of 8-bit Integers. However, before it was not possible to do 8-bit Integer computation, but you had to first convert both numbers to 32-bit, then do the computation, and then convert it back. This would be done implicitly by the GPU so that no programming was necessary. Now the GPU is able to do it on its own. However, the support is still quite limited so you will not the 8-bit deep learning just yet. Probably in a year earliest would be my guess, but I am sure it will arrive at some point.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-9585' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-9585", "9585", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Basically it is two regular deep learning systems together with infiniband cards. You can get infiniband card and a cable quite cheap on eBay and the total cost for a 6 GPU, 2 node system would be about 3k for the system and infiniband cards, and an additional 6k for the GPUs (if you use Pascal GTX Titan X) for a total of $9k.</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-8774">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2728f91bcbe3460f0e15fe4ef263dfe?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2728f91bcbe3460f0e15fe4ef263dfe?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">anon</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim,</p>
<p>I just got 5 dell precision t7500 in an auction.<br />
haven&#8217;t received them yet, but the description mentions Nvidia Quadro 5000  installed.<br />

	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-8815">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-10-03T15:04:11+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-8815" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-10-03 at 15:04</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>The Quadro 5000 has only a compute capability of 2.0 and thus will not work with most deep learning libraries that use cuDNN. Thus it might be better to upgrade.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-8815' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-8815", "8815", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/97dc6eac13c818f9932096a6079b9af7?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/97dc6eac13c818f9932096a6079b9af7?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Ashiq</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-10-19T19:06:32+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-9109" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-10-19 at 19:06</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim</p>
<p>Thanks for the great article and your patience to answer all the questions. I just built a dev box with 4 Titan X Pascal and need some advice on air flow. For reference, here is the  Part list: <a href="https://pcpartpicker.com/list/W2PzvV" rel="nofollow">https://pcpartpicker.com/list/W2PzvV</a> and the Picture: <a href="http://imgur.com/bGoGVXu" rel="nofollow">http://imgur.com/bGoGVXu</a></p>
<p>Loaded Windows first for stress testing the components and noticed the GPUs temps reached 84C while the fans are still at 50%. Then the GPUs started slowing down to lower/maintain the temp.  Then with  MSI Afterburner, I could specify a custom temp-vs-fanspeed profile and  keep the GPU temps at 77C or below &#8211; pretty much what you wrote in the cooling section above.</p>
<p>There is no &#8220;Afterburner&#8221; for Linux, and apparently the BIOS of the Titan X Pascal is locked so we can&#8217;t flash them with custom temp setting. The only option left for me is to play with the coolbits and I prefer not to attach 4 monitors to it (I already have two 30inch monitors that are attached to a windows computer that I use for everything. 6 monitors on the table will be too much).</p>
<p> I wonder if you found any new way of emulating monitors for Xorg as my preferred option would be keep 3 of the GPUs headless ?</p>
<p>Cheers<br />
Ashiq</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-9109' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-9109", "9109", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Ashiq'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

			<p>I did not succeed in emulating monitors so myself. Some other claim that they got it working. I think the easiest way to increase the fan speed would be to flash the GPU with a custom BIOs. That way it will work in both Windows and Linux.</p>

	<li class="comment even depth-3" id="comment-9237">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-9507">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-11-07T11:21:10+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-9507" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-11-07 at 11:21</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>I think that non-consumer hardware is not so economically efficient for setting up a ML/DL lab. However, beyond a certain threshold of GPUs the traditional consumer hardware no longer is an option (NVIDIA will not sell you consumer-grade GPUs on bulk and there might also be problems with reliability). I would recommend to get as much traditional, cheap, consumer hardware as possible and mix it with some HPC components like cheap Mellanox Infiniband cards and switches from eBay.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-9507' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-9507", "9507", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->

                   Thank you for sharing your knowledge  it was very much beneficial to understand the concepts in DL.<br />

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-9509">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-11-07T11:25:52+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-9509" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-11-07 at 11:25</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>You will need to rescale custom images to a specific size so that you can feed your data into a CNN. I recommend looking at ImageNet examples of common libraries (Torch7, Tensorflow) to understand the data loading process. You will then need to write an extension which resizes your images to the proper dimension, for example 1080&#215;1920 -> 224&#215;224.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-9509' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-9509", "9509", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment even depth-3" id="comment-9530">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/e98290addbf25e948e02495379fa7bb9?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/e98290addbf25e948e02495379fa7bb9?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Alisher</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Firstly, I am very thankful for your post. It is very nice and very helpful.</p>
<p>One thing I wanted to point is; you can feed the images into network (in caffe) as they are. I mean if you have 1080&#215;1920 image, there is no need to reshape it to 224&#215;224. But, this does not mean that feeding the image as is perform better, I think this can be standalone research topic 🙂</p>
<p>Secondly, I am planning to buy a desktop PC; and since I am a Deep Learner Researcher (beginner) I am going to do a lot experiments on ImageNet, etc large scale datasets. Do you suggest to buy the gaming PCs directly, or would it be wise choice to build my own PC?<br />
I was considering to buy Asus ROG G20CB P1070.</p>
<p>Thank you very much in advance!</p>
<p>Regards,</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-4" id="comment-9582">

			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-11-10T23:03:53+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-9582" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-11-10 at 23:03</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Building your own PC would be a better choice in the long-term. It can be daunting at first, but it is often easier than assembling IKEA furniture and unlike IKEA furniture there are multitude of resources on how to do it step-by-step. After you have build your first desktops, building the next desktops will be easy and rewarding and you will save a lot of money to boot!</p>
		</div>

			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-11-07T11:27:17+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-9510" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-11-07 at 11:27</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>No extra configuration is required other than the normal monitor configuration for your operating system. Your GPU needs to have enough connectors and support 3 monitors (most modern GPUs do).</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-9510' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-9510", "9510", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-9512">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-11-07T11:33:09+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-9512" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-11-07 at 11:33</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Definitely go for the GTX 10 series GPUs for your laptop since these are very similar to full desktop GPUs. They are probably more expensive though. Another option would be to buy a cheap, light laptop with long-battery duration and a separate desktop to which your connect remotely to run your deep learning work. The last option is what I use and I am quite fond of it.</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-4" id="comment-9583">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-9579">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/cfb1ba6a6511dafc9a3c494487aae399?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/cfb1ba6a6511dafc9a3c494487aae399?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Shahid</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-11-10T10:51:45+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-9579" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-11-10 at 10:51</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>I am confused between two options:<br />
1) A 2nd Generation core i5, 8GB DDR3 RAM and a GTX 960 for $350.<br />
2) A 6th Generation core i3, 16GB DDR3 RAM and a GTX 750Ti for $480.</p>
<p>Can you please comment? I expect to upgrade my GPU after a few months.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-9579' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-9579", "9579", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Shahid'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-9590">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-11-10T23:28:04+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-9590" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-11-10 at 23:28</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>A difficult choice. If your upgrade your GPU in a few months then it depends if you use your desktop only for deep learning or also for other tasks. If you use your machine regularly, I would spend the extra money and go for option (2). If you want to almost exclusively deep learning with the machine (1) is a good, cheap choice. Here the choice also depends if you buy the 2GB or 4GB variant of each GPU. In terms of speed (1) will be about 33-50% faster, but the speed would not be too important when you start out with deep learning, specially if you upgrade the GPU eventually.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-9590' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-9590", "9590", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-4" id="comment-10450">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-12-13T12:18:23+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-10450" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-12-13 at 12:18</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Indeed, the Supermicro motherboard will not be able to hold a 4th GPU. I also have a Gigabyte motherboard (although a different one) and it worked well with 4 GPUs (while I had problems with an ASUS one), but I think in general most motherboards will work just fine. So seems like a good choice.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-10450' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-10450", "10450", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>If I were you I would put together a PC on pcpartpicker.com with 4 GPUs and then build it together by myself. This is the cheapest option. If that is too difficult, then I would look for companies that sell deep learning desktops. They basically sell the same hardware, but at a higher price.</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="comment-10130">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/7b8064d08c8497039ba0dab48e5d6477?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/7b8064d08c8497039ba0dab48e5d6477?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Gordon</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-12-01T13:21:43+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-10130" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-12-01 at 13:21</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Thank you very much for writing this! &#8211; knowing something about how to evaluate the hardware is something I have been struggling to get my head around.</p>
<p>I have been playing with TensorFlow on the CPU on a pretty nice laptop (fast i7 with lots of RAM and an SSD  but ultimately dual core so slow as hell).</p>
<p>I want try something on the GPU to see if it is really just 100&#8217;s of times faster, but I am worried about investing too much too soon as I have not had a desktop in ages.. having read this post and the comments I have the following plan:</p>
<p>Use an existing freenas server I have as a test bed and buy a relatively low end GPU &#8211; GTX 960 4096MB:</p>
<p><a href="https://www.overclockers.co.uk/msi-geforce-gtx-960-4096mb-gddr5-pci-express-graphics-card-gtx-960-4gd5t-oc-gx-319-ms.html" rel="nofollow">https://www.overclockers.co.uk/msi-geforce-gtx-960-4096mb-gddr5-pci-express-graphics-card-gtx-960-4gd5t-oc-gx-319-ms.html</a></p>
<p>The freenas box has a crappy celeron core 2 3.2 dual core and only 8GB of Ram.:</p>
<p><a href="http://ark.intel.com/products/53418/Intel-Celeron-Processor-G550-2M-Cache-2_60-GHz" rel="nofollow">http://ark.intel.com/products/53418/Intel-Celeron-Processor-G550-2M-Cache-2_60-GHz</a></p>
<p>I will buy the graphics card and an SSD to install an alternative OS on, I *may* upgrade the ram and processor too as all of these items will all benefit the freenas box anyway (i also run plex on it).</p>
<p>If this goes well and I develop further I will look at a whole new setup later with appropriate motherboard, cpu, etc. but in the mean time i can learn how to to identify where my specific bottle necks are likely to be etc.</p>
<p>From what you have said here i think there will be several slow parts to my system but I am probably going to get 80-90% of the speed of the graphics, the main restriction being that the cpu only supports PCIe 2.0 &#8211; as everything else while not ideal and scale-able for that GPU can probably feed it fast enough.</p>
<p>I have 2 questions (if you have time &#8211; sorry for long comment but i wanted to make my situation clear):</p>
<p>1. Do you see anything drastically wrong with this approach? &#8211; no guarantees obviously, I could spend more money now if i am just shooting myself in the foot but i would rather save it for the next system once i am fully committed and have more experience.</p>
<p>2. I chose the GPU based on RAM, number of CUDA cores and Nvidia compute capability rating (which reminds me of windows performance rating 😀 &#8211; a bit vague but better than nothing).. the other one i was considering was this £13 more so also a fine price imho:</p>
<p><a href="https://www.overclockers.co.uk/palit-geforce-gtx-1050ti-stormx-4096mb-pci-express-gddr5-graphics-card-gx-03t-pl.html" rel="nofollow">https://www.overclockers.co.uk/palit-geforce-gtx-1050ti-stormx-4096mb-pci-express-gddr5-graphics-card-gx-03t-pl.html</a></p>
<p>Which has less cores 768 vs 1024 but a shorter process length, higher speed 1290MHz vs 1178MHz, and i *think* i higher rating assuming that the Ti is just better (seems to mean unlocked) 6.1 vs 5.2:</p>
<p><a href="https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-gpus#collapse4" rel="nofollow">https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-gpus#collapse4</a></p>
<p>Basically is the drop in cores really made up for to such a drastic extent that this significantly higher rating from nvidia is accurate..  noting that i am probably going to be happy enough either way &#8211; feel free to just say &#8220;either is probably fine&#8221; 😀</p>
<p>Alternatively if there is something else in the sub £150 ish range that you would suggest given that the whole thing may be replaced by a titan x or similar (hopefully cheaper after Christmas 😉 ) if this goes well. I did consider just getting something like this: much less ram but still was more cores than 2 and allows me to figure out how to get code running on the GPU:</p>
<p><a href="https://www.overclockers.co.uk/asus-geforce-gt-710-silent-1024mb-gddr3-pci-express-graphics-card-gx-396-as.html" rel="nofollow">https://www.overclockers.co.uk/asus-geforce-gt-710-silent-1024mb-gddr3-pci-express-graphics-card-gx-396-as.html</a></p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-10157">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-12-02T20:16:39+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-10157" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-12-02 at 20:16</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Upgrading the system bit by bit may make sense. Note that CPU and RAM will make no difference to deep learning performance, but might be interesting for other applications. If you only use one GPU a PCIe 2.0 will be fine and will not hurt performance. The GTX 960 and GTX 1050Ti are on a par in terms of performance. So pick what is most convenient / cheaper for you.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-10157' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-10157", "10157", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-10449">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-12-13T12:14:58+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-10449" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-12-13 at 12:14</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Om,</p>
<p>I am really glad that you found the resources of my website useful — thank you for your kind words!</p>
<p>The thing with the NVIDIA Titan X (Pascal) and the GTX 1080 is that they use different chips which cannot communicate in parallel. So you would be unable to parallelize a model on these two GPUs. However, you would be able to run different models on each GPU, or you could get another GTX 1080 and parallelize on those GPUs.</p>
<p>Note that using a Ubuntu VM can cause some problems with GPU support. The last time I checked it was hardly possible to get GPU acceleration running through a VM, but things might have changed since then. So I urge you to check if this is possible first before you go along this route.</p>
<p>Best,<br />
Tim</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-10449' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-10449", "10449", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->

I am just beginning to experiment with deep learning and I&#8217;m interested in generative models like RNNs (probably models like LSTMs, I think). I can&#8217;t spend more than $2k (maybe up to $2.3k), so I think I will have to go with a 16-lane CPU. Then I have a choice of either a single Titan X Pascal or two 1080s. (Alternatively, I could buy a 40-lane CPU, preserving upgradability, but then I could only buy a single 1080). Do you have any advice specific to RNNs in this situation? Is model parallelism a viable option for RNNs in general and LSTMs in particular?</p>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-10452">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-12-13T12:24:54+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-10452" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-12-13 at 12:24</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>I think you can apply 75% of state-of-the-art LSTM models on different tasks with a GTX 1080; for the other 25% you can often create a &#8220;smarter&#8221; architecture which uses less memory and achieves comparable results. So I think you should go for 16 lanes and two GTX 1080. Make sure your CPU support two GPUs in a 8x/8x setting.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-10452' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-10452", "10452", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

Another strategy might be to wait a bit longer for the GTX 1080 Ti to arrive and then buy a cheap GTX 1080 from eBay. I think these two choices make sense if you can wait for a month or two.</p>

	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment even depth-4" id="comment-11048">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/d902111389ae6ed31320da7a481d2835?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/d902111389ae6ed31320da7a481d2835?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Nader</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2016-12-30T05:16:43+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-11048" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2016-12-30 at 05:16</a></time></p>		</header>

I appreciate it.</p>

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="comment-12201">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4045a5c4ca3e6a8284003ba56ae44b25?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4045a5c4ca3e6a8284003ba56ae44b25?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Andrew</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-02-10T08:44:00+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-12201" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-02-10 at 08:44</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>I would personally recommend a couple small changes. Here&#8217;s what i would go with: <a href="https://pcpartpicker.com/list/bx2ssJ" rel="nofollow">https://pcpartpicker.com/list/bx2ssJ</a></p>
<p>First off, if you are going to spend $85 on a 256GB regular SATA based SSD for storage then you might as well get the top of the line M.2 960 Evo for $120. It&#8217;s over 3 times faster than the one you picked in transfer speeds, and is overall much better. (alternatively if you don&#8217;t care about the extra speed you can get a 500GB SATA drive for about that same price, getting double the storage) </p>
<p>The second thing i would change is to get a Z270 motherboard rather than a Z170.  It&#8217;s been a month or so since you commented so not sure if you bought yours yet, but the new Z270 motherboards support more PCI lanes, support 4K encoding on 7000 series CPUs etc.. so they&#8217;re worth looking at, especially since they&#8217;re basically the same price.  My link swapped in a Gigabyte Z270 Gaming K3 for your Gigabyte Z170 Gaming M3. Very Similar boards.</p>
<p>Lastly, you should also get the i5 7600K instead of the i5 6600K since Kaby Lake 7000 processors are about 5-10% faster than Skylake 6000 processors, and the 7600K can be overclocked to over 5ghz no problem compared to the 6600K that has trouble getting over ~4.7ghz on air cooling in some cases. And since the 7600K is also about the same price you might as well get it.  Personally though i would still recommend an i7 over an i5 in this situation simply because simultaneous multi-threading is becoming fairly more important as of late, and the extra 2MB of L3 cache is also nice to have.  I figure if you are spending $1200 on a TITAN X Pascal you should be able to fit in $100 more for an i7 7700K that can also be overclocked to 5ghz pretty easily in most cases (even on air!)</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-12201' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-12201", "12201", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Andrew'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim,</p>
<p>I&#8217;ve just upgraded from GTX 960 to GTX 1070.<br />
I used to run the tensorflow cifar10_multi_gpu_train.py file to check the speed from one release to another. With the last tensorflow release it peak at about 1500 images / sec with GTX 960 (which is an impressive progress btw, with the initial releases it was more like 750 images / sec). </p>
<p>I was suprised to see that my GTX 1070 peaks at ~1700 images / sec, a very small improvement. It looks like the CPU is now the bottleneck (I see it constantly at 300% usage &#8211; 3 full cores). I have a i5-3570k which should be decent. </p>
<p>I didn&#8217;t analysed it further (yet) but could samebody share an experience on that ? I wasn&#8217;t expecting the CPU to be the bottleneck here.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Are you training on multiple GPUs (cifar10_multi_gpu_train.py)? If so, then this is your answer. TensorFlow has terrible performance for multiple GPUs and upgrading multiple GPUs will not yield much better performance for TensorFlow.</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment even depth-2" id="comment-23668">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-11-07T22:36:01+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-23668" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-11-07 at 22:36</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Paweł,<br />
Tensorflow do not use GPU to GPU transfer when updating weights.  It download the whole model to RAM and make updates on CPU. At least this is the understanding i&#8217;ve got from reading: <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1608.07249" rel="nofollow">https://arxiv.org/abs/1608.07249</a></p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="comment-11283">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/ad8bbf0e30f89bf79f0362afa8c0f04a?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/ad8bbf0e30f89bf79f0362afa8c0f04a?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Michael</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-01-05T22:56:54+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-11283" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-01-05 at 22:56</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Tim, thanks for the great article! I have a couple of questions: </p>
<p>1. What is &#8220;4&#8221; in your mini-batch size calculation (4x128x244x244x3)? </p>
<p>2.  I&#8217;m deciding on which SSD to buy for my machine with four Pascal Titan X cards, mostly to do training on Imagenet. Assuming your bandwidth estimate of 290MBps is for a single card,  should I multiply it by four when running a model on all four cards? Do you know how fast Pascal Titan X processes a single 128 mini-batch? Also, if I use mini-batch of 256 , I would need double the bandwidth, right?<br />
Given the above considerations, would you recommend going with a PCIe based SSD, such as Samsung 960 Pro, rather than SATA based one, such as Samsung 850 Evo?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-11283' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-11283", "11283", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Michael'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-11296">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-01-06T12:48:29+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-11296" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-01-06 at 12:48</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>1. The data used in deep learning is usually 32-bit or 4 bytes; this is the 4 in the calculation above (conversion into bytes).<br />
2. This is a bit complicated. Parallelism does not scale linearly, so that you should multiply the estimate by 3.5 or so (for TensorFlow this will be closer to 2.5-3). One thing to keep in mind is that in practice small data transfers are often slower (the overhead is large when the data size is small) and that GPUs operate more efficient on larger batch sizes. </p>
<p>I am unfamiliar with the exact internals of the TensorFlow batching procedure. If they do it right for both data loading and data transfer a PCIe SSD would lend a bit improved performance. However, from some benchmarks it seems that some parts (GPU transfers I think) TensorFlow is sub-optimal. If this is really so for GPU transfers then a PCIe SSD and a normal SSD would lend the same performance. I personally would just go for a cheap normal SSD.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-11296' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-11296", "11296", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment even depth-3" id="comment-13639">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/ad8bbf0e30f89bf79f0362afa8c0f04a?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/ad8bbf0e30f89bf79f0362afa8c0f04a?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Michael</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-03-25T03:22:07+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-13639" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-03-25 at 03:22</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Thanks Tim. A different question: which software framework would you use for experimenting with Imagenet?<br />
So far I&#8217;ve been using Theano, but only on small datasets (MNIST and CIFAR). My main interest is to test different quantization methods for weights and activations, and see how it works for different network architectures. I&#8217;ve read your paper, by the way, very interesting, but I prefer not to code everything from scratch in C/CUDA if possible. Right now I&#8217;m looking into implementation of the asynchronous batch allocation, like you suggested, in Theano, and it&#8217;s not very straightforward.<br />
Would you recommend switching to TensorFlow, or sticking with Theano? I&#8217;m less concerned with the ability to parallelize code across multiple GPU, because I can just run different experiments in parallel.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-13639' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-13639", "13639", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Michael'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-4" id="comment-13680">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-03-26T13:54:37+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-13680" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-03-26 at 13:54</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>TensorFlow is a good call. If you want to work on vision only Caffe is also an excellent option. However, overall PyTorch or Torch might be more suitable to you. PyTorch already implements asynchronous batching by default and Torch already has the 1-but quantization method. I am currently not sure how that is integrated into PyTorch, but since both Torch and PyTorch are only wrappers for lua and python, respectively, interfacing with 1-bit quantization should be relatively straighforward. If you want to implement other methods of quantization, then Torch and to some degree PyTorch some good interfacing and easy extension. However, the algorithms would need to be written in C/CUDA. Extending TensorFlow in this way might not be as straightforward, so you might run into difficulties either way. TensorFlow is of course still more popular and thus if you extend it, it will have more value for other people. So not an easy decision, but maybe I could give you some points which makes a decision easier.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-13680' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-13680", "13680", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-11599">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/68b0f4cb2eee7b067e1e67a48dabd0ad?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/68b0f4cb2eee7b067e1e67a48dabd0ad?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Usher</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

<p>Hello trulia.</p>
<p>You have a new message from .<br />
Re: tensorflow<br />
Message: Hi Trulia, We currently do not have an eGPU solution for the Mac and the only eGPU solution we have is for select Thunderbolt 3 PCs, so the answer to your question is No. Having said that, it might be possible that you could make it work but this would be more of a DIY project that requires hardware and software modification. Also, it would void the warranty, so this is not something that I can recommend. Regards, Stefan</p>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>It is an old CPU, but you should be relatively fine. You can expect to run about 10-20% slower than with a high end CPU. Probably processing some non-deep learning code, that is preprocessing data will take quite a bit more, but running the deep learning model should be not much slower.</p>
