	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-12907">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-03-06T10:52:45+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-12907" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-03-06 at 10:52</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>If you are interested in parallelism I recommend looking into Microsoft&#8217;s CNTK library. Their parallelisation algorithms, especially 1-bit quantization and block momentum, are so good that you get linear speedups without having NVLink. Granted, the software is a bit difficult to use but is maturing quickly and you could save a lot of money by going without NVLink. I am currently not aware of any affordable NVLink hardware which is used outside of supercomputing. You might get your hands on one of those machines, but it will be expensive. So in the end CNTK might be the only way to go which is practical. This may be disappointing, but I hope it helps!</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-12907' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-12907", "12907", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="comment-12786">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/d902111389ae6ed31320da7a481d2835?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/d902111389ae6ed31320da7a481d2835?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Nader</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-03-03T18:46:37+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-12786" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-03-03 at 18:46</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Is the NEW Ryzen 1800X compatible with the GTX 1080ti ?<br />
Will using theano as the backend work ?<br />
Thank you</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-12786' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-12786", "12786", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Nader'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment even depth-2" id="comment-12861">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4045a5c4ca3e6a8284003ba56ae44b25?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4045a5c4ca3e6a8284003ba56ae44b25?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Andrew</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-03-05T09:04:50+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-12861" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-03-05 at 09:04</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Ryzen will work perfectly fine with a 1080 TI.  However depending on your work load Ryzen may not be the best option.  </p>
<p>The Pro&#8217;s and Con&#8217;s of Ryzen 1800X is: </p>
<p>Pro: Ryzen has ECC RAM support which is great for mission critical situations where data CAN NOT risk being corrupted at any cost. However if you are mainly doing Deep Learning then ECC RAM is not really necessary at all as most Deep Learning algorithm&#8217;s and AI training etc.. can be done on 16 bit or even 8 bit precision (which is something that the TITAN X pascal excels at actually, thus why something like a Quadro or Tesla isn&#8217;t necessary either in most cases)</p>
<p>Pro: Ryzen has 8 cores, which are beneficial if you plan to do work with highly multi-threaded programs for video editing, 3d rendering etc.. although in many of these cases you are better off using GPU acceleration instead of relying on a CPU since CUDA acceleration on an Nvidia GPU (especially a TITAN X) will be FAR faster than ANY CPU.  And again, if you are just doing Deep Learning mostly, or maybe some PC Gaming on the side etc.. and aren&#8217;t doing programs that need all those extra cores (Deep Learning only needs 4 cores even for four way SLI in most cases as shown in this article) then the extra cores of Ryzen are redundant frankly.</p>
<p>Con:  Ryzen is limited to dual channel RAM. This cuts your memory bandwidth in half pretty much which CAN effect intensive Deep Learning work somewhat. It also only supports up to 2666-2900mhz RAM speeds in many cases which isn&#8217;t really a big deal for Deep Learning but will effect any memory intensive workstation/proffesional tasks. It also has a RAM capacity limit of 64GB compared to Intel X99 chipset used with CPUs like the i7 6800K etc.. that allows for 128GB of QUAD channel RAM clocked at up to 3600mhz. It&#8217;s up to your situation whether you consider that a problem or not.</p>
<p>Con: Ryzen has no overclocking capability to speak of. Nobody has really been able to get ANY Ryzen chip to get over 4.1ghz; with many even being stuck at 3.9gh zor 4.0ghz (which in the case of the 1800X is literally NO overclock at all since the 1800X runs at 4ghz out of the box).  So if you are using programs that need clock speed then a faster chip would be beneficial.</p>
<p>So overall unless you really have specific need of an 8 core chip, i would say for a Deep Learning PC, even if you do things like normal web browsing, heavy PC gaming, video streaming/encoding etc.. you might be better off getting something like an i7 6800K (which has 6 cores 12 threads but can hit 4.4ghz in some cases so overall is a bit better) which is $100 cheaper than the R7 1800X; or perhaps the i7 7700K which is only $329 ($170 cheaper than R7 1800X) and can easily overclock to 5ghz with proper cooling (many people have hit 5.2ghz even with just the high quality noctua air coolers or AIO water coolers etc..)   Only reason i would specifically get Ryzen is if you are really needing an 8 core chip for specific programs, as Deep Learning and most general use doesn&#8217;t require any more than 4 cores.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-12861' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-12861", "12861", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Andrew'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="comment-12881">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/ad8bbf0e30f89bf79f0362afa8c0f04a?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/ad8bbf0e30f89bf79f0362afa8c0f04a?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Michael</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-03-05T20:10:28+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-12881" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-03-05 at 20:10</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Keep in mind that 6800K has only 28 PCIe lanes (Ryzen and 7700k are even worse), so if you&#8217;re planning to use multiple GPUs (now or in the future), go with  E5-1650 v4 (or E5-1620 v4 if you&#8217;re on a budget).  Also, Skylake Xeons are about to be released (this month), so if you can, wait for them (mainly for AVX512 support).</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-12881' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-12881", "12881", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Michael'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Ah yes. Good catch.  </p>
<p>Have you really noticed a difference between running a GPU with PCI-e 3.0 x8 and x16 for Deep Learning though? In most other situations i&#8217;ve seen having x8 PCI-e 3.0 isn&#8217;t hindering much at all, if any; you sometimes see a 0.5% or maybe 1% performance delta between the two but that&#8217;s typically it.</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-12910">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-03-06T11:09:06+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-12910" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-03-06 at 11:09</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Yes, the AMD Ryzen CPU series will be compatible with your NVIDIA cards. In general, all modern CPUs should support NVIDIA cards. This is so because the CPU and NVIDIA communicate with a protocol that is in general used for printers, network interfaces and so forth, and there is no CPU manufacturer which can themselves not to support these features. Thus all CPUs should have support for NVIDIA GPUs (at least those which come as PCIe cards, which are all GPUs except the ones with NVLink, that is the NVIDIA P100 currently).</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-12910' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-12910", "12910", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-12913">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-03-06T11:21:19+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-12913" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-03-06 at 11:21</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Looks a solid build which offers some opportunities for upgrades in the future. </p>
<p>If I would do more data science I would probably go with cheap or used DDR3 CPU/RAM combo and buy more RAM (32-64GB); possibly I would swap the GTX 1060 for a GTX 1070 if I have the spare money left from switching from DDR4 to DDR3. If I would do more deep learning I would also go for a DDR3 CPU/RAM combo, possibly buy used hardware, and then buy a GTX 1080 Ti.</p>
<p>This does not mean that your build is bad. Your build is more future proof. My build would be more &#8220;I-want-to-do-things-now&#8221;. I guess this depends on taste, but be aware of what you want to buy when you buy hardware. Do you want to buy data science, deep learning, machine learning, Kaggle competitions, or being future proof? Your build buys all of that a little and a lot of being future proof, which can be a very sensible choice.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-12913' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-12913", "12913", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

			<p>Final build &#8211; for now: </p>
<p>Intel Core i5-6500 3.2GHz Quad-Core Processor 198.68 (w shipping)<br />
Corsair H60 54.0 CFM Liquid CPU Cooler  59.99<br />
MSI B150 PC Mate ATX LGA1151 Motherboard 84.78<br />
Kingston HyperX Fury Black 8GB (1 x 8GB) DDR4-2133 Memory 68.99 (I tend to pull out memory and use it for other builds so kept the newer version)<br />
Western Digital Caviar Blue 1TB 3.5&#8243; 7200RPM Internal Hard Drive 49.99<br />
Gigabyte GeForce GTX 1070 8GB Windforce OC Video Card 369.99<br />
Rosewill GRAM ATX Mid Tower Case  49.99<br />
Rosewill 600W 80+ Bronze Certified Semi-Modular ATX Power Supply (had to up for the new GPU) 59.99<br />
TP-Link TG-3468 PCI-Express x1 10/100/1000 Mbps Network Adapter 9.22<br />
D-Link DWA-552 PCI 802.11g/n Wi-Fi Adapter 9.95<br />
Logitech K120 Wired Standard Keyboard 9.00</p>
<p>I am going to use a 32&#8243; TV &#8211; hope that doesn&#8217;t kill my eyes..<br />
And have a little mouse and speaker. </p>
<p>Total cost $970.57 (using used where possible)</p>

	<li class="comment even depth-5" id="comment-12931">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/ad8bbf0e30f89bf79f0362afa8c0f04a?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/ad8bbf0e30f89bf79f0362afa8c0f04a?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Michael</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-03-06T22:10:37+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-12931" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-03-06 at 22:10</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Ashley, no, this is not how I&#8217;d spend a thousand bucks if I needed a cheap machine for DL. Instead of getting all these parts individually, I&#8217;d shop for a decent used desktop, then buy a good video card separately. For example, something like this: <a href="https://santabarbara.craigslist.org/sys/5992606383.html" rel="nofollow">https://santabarbara.craigslist.org/sys/5992606383.html</a><br />
Then you will have enough money left for GTX 1080 and more. The truth is, CPU performance haven&#8217;t improved that much in the last 5 years, so for deep learning an old CPU + 1080 will be faster than a new CPU + 1070. </p>
<p>Also, you should get a SSD. Again, old CPU + SSD will be faster than new CPU + hard drive.</p>
<p>p.s. and you definitely don&#8217;t need a liquid cooler (nor any overclocking).</p>
		</div>

		
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="comment-12934">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-12935">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/1e4d893b3cc94944686ceb3a05361dc5?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/1e4d893b3cc94944686ceb3a05361dc5?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">ElXDi</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-03-06T22:40:30+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-12935" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-03-06 at 22:40</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim and all Deep Learning guys!<br />
I have a i7-4790K CPU with 32Gb of RAM which should be fine for the beginning.<br />
I&#8217;m planning to buy new GPU. I have a few options. 1060s is best seller and best chose price/performance, I guess. BTW here is list of non reference design PCBs <a href="http://thepcenthusiast.com/geforce-gtx-1060-compared-asus-evga-msi-gigabtye-zotac/" rel="nofollow">http://thepcenthusiast.com/geforce-gtx-1060-compared-asus-evga-msi-gigabtye-zotac/</a><br />
1. GTX 1060 3GB reference design 200e<br />
+ really cheap<br />
&#8211; poor over clocking results<br />
&#8211; just 3GB of VRAM</p>
<p>2. GTX 1060 3GB non reference design (the PCB is based on GTX 1080 with better power feed and 8pin connector) 250e.<br />
+ performance boost +5% 🙂<br />
+ ability to over clock with volt mode<br />
&#8211; price<br />
&#8211; just 3GB of VRAM<br />
3. GTX 1060 6GB ref design 260e<br />
+ more CUDA cores<br />
+ more VRAM</p>
<p>4. GTX 1060 6GB  non reference design (the PCB is based on GTX 1080 with better power feed and 8pin connector. 280e &#8211; 300e<br />
+ more CUDA cores<br />
+ more VRAM<br />
+ really good over clocking ability (+15%)<br />
&#8211; quite expensive<br />
&#8211; price / performance index is not so good any more</p>
<p>5. GTX 980 4Gb used with 1 year warranty 250e<br />
+ more CUDA<br />
+ 5% more performance than 1060 6GB version<br />
&#8211; used<br />
&#8211; less VRAM<br />
&#8211; more power consumption </p>
<p>So what you think about above options?  What is more important more VRAM or CUDA core number or GPU clock speed or VRAM bandwidth?</p>
<p>Thank you for sharing your experience!</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-12935' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-12935", "12935", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to ElXDi'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-12936">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-03-06T23:04:48+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-12936" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-03-06 at 23:04</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>If you have missed it you might want to check out my other blog post about GPU selection: <a href="http://timdettmers.com/2014/08/14/which-gpu-for-deep-learning/" rel="nofollow">GPU advice</a>. To reiterate the points:<br />
&#8211; Bandwidth is the thing that you want to have the most of<br />
&#8211; The best GPU in terms of cost/performance is the GTX 1070 (and soon also the GTX 1080 Ti)<br />
&#8211; GPU memory size is important; but for many tasks 8GB is fine. If you want to computer vision research get a 12GB GPU</p>
<p>To answer other questions: CUDA core number and clock speed are not that important. Overclocking will give you almost no performance increase for deep learning.</p>
<p>Hope that helps!</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-12936' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-12936", "12936", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-13205' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-13205", "13205", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Dhaval'>Reply</a></div>

	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-13474">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-03-19T18:16:11+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-13474" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-03-19 at 18:16</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>The GT 730 variant with GDDR5 memory is a good choice in that price range. The DDR3 variant will be much slower so pay attention to the memory. The memory is just 1 GB in this variant, but if you use 16-bit networks you can do some experiments with this. If you need to train larger networks then the DDR3 variant with larger memory (up to 4GB) will be a good choice too. You will have to wait for experiments a bit longer, but you will be able to run most models if you use 16-bit and you will get a speedup over using the CPU.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-13474' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-13474", "13474", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="comment-13273">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/8aa93c1c6477d7f76762820f7b960501?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/8aa93c1c6477d7f76762820f7b960501?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Chris</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-03-14T02:16:39+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-13273" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-03-14 at 02:16</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi,</p>
<p>someone else above had a similar but not exact the same question, hence I would like to ask for your opinion as well 🙂</p>
<p>I understand that it would be optimal to have a CPU with enough native PCIe lanes to connect to every GPU with 16 lanes. Given that I would like to build a system with not more than two GPUs, I would need 32 lanes for the GPUs to avoid PCIe bottlenecks. Currently that yields to socket 2011-3 CPUs (Broadwell) with 40 lanes.</p>
<p>If I would, for reasons of cost, use a socket 1151 (Kaby Lake) setup with a 16 lane CPU but with a mainboard offering a PLX switch that can offer 2 PCIe x 16 slots, one questions arises: Do the GPUs need the whole PCIe bandwidth permanently, forcing the PLX switch to permanently share the 16 x bandwidth into 8 x / 8x or is it more likely that the GPUs transmit in an interleaving manner with full x 16 bandwidth available to the currently transmitting one. My guess is, that the truth would be something in between but I have no exact numbers or benchmarks. Do you have some experience regarding actual bandwidth loss or suggestions here, is it beneficial to use a PLX switch in 16 lane CPU, dual GPU configurations or should I definitely go for a 40 lane CPU?</p>
<p>Cheers,</p>
<p>Chris</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-13273' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-13273", "13273", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Chris'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-13472">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-03-19T18:02:08+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-13472" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-03-19 at 18:02</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Chris,</p>
<p>there are some motherboard which support the 16x speed when no transfers to the other GPU is executed, but this is rare. In general you will have 8x / 8x speed. Check your motherboard specs for this.</p>
<p>I would not worry too much about PCIe lanes. If you want to parallelize GPUs it will be a performance hit, but you would still get good speedups. If you use good parallelization algorithms, like those provided by Microsoft&#8217;s CNTK, then you will have no performance hit. If you use the GPUs separately you will see almost no performance hit. So I would just go ahead with that setup. It will probably give you the best bang for the buck.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-13472' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-13472", "13472", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-14032">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-04-08T15:58:42+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-14032" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-04-08 at 15:58</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Sami,</p>
<p>I so do see why the $180 would be justified; the board adds 1 PCIe slot but give pretty much the same deep learning performance.</p>
<p>Please note that if you have two GPUs of different chipset for example a GTX 1070 and a GTX 1080 you will not be able to parallelize them.</p>
<p>Often the coolers on the GPUs are quite similar in performance so that it should not be a big deal. However, I am not so familiar with the current fan designs and there might be a fan which is superior to others. I probably would pay $20-30 if the fan performance is > 33% better, but not more. I do not think it is worth it at a certain point &#8211; better to save that money to buy another GPU in the future.</p>
<p>Hope this helps</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-14032' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-14032", "14032", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-4" id="comment-14045">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-04-09T10:49:01+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-14045" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-04-09 at 10:49</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Ah I understand, using a GTX 1080 Ti and a GTX 1070 makes sense if you use them in that way.</p>
<p>There are in general no reliable motherboard manufacturers, but certain specific motherboard versions are more stable than others. I think to orient yourself along newegg reviews is a good idea. For example, I would not buy the motherboard that you linked due to their bad reviews. However, I am not current on the market situation for motherboards, so you have to find a good motherboard by yourself. Usually using pcpartpicker, selecting the X-SLI option where X is how many GPUs you want to have and then sort the price and pick the first option with good reviews is a sound strategy to find a good motherboard.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-14045' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-14045", "14045", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-14056">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/ad8bbf0e30f89bf79f0362afa8c0f04a?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/ad8bbf0e30f89bf79f0362afa8c0f04a?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Michael</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-04-09T22:25:40+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-14056" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-04-09 at 22:25</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Sami, for my last 3 workstations, I didn&#8217;t bother building them myself. I sent the desired specs to several system builders, and then negotiated the price down. In the end, I only paid a few hundred bucks more than what it would cost me to do it myself.<br />
For your budget, I would buy a used computer, 2-3 generations old, and get a couple of 1080 Ti cards.</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-04-19T10:11:19+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-14334" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-04-19 at 10:11</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Maybe you should consider one or two additional case fans? IIRC the power supply fan pushes the air out. If you add another out-blowing fan somewhere at the top and an aspirating  one at the bottom this might improve heat dissipation in 24/7 operation.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Does CPU have 40 lanes? </p>
<p>How many max GPU it can support?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-14615' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-14615", "14615", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to trulia'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-3" id="comment-14620">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-04-29T13:20:29+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-14620" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-04-29 at 13:20</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>A CPU can have between 16 and 40 lanes. Read the specifications of a CPU to see how many lanes that CPU has. Usually you will need at least 8 lanes for a single GPU, but this is dependent on your motherboard. The CPU can provide support for lanes, but they must be there on the motherboard. A CPU can support a maximum of 4 GPUs.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-14620' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-14620", "14620", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-14332">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/22f9ef0f9f882d3d049d3c56800a60c3?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/22f9ef0f9f882d3d049d3c56800a60c3?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Petra-Kathi</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-04-19T10:01:45+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-14332" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-04-19 at 10:01</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Another great thank-you from my side as I (hope I) have gained a lot of insight into the hardware setup of deep learning workstations!</p>
<p>Presently I am in the position of defining a deep learning workstation for internal research purposes in a professional environment (i.e.: full-grown Windows IT environment :-/ with a dedicated server room, requirements to use only certified hardware and such). From the pure deep learning research approach I would have opted for a system with 3 or 4 GTX 1080TI cards &#8211; well aware of the problem of parallelization, but at least providing ample computing power for independent parallel jobs to come to their ends in sensible absolute time slices. But the only certified offer in the strived-for power range we got was a system with 2 P6000 cards.<br />
As this card is quite new and mentioned here only once and without further discussion w/r/to potential deep learning issues, let me please ask for hands-on experiences in the directions of libraries support, half precision deep learning computational power, and potential further quirks I may not have thought about? I am well aware that the P6000 is sub-optimal cost-wise, but anything not certified is a no-go in this environment.  🙁<br />
Your hints are very appreciated!</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-14332' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-14332", "14332", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Petra-Kathi'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-14384">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-04-21T12:31:06+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-14384" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-04-21 at 12:31</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>The P6000 is based on the GP102 ship, which is very similar to a GTX 1080 Ti and Titan X Pascal. The features and performance will be similar to these cards, that is, you will have usual support of all deep learning libraries, good computational power, but almost no half-precision performance. So with that card you will receive a powerful GPU which you can use in your certified environment. If the cost difference between the P6000 and P100 is slim, you might want to opt for the P100 with which you gain a bit of performance and half-precision computation. However, if the difference is larger then just go with the P6000.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-14384' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-14384", "14384", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="comment-14389">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/ad8bbf0e30f89bf79f0362afa8c0f04a?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/ad8bbf0e30f89bf79f0362afa8c0f04a?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Michael</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-04-21T17:59:20+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-14389" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-04-21 at 17:59</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>I&#8217;d definitely recommend going with Quadro GP100 or Tesla P100:<br />
<a href="https://exxactcorp.com/index.php/product/prod_detail/2048" rel="nofollow">https://exxactcorp.com/index.php/product/prod_detail/2048</a><br />
<a href="https://exxactcorp.com/index.php/product/prod_detail/1662" rel="nofollow">https://exxactcorp.com/index.php/product/prod_detail/1662</a><br />
P100 should provide double the performance of P6000 for deep learning, with effectively the same or more of half precision memory (24GB or 32GB).<br />
Talk to Exxact folks, I had a very positive experience with them.</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-14607">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Nikos Tsarmpopoulos</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-04-29T01:11:52+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-14607" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-04-29 at 01:11</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim,</p>
<p>I&#8217;m reading through each and every single article of yours, they are to-the-point and very helpful for beginners in neural networks, like myself. </p>
<p>Regarding PCIe 3.0, I&#8217;ve noticed that most consumer-grade motherboards fall back to x8x8x16 for three GPUs and x8x8x8x8 for four GPUs. Hence, in a multi-GPU setup, where a different CPU thread handles each GPU, it&#8217;s not possible make use of the GPUs&#8217; x16 lanes capability. Notably, PCIe 3.0 x8 has the same theoretical throughput as PCIe 2.0 x16.</p>
<p>While searching for motherboards with more PCIe lanes, I noticed that some new consumer-targetted motherboards come with a PEX 8747 Broadcom PCIe Bridge. That&#8217;s a 48 lanes bridge, which is still insufficient for non-synchronised, concurrent data transfers. Broadcom&#8217;s top of the line bridge supports 96 lanes (no idea how this solution costs): 64 lanes could be used for 4 GPUs and 32 additional lanes for the CPU, which means GPUs can communicate with each other using the full PCIe 3.0 x16 bandwidth and up to two GPUs can concurrently transfer data from/to the CPU at full bandwidth. </p>
<p>Have you considered these solutions? Are you aware of motherboards that deliver sufficiently good value for money, e.g. achieving performance that would costs a less than alternative solutions, to justify the cost?</p>
<p>Thanks in advance.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-14607' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-14607", "14607", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Nikos Tsarmpopoulos'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-14622">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-04-29T13:37:47+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-14622" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-04-29 at 13:37</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Nikos,</p>
<p>thanks for your comment. I also stumbled upon these switches, but in the end they are probably not so suitable for deep learning. The details are a bit difficult to understand but let me try to explain: The problem with these solutions is that they still use the underlying PCIe interface and thus are limited just like normal PCIe transfers. In most graphics applications you do not have parallel GPU-to-GPU transfers, but GPU-to-GPU transfers which are slightly off-set in time and also small in size. Under such circumstances you can have clever protocols and extra lanes which feed into the usually attached lanes (which have a hard limit to 16 per GPU) in a safe in secure manner without blocking the channels. In other words, with these switches you can send multiple packets asynchronously and securely but each GPU still receives one packet at a time; in a normal switch each packet must be scheduled after all other packets on that path have completed or otherwise one has insecure transfers (which can corrupt the data).</p>
<p>The crux is that in deep learning, or generally in computing, you do many parallel transfers at the very same time and usually these packets are large. With this new fancy switch you can start the transfer of the packets asynchronously but they will still block each other for access to the GPU (because it takes quite some time to send the full package). This means that instead of blocking <em>before</em> the transfer you now have blocking <em>during</em> the transfer. I am not sure about the performance in this case, but I could imagine that the performance is the same or even worse than with normal switches.</p>
<p>The reasoning behind these switches is that they trade the synchronization of the full PCIe path with the synchronization of sub-paths on the PCIe circuit (the sub-path to the GPU) which increases performance for many applications, especially graphics applications, but probably not for deep learning.</p>
<p>Hope this helps!</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-14622' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-14622", "14622", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="comment-14730">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Nikos Tsarmpopoulos</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-05-04T01:33:30+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-14730" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-05-04 at 01:33</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim, </p>
<p>Thanks for your response, as always very informative. </p>
<p>I wrote to Broadcom, to ask for additional information regarding their particular PCIE switches and they came back with very interesting feedback. </p>
<p>My understanding from their response is that broadcom&#8217;s aforementioned 80- and 96- lanes switches should  allow for more efficient GPU &#8211; to &#8211; GPU communication at full x16 lanes speed (per pair), compared to the x8 lanes currently supported in triple and quadruple GPU configurations via a 40lanes CPU. </p>
<p>However, they also implied that these [current generation] switches communicate with the cpu via a 16lanes connection, ie the cpu cannot establish two 16lanes connections with corresponding GPUs in parallel via the switch. Multicasting data wouldn&#8217;t be affected. </p>
<p>I&#8217;m looking into reconfirming this with Broadcom, as there might be a benefit in using a motherboard with these switches in multiGPU configs. </p>
<p>Kind regards,<br />
Nikos</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-14730' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-14730", "14730", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Nikos Tsarmpopoulos'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment even depth-3" id="comment-14733">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Nikos Tsarmpopoulos</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-05-04T02:45:43+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-14733" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-05-04 at 02:45</a></time></p>		</header>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-05-04T18:05:31+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-14743" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-05-04 at 18:05</a></time></p>		</header>

	<li class="comment even depth-4" id="comment-14999">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Nikos Tsarmpopoulos</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-05-14T14:53:03+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-14999" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-05-14 at 14:53</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim,</p>
<p>Following up from my previous message, I have now confirmed with Broadcom that, due to a contraint imposed by the PCIe specification, its PCIe switches feature a total of 16 lanes on the upstream port, i.e. to the CPU. </p>
<p>The downstream ports are non blocking, i.e. when using a PCIe switch of 80 lanes (64 lanes for the GPUs + 16 lanes for the upstream connection to the CPU), pairs of GPUs can talk to each other directly, using 16 lanes per pair. </p>
<p>If we use 4 GPUs, a single GPU can broadcast data to the others at full x16 speed (versus x8 speed if they were attached directly to the CPU&#8217;s PCIe lanes). </p>
<p>Also, the CPU can broadcast data to all four GPUs using the full x16 throughput. </p>
<p>Two pairs of GPUs can exchange data at full x16 speed (again, versus x8 speed if they were attached directly to the CPU&#8217;s PCIe lanes).</p>
<p>The downside is lower concurrent (non-broadcasted) data throughput from the CPU to the GPUs, where 16 lanes will be shared, delivering the equivalent of x4 throghput per GPU (versus x8 speed, if &#8230;, as above).</p>
<p>Thus, it really depends on how much unicast data needs to be transferred -concurrently- between the CPU and the GPUs versus between the GPUs. </p>
<p>Depending on what proportion of the time it takes to train a deep neural network is spent on (a)unicasting data -concurrently- from the CPU to the GPUs , (b) broadcasting data from the CPU to the GPUs, (c) unicasting data between pairs of GPUs and (d) broadcasting data from one GPU to the rest, a multi-GPU might benefit from a PCIe switch (also called PLX).</p>
<p>My understanding is that a motherboard with such a switch costs £200-£300 more than normal motherboards.</p>
<p>What do you think?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-14999' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-14999", "14999", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Nikos Tsarmpopoulos'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-5" id="comment-15030">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-05-15T18:02:57+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-15030" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-05-15 at 18:02</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>That is a pretty good insight, thanks Nikos! </p>
<p>So one will get improved performance from such a system. However, for bigger systems it is common to pool the data on the CPU to perform more complicated, tree-like broadcasts through the network. I do not think such broadcasts are currently implemented for GPU memory (this feature might have been added since the last time I checked, which was more than a year ago). I think such a motherboard with the 64 GPU lanes would be optimal in a 4 GPU setup. For a multi-node setup it might still be helpful, but probably too expensive to justify the costs, and for big systems reliability is often more important than squeezing out the last bits of performance. </p>
<p>All of this also depends on the type of algorithm that one uses though, but it is good to know that these motherboards can improve performance! Thanks again!</p>
		</div>

		
		
	</article>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-05-01T06:52:12+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-14676" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-05-01 at 06:52</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-14676' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-14676", "14676", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Charles U'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-14698">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-05-02T13:38:26+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-14698" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-05-02 at 13:38</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>This requirement is not so strict; I should update my blog post on this. If you have 4GB RAM you will be able to work with most datasets if you stream your data, that is load them in small batches bit-by-bit. If you do this 4GB will even suffice for the GTX 1080Ti. You might run into some problems if you run very large RNNs, but this can be prevent with some code which initialize weight directly on the GPU rather than CPU. You might also run into problems when you preprocess data, but also this can be managed with some extra code. You should be fine with 4GB.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-14698' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-14698", "14698", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-14767">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a4b2ea53e9e2c663e20efc0939b90cc5?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a4b2ea53e9e2c663e20efc0939b90cc5?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Adarsh</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-05-05T13:57:12+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-14767" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-05-05 at 13:57</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hey Tim, Nice article. I have a question:<br />
 Lets suppose I train a model for a particular task (classify an image in class 1 or 2) on a particular kind of input (800&#215;400 resolution), I want to choose a GPU with MINIMUM number of cores and power that would give me the result in under 100 mili seconds. How to estimate this without running the model on GPU? Is there a relation between no of cores of the GPU and the performance of a deep learning model?</p>
<p>Thanks a lot in advance.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-14767' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-14767", "14767", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Adarsh'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-14768">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-05-05T14:05:43+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-14768" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-05-05 at 14:05</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>The speed of the computational units between different GPUs of the same series are about the same (NVIDIA Titan Xp modules are not much faster than say, GTX 1060 modules), but the reason why bigger cards is faster that they just have more modules (called stream multiprocessors or SMs). If your model is computationally not intensive, then benchmarking some small GPUs and extrapolating the number of SMs might be a valid option to find which is the optimal GPU in this case.</p>
<p>For operations which saturate the GPU such as big matrix multiplications or, in general, convolution this is very difficult to estimate. It sounds like you want to reduce costs. A good way to do this is also through power efficiency and this is a very transparent option which can be easily optimized. It also sounds like you want to reduce latency — this is very difficult to test because computationally graphs differ too widely; the only option that I see is to find people that have these GPUs and let them run benchmarks on your model. Or otherwise, try to generalize existing benchmarks for your model.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-14768' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-14768", "14768", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment even depth-3" id="comment-14769">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">

Let us assume I have a GPU of 4 SMs and 4GB Global Memory on Pascal architecture which gives me X mili second avg classification time.  Theoretically, Can I expect timing of X/2 mili seconds with a GPU having 8 SMs and 8 GB Global memory.</p>

<p>Thanks</p>

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="comment-14773">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/ad8bbf0e30f89bf79f0362afa8c0f04a?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/ad8bbf0e30f89bf79f0362afa8c0f04a?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Michael</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-05-05T18:46:59+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-14773" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-05-05 at 18:46</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Adarsh, it&#8217;s hard to give you any advice, because you didn&#8217;t tell us anything about what you&#8217;re trying to do exactly: what is your accuracy target (e.g. on ImageNet)? What is your power budget? </p>
<p>People have run VGG and Inception on an Iphone 6s, with 150-300ms latency:<br />
<a href="http://machinethink.net/blog/convolutional-neural-networks-on-the-iphone-with-vggnet/" rel="nofollow">http://machinethink.net/blog/convolutional-neural-networks-on-the-iphone-with-vggnet/</a></p>
<p>If you have some embedded application in mind, then your best option is Jetson TX2 dev kit. It should definitely be able to run latest Imagenet networks under 100ms latency.<br />
See this nice paper which tested the previous Jetson kit:<br />
<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1605.07678" rel="nofollow">https://arxiv.org/abs/1605.07678</a><br />
It also provides some insight into the relation of amount computation and accuracy.</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="comment-14789">

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-05-06T15:50:52+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-14789" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-05-06 at 15:50</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hello Tim.<br />
Thank you very much for this blog. You gave me solid background for my understanding of dependency between hardware and deep learning.</p>
<p>I have a question about bus speed in CPU. Should that be a concern ? As you wrote the true bottleneck is between cpu and gpu, and as i understand the &#8220;Bus speed&#8221; which is at ark.intel white sheets refers to that connection.<br />
I have to choose between E5-262x v4/3 or E5-16xx v4/3. The 262x family have  bus speed set at 8 GT/s QPI while 16xx have  5 GT/s. (8 GT/s is what PCIe 3.0 offers) Besides the Scalability, clock frequency and memory bandwidth that is the difference between them, and the only one that matters in deep learning since all of them have clock speeds above 2GHz, memory bandwidth over 68 GB/s and I will not make use of Scalability.</p>
<p>This link refers to the possible comparison of those models: <a href="http://ark.intel.com/compare/92980,92986,92994,92987" rel="nofollow">http://ark.intel.com/compare/92980,92986,92994,92987</a></p>
<p>Thank you in advance.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-14789' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-14789", "14789", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Thomas'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-14893">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-05-10T13:10:58+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-14893" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-05-10 at 13:10</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>It is correct that this is the main bottleneck between the CPU and GPU, however a very tiny amount of time in spend between CPU-GPU interactions on a memory level compared to the actually GPU computation. It becomes more relevant if you have multiple GPUs, but for multiple GPUs the main bottlenecks are somewhere else. Currently a good CPU (in terms of bus speed) will improve your deep learning performance by about 0-1.5% compared to a &#8220;standard&#8221; one and I would not worry about it too much. I think all the CPUs that you linked are more than fine.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-14893' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-14893", "14893", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi! </p>
<p>First of all a big thanks! You&#8217;ve basically created the best resource for deep learning enthusiasts looking to build their own machine.</p>
<p>My computer is going to be situated close to my bed so one priority is noise. This brings me to the first issue of whether or not to get a reference (Founders Edition) 1080 Ti or not, as they generally seem to be louder than their OEM counterparts. There seems to be a debate around performance and quality between reference and OEM cards. From what I can gather, most people who are doing long-running computations rather than gaming, especially on multi GPU setups, favor reference cards due to their fan design which blows air out the back rather than just circulate air inside the case. I&#8217;m starting with one card and plan to add a second one later, and I doubt I&#8217;ll get more than 2 cards for a while. </p>
<p>For the CPU, I was first looking at Intel i7 6850k, which was the cheapest i7 I could find that supports 40 lanes. However, Intel Xeon E5-1620 V4 is almost half the price and also supports 40 lanes. Not sure if the faster i7 is worth the money here?</p>
<p>Lastly, I was thinking about getting a water cooler for the CPU. I&#8217;ve read mixed opinions about water cooling, but I reckon moving air outside of the case should be a good thing as it allows the GPUs to run at lower temperatures?</p>
<p>Here&#8217;s the build: <a href="https://pcpartpicker.com/list/gzfgxY" rel="nofollow">https://pcpartpicker.com/list/gzfgxY</a></p>
<p>Any suggestions highly appreciated!</p>
