	<li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="comment-14970">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/19b4e0c8de00ffbd3b527c41cc374c74?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/19b4e0c8de00ffbd3b527c41cc374c74?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Sam</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-05-13T18:52:58+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-14970" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-05-13 at 18:52</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim,</p>
<p>Thanks so much for writing all of this up, it&#8217;s very informative. I&#8217;m currently picking out parts for a DL machine, and I&#8217;m trying to figure out where I may have bottlenecks.</p>
<p>Your piece on DMI for ram to vram transfer is quite interesting. Most of what I&#8217;m reading emphasizes high pci-e bandwidth. I&#8217;m building a dual gpu system, and I&#8217;m wondering if I really need both gpus running at pci 3.0&#215;16, or if x8 is fine for each? It sounds like the DMA bandwidth could be a problem. I couldn&#8217;t find much info on DMA related to specific chipsets, however you mentioned 12GB/s. Is this bandwidth the same for different chipsets (I&#8217;m comparing z270 to x99). If I&#8217;m mostly running independent models on each GPU, would I see much if any benefit to 2x pci-3 x16, or would that only really show a big benefit when running the gpu&#8217;s in parallel for a single model? Asynchronous mini-batch allocation is interesting, however I&#8217;m not sure if it&#8217;s integrated into all of the newer high-level DL frameworks&#8230;</p>
<p>Re: the DMA issue, intel&#8217;s new optane drives are routed through PCI, and they can be used as ram in addition to long term storage. Do you think that these can be used as a way around the DMA bottleneck??</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-14970' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-14970", "14970", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Sam'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-15027">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-05-15T17:52:40+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-15027" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-05-15 at 17:52</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>If you use the right algorithms there will be almost no decrease in performance if you use x8 for each GPU. Even if you use the &#8220;wrong&#8221; algorithms, performance reduction should be minimal for most models since aggregated transfer-times for 2 GPUs are not that large. The costs increase dramatically as you add more GPUs though — for a 4 GPU system it is important that you are on PCIe 3.0 with at least 32 PCIe lanes from your CPU/motherboard.</p>
<p>I would not care too much about DMA. I suppose for most chipsets / CPU combos it is the same. It might differ a bit here and there, but the performance difference should be negligible. I recommend using PyTorch for parallelism if you have a two GPUs and if you have 4+ GPUs I recommend Microsoft&#8217;s CNTK.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-15027' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-15027", "15027", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="comment-15283">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/19b4e0c8de00ffbd3b527c41cc374c74?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/19b4e0c8de00ffbd3b527c41cc374c74?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Sam</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-05-24T23:19:56+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-15283" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-05-24 at 23:19</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Thanks! After days and days of research I just ordered my hardware.</p>
<p>I thought I&#8217;d mention, theres a motherboard that I feel is perfect for dual gpu rigs: The ASRock Z270 supercarrier:</p>
<p><a href="http://www.asrock.com/MB/Intel/Z270%20SuperCarrier/index.asp" rel="nofollow">http://www.asrock.com/MB/Intel/Z270%20SuperCarrier/index.asp</a></p>
<p>This board, like some of the x99 workstation boards has a PLX switch, allowing dual pci x16 or quad pci x8 on a Z270 board. For dual gpu rigs, you get the added benefit of being able to run 2 gpus 4 slots apart (instead of the usual 3 slots on most non-workstation boards). This helps a lot with cooling since there&#8217;s more space between the 2 gpus, especially with non-reference coolers taking up 2.5-3 slots these days.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-15283' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-15283", "15283", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Sam'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment even depth-4" id="comment-15284">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/d6e53cd310d401852858089d556ce04a?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/d6e53cd310d401852858089d556ce04a?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tom</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-05-24T23:50:37+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-15284" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-05-24 at 23:50</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Sam,<br />
 What Processor are you using  with  ASRock Z270 supercarrier?<br />
Intel  i7-6850K Processor   ???<br />
Does this motherboard support 40 Lane ?</p>
<p>Thanks<br />
Tom</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-15284' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-15284", "15284", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tom'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="comment-15289">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/19b4e0c8de00ffbd3b527c41cc374c74?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/19b4e0c8de00ffbd3b527c41cc374c74?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Sam</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-05-25T00:42:19+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-15289" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-05-25 at 00:42</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hey Tom,</p>
<p>I&#8217;m using a i7 7700k. The ASRock Z270 Supercarrier is a Z270 board, so it takes LGA1151 chips, which are limited to 16 lanes, therefore CPU&#8217;s for this board only have 16 lanes. Just like how some of the Asus/ASRock X99 workstation boards have dual PLX chips that allow 4x pci x16 with a 40 lane X99 cpu, the Z270 Supercarrier allows a cpu with 16 lanes to run 2 GPUs at pci x16. Of course it&#8217;s not that simple &#8211; I don&#8217;t think the performance is identical when running PLX chips to get &#8220;more&#8221; pci lanes than your CPU has, but my understanding is that the GPUs can communicate with each other at x16. Same reason why the Nvidia dev boxes use X99 chips with 40 lanes yet operate 4 cards at x16 through a workstation board with plx chips, the Supercarrier lets us run 2 cards at x16 with a 16 lane Z270 cpu. It&#8217;s much cheaper than a i7-6850k yet allows for similar GPU bandwidth. I think that Z270 also has some other nice things that X99 doesn&#8217;t because it&#8217;s much newer, although X99 does support some things that Z270 doesn&#8217;t like quad channel memory. Lastly, having a board with 4 slots between GPU&#8217;s is nicer for SLI when you&#8217;re air cooling.</p>
		</div>

		
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment even depth-4" id="comment-15285">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/ad8bbf0e30f89bf79f0362afa8c0f04a?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/ad8bbf0e30f89bf79f0362afa8c0f04a?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Michael</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-05-24T23:52:33+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-15285" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-05-24 at 23:52</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Dual PCIe x16 should not need any PLX switches. The switch is only needed when you want to do Quad PCIe x16, which is more lanes than a single CPU can support.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-15285' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-15285", "15285", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Michael'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="comment-15290">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/19b4e0c8de00ffbd3b527c41cc374c74?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/19b4e0c8de00ffbd3b527c41cc374c74?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Sam</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Dual PCIe x16 doesn&#8217;t need switches when using a 40 lane CPU, however having a switch on a Z270 board allows me to use a much cheaper, still very powerful 16 lane CPU with 2 GPUs at x16.</p>
		</div>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-05-25T00:49:46+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-15291" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-05-25 at 00:49</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Non-X99 motherboards and a normal processor which does not have  40 lanes can not run  2 GPU with the full power which is 16X, is that correct? </p>
<p>So in my understanding  ASRock Z270 supercarrier is perfect becase it allows having 2 GPU using 16x and   3 M.2.</p>
<p>99.9% motherboard does not space to put 4 GPU  (Overclocked ones) without water cooling installed.  4 Founder edition GPU can be installed  in motherboard like &#8220;ASUS LGA2011-v3 Dual 10G LAN 4-Way GPU ATX/CEB Motherboard (X99-E-10G WS)&#8221; which provide full 16x utalization.</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="comment-15298">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/19b4e0c8de00ffbd3b527c41cc374c74?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/19b4e0c8de00ffbd3b527c41cc374c74?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Sam</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-05-25T02:32:15+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-15298" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-05-25 at 02:32</a></time></p>		</header>

		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-15298' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-15298", "15298", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Sam'>Reply</a></div>

	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment even depth-5" id="comment-15300">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Nikolaos Tsarmpopoulos</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-05-25T03:17:26+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-15300" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-05-25 at 03:17</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>With a 40 lanes cpu you can have the CPU concurrently exchanging data with 2 GPUs at full bandwidth. </p>
<p>With a x16 lanes CPU you&#8217;re limited to either x16 lanes to one GPU at a time,  or x8 lanes for concurrent exchange of data with both GPUs. </p>
<p>As Tim  mentioned earlier, for 2 GPUs you&#8217;re fine with x8 per GPU. Having said that, 16 lanes on the cpu may not be sufficient, as some of these lanes maybe reserved by the chipset or other PCIe devices, eg integrated M.2 slot.</p>
<p>I would opt for a cpu with more PCIe lanes, as Tim and Michael have advised.</p>
		</div>

		
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-15583">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/90c25326d6e73f0e7b9e3c26de1447dd?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/90c25326d6e73f0e7b9e3c26de1447dd?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Raja</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-06-02T10:17:17+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-15583" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-06-02 at 10:17</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>So I&#8217;ve purchased a ryzen 1700x and a msi x370 sli plus<br />
I am wondering if it is going to bottleneck 2x 1080ti for deep learning?<br />
ryzen only has 24 pcie lanes</p>
<p>the board only supports<br />
x8/x8 in pci 3.0<br />
if i understand correctly that is almost the same as x16 pci 2.0</p>
<p>Is x16 pcie 2.0 single gpu a bottleneck?<br />
is x8/x8 pcie 3.0 going to bottleneck 2 gpus?</p>
<p>a 1080ti has 11gbps ram<br />
but x8 pcie 3.0 would be only around 8gbps while x16 3.0 is around 16gbps</p>
<p>Can a modern gpu stream in new data while it is doing calculations?<br />
in which case some of the 11gbps is being used for compute and some of it is being used to stream new data in?</p>
<p>Bit of a deep learning rookie here.<br />
Grateful for any advice.<br />
Also will the dual channel ram in ryzen be a problem?</p>
<p>Should i build a threadripper machine?<br />
As of now I don&#8217;t plan to use 4 gpus.<br />
So as long as my current build doesn&#8217;t have a major problem i will use it with 2 gpus<br />
and then next year do a 4 gpu build with canonlake/10nm</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-15583' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-15583", "15583", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Raja'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-15590">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-06-02T16:21:38+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-15590" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-06-02 at 16:21</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>It depends on the algorithm but in general PCIe lanes with 2 GPUs are not that important. If will decrease performance but not by a lot. Maybe 0-10% depending on the use-case. You should be fine.</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="comment-15616">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/1fc314405c7cd8c86ff471c7ca97e1c6?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/1fc314405c7cd8c86ff471c7ca97e1c6?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Alderasus Ghaliamus</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-06-03T08:35:21+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-15616" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-06-03 at 08:35</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>First of all,  thank you very much for how comprehensive and deep knowledge you gave us through the two blogs: the full and the GPU focused. </p>
<p>I wish that you could answer my question, with advance apologies if my question asking the obvious. </p>
<p>I was about to spend around £3800 on a PC (the new ALIENWARE AURORA) which has two GeForce  GTX 1080 Ti, 64GB DDR4 at 2400MHz, and Intel Core i7-7700K Processo. I was very happy that I finally could decide which PC I should buy for my PhD research the next two years. What made me more happy that I was following your appreciated GPU-focused blog &#8211; YES! I have multiple high performance GPUs!</p>
<p>However, something took me to the other blog &#8211; this blog &#8211; and I read the CPU advice ending with the fact that my CPU is only 16 PCIe lanes &#8211; not 40 as you warned. I went back the first step in my searching for a PC, before 4 months. </p>
<p>I did my best again, [focusing only on built PCs by Dell or Lenovo], and I ended with another ALIENWARE PC &#8211; the ALIENWARE AREA-51, which has same* GPUs and Memory in the first PC in my comment, however it has different CPU which is i7-6850K with 40 PCIe lanes and 3.0 ER. However, the cost went up by more £700:  £4500. It is expensive, I could and will afford it for my PhD, but it is expensive.</p>
<p>When I reached such cost, I remembered two Laptops from which I ran away because their costs. I said to myself, if I reached £4500 with the PC, why not go with the life laptop with one or two more thousands. The laptops are:</p>
<p>(A) ThinkPad P71.<br />
&#8211; CPU: Intel Xeon E3-1535M v6 (certainly, back to 16 PCIe lanes).<br />
&#8211; Memory: 64GB(16&#215;4) DDR4 2400MHz ECC SoDIMM<br />
&#8211; GPU: NVIDIA Quadro P5000 16GB (no two GPUs).<br />
&#8211; SSD: 1TB<br />
-HDD: 1TB<br />
-Cost: £6200</p>
<p>(B) Dell Precision 7720:<br />
&#8211; CPU: Intel Xeon E3-1535M v6 (certainly, back to 16 PCIe lanes).<br />
&#8211; Memory: 64GB(16&#215;4) DDR4 2400MHz ECC SoDIMM<br />
&#8211; GPU: NVIDIA Quadro P5000 16GB (no two GPUs).<br />
&#8211; SSD: 1TB<br />
-HDD: 2TB<br />
-Cost: £5800</p>
<p>So, my choices are as following:<br />
Choice One: new ALIENWARE AURORA as PC + XPS 15  £1800 as Laptop = £5400<br />
Choice Two: ALIENWARE AREA-51 + my very old crying coughing laptop = £4500<br />
Choice Three: no PC + ThinkPad P71 = £6200<br />
Choice Four: no PC + Dell Precision 7720 = £5800</p>
<p>If you could please, and really I am so sorry to have you and your appreciated time reading this long comment, help me with selecting one choice or arranging them with your reasons, you will make my next two years technically truly safe. I have to say that my research is on two different data spaces: genetic data and textual data. </p>
<p>Finally, thank you again for your contribution through this blog, and thank you in advance for getting this point reading my comment.</p>
<p>*To be fair regarding the cost of the second PC, it has 2 more TB HDD [4TB] than the first PC, however it provides the same size of SSD: 512GB.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-15616' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-15616", "15616", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Alderasus Ghaliamus'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-15684">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-06-05T03:28:43+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-15684" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-06-05 at 03:28</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>These are all solid options albeit all quite expensive. Note that PCIe lanes are not that important if you have 2 GPUs, but become more important if you have 4 GPUs. However, I do think the biggest issues here is just that these computers are too expensive. If I were you I would go for a used computer solution which I would upgrade to your needs.</p>
<p>For example, I just last week sold my used computer, which is similar, or even better than these options for 800 pounds on gumtree. So a smart choice might be to buy a used computer and upgrade it with some parts. For genetics research I would try to find a cheap computer which support 8 RAM slots and than buy 64 GB RAM for the machine and upgrade to 128 GB of RAM if your research requires this. Speed of the RAM is overvalued; a plain DDR3 RAM setup is sufficient and cheap. For some deep learning algorithms or algorithms in computational biology a single GPU should be sufficient but choose one that has a lot of RAM; a 12GB is ideal and I would go for a used GTX Titan X for 400-500 pounds on eBay (make sure your computer has a PSU which at least support 600 watts).</p>
<p>This option would yield a very high performance computer for roughly 2000 pounds. Of course it requires some manual assembly, but it really is not difficult and you really should try to do this.</p>
<p>If you cannot get a used option with parts due to university bureaucracy I would go with a ordinary laptop + a <a href="https://www.hetzner.de/en/hosting/produkte_rootserver/ex51ssd-gpu" rel="nofollow">hetzner.de GPU machine</a> which for a 3 year PhD will cost 4400 pounds but offers everything that you need and can be canceled / upgraded month-wise. For most genetics research you should be fine without a GPU which would cost 2150 pounds on hetzner.de. If your algorithms require double precision then you will need to make a careful choice about which GPU to get, but probably the most cost efficient solution would involve renting some Tesla GPU in the cloud (AWS for example) to work with double precision when you need it.</p>
<p>So the main options that I see are (1) buying used computer and upgrade its parts, (2) buy ordinary laptop and a dedicated machine in the cloud. These options will give you the best performance per quid.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-15684' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-15684", "15684", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

many many thanks for your great blog articles, they are a great help! </p>
<p>I have a perhaps a bit off-topic question. Can you recommend any resources to learn about computer hardware on a conceptual level?  So I am not really interested in the underlying electrical engineering just yet, but about different components and how they interact. For example I&#8217;m interested in how data is being transferred from memory to GPU-memory in more detail.</p>
<p>Thank you again,<br />
Felix</p>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-16127">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-06-16T20:08:32+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-16127" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-06-16 at 20:08</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>That is a good question, but unfortunately, I do not have a good answer for that! I also wanted to learn more the conceptual side of hardware, but the resources that I found are often resources from universities and textbooks which also look at the details. What I found most promising was to just do google searches for specific questions and try to get informed through multiple sources of websites. For example googling <a href="https://www.google.com/?gws_rd=ssl#q=cpu+to+gpu+memory+transfer" rel="nofollow">&#8220;cpu to gpu memory transfer&#8221;</a> will yield blog posts, forum questions, presentations on the topic and so forth. With that, you can get informed about that question. From here you might have new questions which you can then google. If you do this for a few hours every week, you will get quite knowledgeable about concepts quite quickly. Hope this helps!<br />
Tim</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-16127' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-16127", "16127", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-3" id="comment-16819">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-07-05T00:48:24+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-16819" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-07-05 at 00:48</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>That sounds reasonable. If I were you I would also pay good attention to the motherboard. If it has extra RAM slots (8 slots) then you can always increase the RAM size if you need more; in that way you can upgrade your setup depending on the problem that you are working on.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-16819' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-16819", "16819", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-16818">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-07-05T00:44:02+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-16818" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-07-05 at 00:44</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>You might want to go with the 64GB setup depending on what kind of graphs you will work. The graph structure can differ greatly and some graphs will require you to have more than 100GB of RAM while for others it is more manageable. The CPU if often less important (but still depends on graph and problem, so check this for problems/graphs you work with). A GTX 1060 might be a bit slow at times, but often you do not work with the full graphs anyways because training would take too long. Thus you could also trim down your graph further and then a GTX 1060 is a solid choice (no large memory required and good speedup over the CPU).</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-16818' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-16818", "16818", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

			<p>Hi Tim,<br />
Many thanks!<br />
I have bought the components for below listed setup, aiming at having as much RAM as possible (&#8216;affordable&#8217; :).<br />
&#8211; intel xeon e5 1620 v4<br />
&#8211; supermicro x10 srl-f<br />
&#8211; kensington ddr4 32gb RAM (lrdimm) 2133 mhz<br />
-&gt; I plan to have in total 8 modules of these, in total 256 gb<br />
(it&#8217;s even possible to go up 375 based on the cpu, and 1 tb based on the motherboard)<br />
&#8211; 256 gb SSD<br />
&#8211; 1 tb HDD<br />
&#8211; msi geforce gtx 1060  6gb<br />
&#8211; noctua cooling<br />
&#8211; lepa power, 800W</p>
<p>Have seen <a href="https://event.cwi.nl/grades/2016/00-Leskovec-slides.pdf" rel="nofollow">https://event.cwi.nl/grades/2016/00-Leskovec-slides.pdf</a> also, seems like RAM is very relevant indeed 🙂<br />

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-17216">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-07-17T05:03:42+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-17216" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-07-17 at 05:03</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>It looks reasonable. With 28 lanes you will have a bit slower parallelism, but for 2 GPUs this bottleneck is not too large so you should still be fine; I guess you could expect a performance decrease of 10-15% for parallelism with 2 GPUs, which is okay. Otherwise, the specs are quite good for general computation, so if you want to use your CPU for other data science tasks this is a good choice. If you want to only do deep learning I might go for a slower CPU which has more lanes, but your current option is also not too bad.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-17216' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-17216", "17216", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-17336">

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-07-20T09:19:26+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-17336" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-07-20 at 09:19</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim,<br />
thanks for this great guide!<br />
It helped us to choose a deep learning server for tensorflow. We now use this rack machine <a href="https://www.cadnetwork.de/de/produkte/deep-learning" rel="nofollow">https://www.cadnetwork.de/de/produkte/deep-learning</a> but with four Tesla P100 instead of GTX 1080 Ti. But i don&#8217;t know if there is a huge difference between GTX and Tesla.<br />
I can confirm that 1-3 GPUs are used fully and the fourth GPU deliver about 40% of their performance. It could be a limitation of the PCIe Bus.</p>
<p>Thanks<br />
Thorsten</p>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-17353">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-07-20T17:21:56+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-17353" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-07-20 at 17:21</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Thorsten,<br />
that is interesting. I do not think that the 40% performance comes from PCIe issues alone, there might be another thing amiss. It cannot be some cooling issue since then you would see a performance degradation with other GPUs too. It would be interesting to know the reason for this. Let me know if you know more!</p>
<p>I am happy that my guide helped you to choose your server! Indeed, Tesla GPUs are only minimally better than GTX GPUs. The P100 is quite a bit better than the GTX 1080 Ti, but it also costs un-proportionally more. I think GTX 1080 Ti would have been more cost effective, but often these are not available for servers (NVIDIA has the policy to sell GTX cards only to consumers and Tesla cards to companies), so overall not a bad choice!</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-17353' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-17353", "17353", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/459d084307987c1601cec626220736ee?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/459d084307987c1601cec626220736ee?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">new_dl_learner</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-18497' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-18497", "18497", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to new_dl_learner'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-18668">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-08-07T21:21:47+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-18668" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-08-07 at 21:21</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Any of the CPUs that you listed is fine for deep learning with multiple GTX 1080 Tis. Choose the CPU according to your additional needs (preprocessing, other data science applications, other uses for your computer etc).</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-18668' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-18668", "18668", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-19094">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-08-13T20:35:06+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-19094" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-08-13 at 20:35</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Scaling within one computer is usually quite good. It still depends on the task, but you can expect a scaling from 2.5-3.9 for 4 GPUs depending on the software framework. The main drawback is that you have to add more special code with handles the parallelism. I recommend PyTorch for these kinds of tasks.</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="comment-19043">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/17b1a1bcb3a130116bd3ff71d052eff0?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/17b1a1bcb3a130116bd3ff71d052eff0?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Fernando</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-08-12T20:06:58+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-19043" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-08-12 at 20:06</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim,<br />
I followed your guide to understand better my needs in the computer I want to build for deep learning applications. However I have a question regarding the PCIes from the CPU. </p>
<p>Specifically, you mention that 40 PCIe are good to go for 4 GPUs, and also mentioned that every GPU communicates through 16 PCIe. In my mind if I would like to use the full potential of the GPUs I calculate I would need 16&#215;4 = 64 PCIe in my cpu to make this communication efficient.  I defintely misunderstood something about that but I would love to know how did you came to this conclusion. So the question basically is, how many PCIe does a CPU need?  do I need more than the ones that my GPUs demand? Is there any other component demanding this buses and therefore necessary to have even more?</p>
<p>Thanks in advance for the information.<br />
Best Regards,<br />
Fernando</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-19043' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-19043", "19043", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Fernando'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-19095">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-08-13T20:41:50+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-19095" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-08-13 at 20:41</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Generally the more the better and while PCIe speed is not that important if you only do parallelism among 4 GPUs it is still the easiest factor to improve (or decrease if you do not have the lanes) your performance, Generally only devices that are attached to the PCIe bus also draw lanes. For example, if you have a PCIe SSD, this will also affect the transfer speed to your GPUs. The setup in which your PCIe devices can run is specified by the motherboard. For example you might have a 40 lane CPU, but your motherboard only supports a 8x/8x/8x/8x setup for your PCIe devices, in this case GPUs, so that so GPU can utilize the full 16x speed. </p>
<p>In my research on GPU parallelism, it is usually the case that networking performance is the greatest bottleneck. So if you have few lanes, your algorithms are limited by how much they can scale. There are algorithms which go around this, but currently only Microsoft CNTK supports those algorithms (block momentum parallelism). So in general, having full 40 lanes (or rather 36 because one GPU with 16x speed is useless for deep learning if the other GPUs do not have 16x) is a good thing to have. On the other hand, such CPUs and motherboard that support 40 lanes are more expensive. From a cost efficiency perspective it might be better to go with fewer lanes — you might just get more bang for the buck.</p>
<p> The details are more complicated., but I hope this helps you to get an overview about the issue.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-19095' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-19095", "19095", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="comment-19102">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Nikolaos Tsarmpopoulos</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-08-14T01:54:22+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-19102" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-08-14 at 01:54</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Fernando,<br />
Also check if a PCIe switch (PLX) makes sense for the types of workloads you will be creating. </p>
<p>Some motherboards feature PLX chips, to allow for 4 GPUs operating at 16 lanes each. Typically, a PLX chip connects to the CPU using 16 lanes and handles 2 GPUs using 32 lanes. The paired cards can communicate with each other (DMA) via the PLX chip, i.e without consuming any PCIe lanes on the CPU and without being affected by any communication of the other pair of GPUs. </p>
<p>Also, note that PCIe uses separate lanes for downlink and separate for uplink, i.e  a device that supports 16 lanes, practically supports 16 lanes uplink and 16 lanes downlink, which can be used concurrently at full speed. This is beneficial, when the software library uses the following approach:</p>
<p>If the workload can be split into four processing stages that take about the same processing time and each stage can be handled by  a separate GPU, here&#8217;s how the data would be transferred at full speed: GPU1, GPU2 are attached to PLX1 and GPU3, GPU4 are attached to PLX2. The CPU uses 16 (uplink) lanes to send data to GPU1 via PLX1. At the same time (in parallel), GPU1 transfers the data it has just processed to GPU2  using 16 lanes via PLX1, GPU2 transfers data it has processed to the CPU  using 16 (downlink) lanes via PLX1, the CPU transfers this data to GPU3 using 16 (uplink) lanes via PLX2 and, similarly, GPU3 transfers data it has processed to GPU4 using 16 lanes via PLX2; GPU4 transfers the data it has processed back to the CPU using 16 (downlink) lanes via PLX2. You&#8217;ll notice that the GPUs make use of all 16 PCIe lanes available to each of them and the CPU also makes full use of 32 lanes (on both directions, up link and downlink).</p>
<p>In other words, your software can potentially make optimal use of 16-lane GPUs, via a CPU with 32 available PCIe lanes, if it only needs to send data from the CPU to the first GPU and receive data concurrently from the last GPU (in a sequence of GPUs, where each GPU does some processing and forwards the data to the next, for further processing) back to the CPU. The workload needs to be balanced, so that GPUs don&#8217;t wait too long.</p>
<p>I&#8217;m aware of two EATX motherboards with this feature and they are quite expensive and I&#8217;m not sure if the additional cost can be justified in terms of performance:</p>
<p>ASRock X99 WS-E/10G<br />
ASUS X99-E WS</p>
<p>Regards</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-19102' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-19102", "19102", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Nikolaos Tsarmpopoulos'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment even depth-3" id="comment-19116">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/459d084307987c1601cec626220736ee?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/459d084307987c1601cec626220736ee?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">new_dl_learner</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-08-14T13:32:02+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-19116" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-08-14 at 13:32</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-19116' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-19116", "19116", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to new_dl_learner'>Reply</a></div>

	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="comment-19123">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Nikolaos Tsarmpopoulos</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-08-14T17:02:17+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-19123" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-08-14 at 17:02</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>You will not be using SLI for deep learning. </p>
<p>I suggest that you ensure the  motherboard has enough PCI-E x16 slots for future expansion (as Tim has advised) and, if you are concerned about the number of lanes that will be available in a multi-GPU setup, you will need to download the manual (in pdf) of the motherboard you&#8217;re interested to buy and check the number of lanes according to the number of GPUs. </p>
<p>Without a PLX chip, depending on CPU lanes, the manual could say for example 2 GPUs at 16/16, 3 GPUs at 16/8/8, 4 GPUs at 8/8/8/8. A motherboard with PLX typically says 2 GPUs at 16/16, 3 GPUs at 16/16/16, 4 GPUs at 16/16/16/16.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-19123' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-19123", "19123", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Nikolaos Tsarmpopoulos'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="comment-19142">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Nikolaos Tsarmpopoulos</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-08-15T02:26:55+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-19142" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-08-15 at 02:26</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Indeed, Ryzen Threadripper comes with 64 lanes but my understanding is that some of these are reserved for other motherboard features, eg. chipset, M. 2 slots, etc. Check the following, as an example :</p>
<p>&#8220;4 x PCIe 3.0 x16 (single@x16, dual@x16/x16, triple@x16/x16/x8 mode)&#8221;<br />
Source : <a href="https://www.asus.com/Motherboards/ROG-Strix-X399-E-Gaming/specifications/" rel="nofollow">https://www.asus.com/Motherboards/ROG-Strix-X399-E-Gaming/specifications/</a></p>
<p>It advertises 4 x PCIe 3.0 x16 but then explains that the third GPU will be operating in x8 mode. Check the detailed specs in the manual before you buy a motherboard. </p>
<p>More lanes on the CPU is a good thing, but I suspect a single threadripper will support up to 3 GPUs at x16 and the server equivalent will support up to 6 GPUs at x16. </p>
<p>Parallelism is implemented differently in each library. Read through Tim&#8217;s articles, he has  provided some very helpful  info in his blog. Also, check each library for updates, as they are gradually improved by their respective authors.</p>
		</div>

		
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment even depth-5" id="comment-19427">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/459d084307987c1601cec626220736ee?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/459d084307987c1601cec626220736ee?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">new_dl_learner</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-08-18T17:29:55+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-19427" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-08-18 at 17:29</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>I asked Asus. Their reply is: </p>
<p>&#8221; I understand that want to the specifications of ROG Zenith Extreme and ROG Rampage VI Extreme. I know that as a computer user you want to customize your motherboard on your own preference to use it to its full potential. Let me continue assisting you with your concern.</p>
<p>For the two motherboard, it can support 4 x PCIe 3.0 x16 (x16, x16/x16, x16/x0/x16/x8, or x16/x8/x8/x8) at the same time since they didn&#8217;t share any bandwidth with any of the slots in the motherboard.&#8221;</p>
<p>Does that mean for these two motherboards, I can use four 1080Ti GPUs running at top speed at the same time?</p>
<p>In another reply, support mentioned that even I added a SSD or other PCI cards, the four GPU can still run at top speed.</p>
		</div>

		
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="comment-19443">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Nikolaos Tsarmpopoulos</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-08-18T21:26:55+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-19443" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-08-18 at 21:26</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>My understanding is that &#8220;4 x PCIe 3.0 x16 (x16, x16/x16, x16/x0/x16/x8, or x16/x8/x8/x8)&#8221; means:</p>
<p>1 GPU at x16, i.e at full speed<br />
2 GPUs at x16/x16, ie. both cards at full speed<br />
3 GPUs at x16/x16/x8, ie. two cards at full speed, the third at half speed,<br />
4 GPUs at x16/x8/x8/x8, ie. one card at full speed, three others at half speed.</p>
<p>Hence, a motherboard with the aforementioned capability does not support more than 2 GPUs at full speed.</p>
<p>I suggest you go back to the manufacturer and ask them to clarify their position. You can ask them, for example: if you attach 3 or 4 GPU cards and each card supports x16 bidirectional PCIe lanes, will the particular motherboard (of interest) allocate, to each card,  x16 dedicated bidirectional PCIe lanes, for concurrent transfer of data between the cards and the CPU?</p>
<p>If the motherboard supports 4 GPUs at full speed, it&#8217;s typically reported as x16/x16/x16/x16.</p>
		</div>

		
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment even depth-5" id="comment-19448">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-20373">

		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p>I checked NewEgg and indeed the X399 board&#8217;s specs show that they only support standard PCIe setups. However, if you look at the manufacturer&#8217;s homepage you will see that they indeed support full 64 PCIe lanes. I assume Newegg system is not updated yet to make a 16x/16x/16x/16x system available for the specs (it seems to be standardized). See for example <a href="https://www.gigabyte.com/Motherboard/X399-AORUS-Gaming-7-rev-10#kf" rel="nofollow">https://www.gigabyte.com/Motherboard/X399-AORUS-Gaming-7-rev-10#kf</a></p>

	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/459d084307987c1601cec626220736ee?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/459d084307987c1601cec626220736ee?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">new_dl_learner</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-08-31T17:51:42+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-20406" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-08-31 at 17:51</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Thanks Tim. I am a bit confused. From the specifications, there is no mention that it supports 4&#215;16, only 2&#215;16. The online menu states teh same thing. Am I reading it wrong?</p>
<p>    1. 2 x PCI Express x16 slots, running at x16 (PCIEX16_1, PCIEX16_2)<br />
    2. 2 x PCI Express x16 slots, running at x8 (PCIEX8_1, PCIEX8_2)<br />
    (The PCIEX16 and PCIEX8 slots conform to PCI Express 3.0 standard.)<br />
    3. 1 x PCI Express x16 slot, running at x4 (PCIEX4)<br />
    (The PCIEX4 slot conforms to PCI Express 2.0 standard.)</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-4" id="comment-20409">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-08-31T18:16:30+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-20409" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-08-31 at 18:16</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>You are right, I just for searching &#8220;lanes&#8221; and confused the 64 that I saw with specs for the motherboard. This is strange indeed, why do they not support the full 64 lanes? There was another blog post saying that this particular board would support that, but the manufacturer&#8217;s page clearly says it does not. I would get in touch with any manufacturer and just ask.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-20409' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-20409", "20409", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="comment-20415">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Nikolaos Tsarmpopoulos</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-08-31T20:29:22+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-20415" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-08-31 at 20:29</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>The following article suggests that only 56 out of 64 PCI-E lanes can be used for GPUs:</p>
<p><a href="http://www.guru3d.com/articles-pages/amd-ryzen-threadripper-1920x-review,4.html" rel="nofollow">http://www.guru3d.com/articles-pages/amd-ryzen-threadripper-1920x-review,4.html</a></p>
<p>I haven&#8217;t found a good explanation but I think it&#8217;s likely 4 lanes are used to connect the cpu to the X399 chipset. </p>
<p>PCIE switches  could be used (in future workstation motherboards)  to support  more (than 3) GPUs at x16 lanes.</p>
		</div>

		
		
	</article>

	<li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="comment-20452">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/459d084307987c1601cec626220736ee?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/459d084307987c1601cec626220736ee?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">new_dl_learner</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-09-01T15:34:42+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-20452" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-09-01 at 15:34</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Both Intel and AMD announced an overwhelming number of CPUs in August. Which CPU choice would be the best for ML/DL? At first, I considered the Threadripper but there is no related motherboard that supports the running of 4 GPU at x16x16x16x16 at the same time. I probably get two 1080Ti but I may need four later. Is there an advantageous in getting dual CPUs motherboard vs. getting 2 computers?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-20452' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-20452", "20452", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to new_dl_learner'>Reply</a></div>

	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="comment-20805">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/0fa9c5b9159961a12ae2428aac39fe51?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/0fa9c5b9159961a12ae2428aac39fe51?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="http://singhonline.info" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Sumeet Singh</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-09-07T21:46:20+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-20805" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-09-07 at 21:46</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>I recently built my system (<a href="https://pcpartpicker.com/user/Sumeet0/saved/#view=gFbvVn" rel="nofollow">https://pcpartpicker.com/user/Sumeet0/saved/#view=gFbvVn</a>). Firstly, I would recommend that you run your models on a cloud-platform first in order to get a sense of what type of hardware you want. For e.g. in my case, the importance of the CPU speed and RAM size is very minimal. All the work should be done by your GPU which in my experience was about 60x faster than if I ran my workload on the CPUs. However, IMO you should test your model out on a cloud-platform first (and take measurements) to get a sense for yourself.  Second, my first instinct was to go with AMD processors since those are cheaper &#8211; but within a day of researching I found out that you can&#8217;t find a reasonable AMD GPU that will control even 40 PCIE 3.0 x16 lanes. The intel Xeon E5s (and the new Silvers) will easily control 48 lanes per CPU. So that settled the debate for me. I also wanted to run my experiments continuously for several days &#8211; even weeks &#8211; therefore I preferred to go with server components. Thirdly, there were very few consumer (Intel chipset X99) motherboards that would simultaneously run 4 PCIE 3.0 cards at x16 speeds &#8211; and they all cost $600-$1000. Most X99 motherboards that have 4 or more PCIE x16 slots are only able to drive 2 of those at full x16 speeds. If you add more cards, their speed will drop down to x8. I found a few server motherboards (Intel chipset C612) that did drive 4 cards at x16 speed but at same or cheaper price-point (I ultimately bought an ASRock Rack EP2612 WS for $400). These three points made me decide to go with a server motherboard with two sockets, and Intel Xeon E5 CPU (I&#8217;m only using one at this time). I have the option to add upto 4 GPU cards all of which will be driven at x16 speed with at total of two Xeon E5 CPUs. I can run two cards with one CPU alone, and that&#8217;s what I intend to do in the near-term. If things work out and if there is a need, I&#8217;ll add one more CPU and two more GPU cards.</p>
<p>Since I have my model all setup and running on Google Cloud platform as well as on my own system, I have a very good comparison of speed and price. I will recover the price of my rig in 5-10 months if I run with one GPU and 3-6 months if I run with two (and even sooner with 4 GPUs).  This is based on running my computations at least 12 hours a day every day (which reasonable for my case). I did *not* factor in the fact that mine runs 1.5x to 3x faster than GCP.  I did factor in the cost of electricity though which is 40 cents / kWH for tier-3 and 27 cents / kWH for tier-2 consumption in my area. The biggest advantage for me though is that psychologically now I can leave my jobs running all the time without worrying about accruing costs (not to mention that GCP rations the use of resources and you have to convince them sometimes when you want to increase your resource consumption &#8211; which I find very perplexing). IMO this psychological advantage is a major plus when you&#8217;re experimenting/researching because you can never experiment too much. As a bonus, my system runs much faster which is priceless since I can iterate much faster. That said, you should do your own calculations &#8211; I may have made mistakes or overlooked something. Good luck with your project!</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-20805' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-20805", "20805", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Sumeet Singh'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-09-08T20:48:48+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-20861" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-09-08 at 20:48</a></time></p>		</header>

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="comment-20870">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/0fa9c5b9159961a12ae2428aac39fe51?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/0fa9c5b9159961a12ae2428aac39fe51?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="http://singhonline.info" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Sumeet Singh</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-09-09T00:09:48+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-20870" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-09-09 at 00:09</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim,<br />
    Glad you found my input useful. I found this entire forum more informative than anything else out there on the internet from a deep-learning DIY POV. Thanks again.</p>
<p>Here&#8217;s some detail about how my PSU calculations:<br />
1. After much deliberation I went for a 1000W PSU for driving the 1 CPU + 2 GPU configuration instead of a 850W PSU. The nominal consumption of this config would be 800 Watts (180 for motherboard based on ASRock-Rack&#8217;s &#8216;Prime95&#8217; performance-test results which their wonderful support-rep shared with me, 85W for CPU, 250W per GPU and 5Ws per fan(6) and 2.5W for liquid cooling pumps(2). The cheaper option was to go for a 850W power supply which as you can see would be running at at least 95% load. But since I want to run this config 24&#215;7, I want to give the PSU more head-room and hence opted to go for the 1000W PSU &#8211; which would still be too loaded for my comfort at 80% (I&#8217;d prefer 70% sustained load). But I&#8217;m already quite over budget, so I&#8217;ll stick with it.<br />
2. When/if I add 1 more CPU and 2 more 2GPUs &#8211; they will consume an additional 585W  &#8211; bringing the total nominal consumption to 1385W. Then I&#8217;ll buy another ~850W PSU &#8211; and run the two PSUs in parallel. This way I can scale up the system incrementally. I haven&#8217;t tested running with two PSUs yet, but I think it should work (despite what many people will say on the internet) as long as you choose the second PSU such that it will be okay with one not connecting the 24-pin and EPS/ATX12V mobo pins (some may not put any voltage on the line or suffer poor voltage regulation in this scenario, but I hope that my seasonic will do fine), one ensures that any given component is entirely powered by the same PSU and all the PSUs are grounded to the same ground. So for e.g. ensure that all the motherboard power sockets (one 24-pin and two 8-pin EPS/ATX12v sockets on my mobo) are powered by the same PSU. I&#8217;ll update this forum when/if I do that. An additional complication is that PSUs normally don&#8217;t start powering the output lines when you turn on their power switch. They do that only after they receive a control-signal from the motherboard (which it does when you hit the start button on the computer-case) which they receive on two pins on the 20-24 pin ATX power connector. You can fake that signal to the second PSU by shorting the correct two pins or you can buy a device that will relay the mobo&#8217;s signal to the second PSU. I haven&#8217;t tried this out yet, so don&#8217;t know for sure if it will work but people have done this successfully so I&#8217;m hopeful that I&#8217;ll be able to make it work.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-20870' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-20870", "20870", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Sumeet Singh'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>About getting a dual CPUs motherboard and have each CPU controlling two GPU at the same time&#8230; I have two questions: </p>
<p>1. If I only have one CPU installed, can the motherboard control 4 GPU at the same time at 16x16x16x16?</p>
<p>2. In case two CPUs are required to control 4 GPUs at the same time at 16x16x16x16, will DL software such as Tensorflow take care of the parallelism and distribution of workload of the GPUs automatically?</p>
		</div>
