	<li class="comment odd alt depth-4" id="comment-20872">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/0fa9c5b9159961a12ae2428aac39fe51?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/0fa9c5b9159961a12ae2428aac39fe51?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="http://singhonline.info" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Sumeet Singh</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-09-09T00:24:12+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-20872" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-09-09 at 00:24</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>1. I didn&#8217;t find any mobos that will do that &#8211; but I didn&#8217;t seriously consider anything that was north of $670. I suspect you could find this feature in higher-end server motherboards (much more expensive). You will also need a CPU that will drive at least 64 (i.e. 4*16) PCIe lanes. I know of high end Intel CPUs that will power 96 PCIE lanes but those are very expensive &#8211; I think the newest Intel Xeon Gold and Platinum series (maybe some higher-end Silvers too).<br />
2. Regarding whether Tensorflow will drive all 4 GPUs &#8211; that&#8217;s my working theory. I&#8217;m training on tensorflow and everything I&#8217;ve read and discussed with colleagues who work on DL tells me that that should work out of the box. I know from experience that if you train on CPUs, then tensorflow loads them all up (e.g. it would load all 32 cores on a 4 socket / 32-core HP server machine). I have read that it will do the same with GPUs. That&#8217;s my main reason for trying to build a 4GPU system as against two 2-GPU systems. I just ordered my second GPU and will know in 2 weeks whether this theory pans out. Hope to update this forum then but I suspect that Tim will already know the answer right away &#8211; therefore do ask him.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-20872' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-20872", "20872", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Sumeet Singh'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment even depth-5" id="comment-20878">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Nikolaos Tsarmpopoulos</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-09-09T01:19:31+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-20878" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-09-09 at 01:19</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Latest (Purley), high-end Xeons support 48 lanes per CPU, hence 96 lanes would only be supported from a dual CPU config. These CPUs feature up to 3 Ultra Path Interconnect links, for CPU-to-CPU communication, at 9.6 and 10.4 GT/s.<br />
Source:<br />
<a href="https://software.intel.com/en-us/articles/intel-xeon-processor-scalable-family-technical-overview" rel="nofollow">https://software.intel.com/en-us/articles/intel-xeon-processor-scalable-family-technical-overview</a></p>
<p>That is expected to be similar in performance with the older interconnect, QPI. Source:<br />
<a href="https://www.nextplatform.com/2015/05/26/intel-lets-slip-broadwell-skylake-xeon-chip-specs/" rel="nofollow">https://www.nextplatform.com/2015/05/26/intel-lets-slip-broadwell-skylake-xeon-chip-specs/</a></p>
<p>More information on QuickPath Interconnect and its throughput (about 25Mbps), here:<br />
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intel_QuickPath_Interconnect" rel="nofollow">https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intel_QuickPath_Interconnect</a></p>
<p>I haven&#8217;t been able to confirm whether,  in a dual CPU config, Windows:</p>
<p>1) recognises that a particular process  or thread utilises a particular GPU that is attached to the PCIe lanes of a particular CPU,<br />
2) assigns the aforementioned thread to the CPU where the GPU is attached</p>
<p>If someone can help find information on this, please share it here.</p>
<p>If this is not feasible, then its possible that dual CPU configurations may be slower than a single  CPU motherboard that utilises a PCIe switch (PLX).</p>
		</div>

		
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="comment-20879">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/ad8bbf0e30f89bf79f0362afa8c0f04a?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/ad8bbf0e30f89bf79f0362afa8c0f04a?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Michael</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-09-09T01:34:04+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-20879" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-09-09 at 01:34</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>***will DL software such as Tensorflow take care of the parallelism and distribution of workload of the GPUs automatically?***</p>
<p>Of course not. You have to manually design your code to run on different GPUs. Usually you would break up your data batches and assign them to individual GPUs in a &#8220;multi-tower&#8221; fashion. If you don&#8217;t understand these things, I recommend learning them before spending any money on hardware. It&#8217;s like wondering how big of an engine to get in a car before you learned how to drive. Just get started with whatever hardware you have at hand. By the time you know how to build large complex models, any specific hardware suggestions given here will likely become obsolete.</p>
		</div>

		
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment even depth-5" id="comment-20880">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/0fa9c5b9159961a12ae2428aac39fe51?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/0fa9c5b9159961a12ae2428aac39fe51?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="http://singhonline.info" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Sumeet Singh</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-09-09T01:50:36+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-20880" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-09-09 at 01:50</a></time></p>		</header>

But you&#8217;re right, this is perhaps not what he meant.</p>

				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/459d084307987c1601cec626220736ee?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/459d084307987c1601cec626220736ee?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">new_dl_learner</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-09-29T04:31:23+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-21652" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-09-29 at 04:31</a></time></p>		</header>

	<li class="comment even depth-5" id="comment-21658">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/61163e9aac1c0261506c0ffa62184b50?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/61163e9aac1c0261506c0ffa62184b50?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="http://singhonline.info" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Sumeet Singh</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-09-29T06:37:14+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-21658" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-09-29 at 06:37</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Yeah, my dual-GPU configuration has been up and running for a couple of weeks now. It worked exactly as expected with Tensorflow. I&#8217;ve coded a synchronous towers architecture as described in the CIFAR10 tutorial. I got about 70-80% speed-up (speed went up from 1.25 s/batch to 0.7s). I suppose I could get closer to 100% speed-up if I coded a asynchronous architecture &#8211; which I would do if I got more GPUs. Please note that you have to tell tensorflow to place the operators on a specific GPU &#8211; and you can do so easily by building multiple copies of your graph and place each on a separate GPU (see the CIFAR10 tutorial). Therefore from the beginning try to code your graph such that it can be easily replicated with all subsequent instances reusing variables created by the first instance. Tensorflow will automatically place the variables on the CPU (provided you specify soft-placement in the session config.) and take care of transferring their values to and from the multiple GPUs. All you need to do is specify device-placement and Tensorflow will do the rest &#8211; i.e. it will deploy your graph-code to the multiple GPUs and CPU, transfer data back and forth between GPU and RAM and coordinate the execution of the entire graph spread-up over CPUs, GPUs and RAM. It takes very little effort compared to how much work it does. Coding a asynchronous model on the other hand, will take a bit more coding. Oh and one more thing &#8211; be sure to use queues and queue-runners for reading data asynchronously from the disks so that the data is ready in RAM when the graph needs it. You&#8217;ll also need to ensure that your BIOS is setup properly &#8211; for e.g. I had to turn on the &#8216;Above 4G Decoding&#8217; option on my motherboard. I also noticed that if I turn off ECC, then the speed actually slows down contrary to what I had expected. I also notices a &#8216;warm-up&#8217; period of about 30-45 minutes after boot-up when the graph runs 3x slower &#8211; not sure why (maybe the time it takes for OS to load inodes into cache?) but now I just suspend the machine instead of shutting it down.</p>
<p>Hope this helps.</p>
		</div>

		
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-5" id="comment-21676">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-20590">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-09-04T03:31:54+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-20590" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-09-04 at 03:31</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>More cores are always better, but it is also a question of how much you want to pay. I think CPU cores = 2x GPU might be a bit much for the high range. If you get 3 GPUs a 4 core is still sufficient. If you have 4 GPUs I a 6 core would also be sufficient. I would however not recommend a 2 core for 3 GPUs. 4 cores for a 4 GPU system is borderline, as it will be okay if you just run deep learning but it might become a bottleneck as you run any other application in addition. So choose according to your budget and according to your needs.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-20590' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-20590", "20590", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-20803">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/0fa9c5b9159961a12ae2428aac39fe51?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/0fa9c5b9159961a12ae2428aac39fe51?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="http://singhonline.info" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Sumeet Singh</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-09-07T21:01:53+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-20803" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-09-07 at 21:01</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hello Tim,<br />
    Thanks for this wonderful resource for Deep Learning DIYers. Based on this and several other resources on the internet, I have built my first A.I. &#8216;rig&#8217; on which I am training a Image Captioning/Transcription/Translation Neural Network  &#8211; Im2Latex: to convert Latex generated images back into the original latex markup. I have an convnet of about 14M parameters and my Conditioned-Attentive-LSTM has about 8M parameters. I&#8217;ve been running this on Google-Cloud-Platform before I built my own &#8216;rig&#8217; and am happy to report that my rig with one GPU trains almost twice as fast as the one with one virtual CPU on Google (i.e. half a K80). I think I can make mine a little faster with some BIOS settings &#8211; but am happy with it so far. Am ordering another 1080 Ti soon. Oh yes, I haven&#8217;t yet overclocked my GPU but it naturally runs at over 1900 MHz on load with the help of Nvidia X Server Settings app on Linux (temperature is 50 degrees C with inbuilt liquid cooling with the CPU at 30 degrees C)<br />
    In the spirit of giving back to the community, here&#8217;s my parts list: <a href="https://pcpartpicker.com/user/Sumeet0/saved/#view=gFbvVn" rel="nofollow">https://pcpartpicker.com/user/Sumeet0/saved/#view=gFbvVn</a>. Also, while I do have a copy of Windows 10 I decided to use Ubuntu GNOME 16.04 LTS &#8211; mostly because I&#8217;m very comfortable with Unix like operating systems since I&#8217;ve worked on/with those for over 20 years. One problem with Linux though is that most software utilities for overclocking and system monitoring run on Windows. As you &#8211; and other resources on internet &#8211; say, the best way to overclock a GPU on linux is to flash the BIOS. At the least that&#8217;s not convenient &#8211; especially for a newbie.</p>
<p>    Thanks again for this wonderful resource.</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-20860">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-09-08T20:47:14+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-20860" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-09-08 at 20:47</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Thanks for your feedback — this is very useful for everybody here!</p>
<p>Overclocking does not increase deep learning performance by much, but it helps to squeeze the last bit of performance out of the GPU. I think you can expect something between 0-3% performance increase from that. Might sound like not much, but put into numbers, this means that if your GPU runs 24/7 this can be up to 40 minutes per day extra compute time.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-20860' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-20860", "20860", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment even depth-3" id="comment-20874">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/0fa9c5b9159961a12ae2428aac39fe51?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/0fa9c5b9159961a12ae2428aac39fe51?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name"><a href="http://singhonline.info" class="comment-author-link" rel="external nofollow" itemprop="url">Sumeet Singh</a></span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-09-09T00:29:56+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-20874" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-09-09 at 00:29</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Thanks. Is good to know that I&#8217;m not missing out too much by not overclocking (and that my choosing linux over Windows 10 didn&#8217;t cause me a major performance disadvantage &#8211; since I could have very easily overclocked Windows). Now I can focus on training my 23M parameters 🙂</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-20874' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-20874", "20874", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Sumeet Singh'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="comment-20950">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/f188e736d6e0eda2d6a8a700369192fd?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/f188e736d6e0eda2d6a8a700369192fd?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Reagan</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-09-11T00:05:38+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-20950" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-09-11 at 00:05</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Tim,</p>
<p>What do you think about using the Xeon E-5 1620v4 instead of the i7-5930K for a quadGPU machine? The Xeon is half the price of the i7, also has 40 PCIe lane support, and has a higher memory bandwidth and is the same socket type.</p>
<p>Is there something about server chips I&#8217;m not seeing that would interfere with me using this chip on an X99 mobo?</p>
<p>Also, is there a difference between DDR3 and DDR4 RAM that is meaningful to deep learning?</p>
<p>Great blog!</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-20950' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-20950", "20950", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Reagan'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-21001">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-09-12T08:18:50+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-21001" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-09-12 at 08:18</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>The Xeon is definitely a better option here. It has less cache and fewer cores, but this should only have a minor influence. The chip should work normally on a X99 mobo. For deep learning there is a very minimal difference between DDR3 and DDR4. Probably the performance difference would be a few percent which should not be noticeable unless you run the GPUs 24/7. However, if you want performance for a 4 GPU setup, then the first thing you should look into is cooling, in particular, liquid cooling. Other factors are insignificant.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-21001' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-21001", "21001", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-09-26T10:58:29+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-21526" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-09-26 at 10:58</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>There were some deep learning desktops from other companies, but I cannot find them on Google. I think some of them might be buried in the comment section somewhere, try to search that. Other than that, you could also just buy a high-end gaming PC. Basically, there is no difference between a good deep learning machine and a high-end gaming machine. So buying a high-end gaming machine is a perfect choice if you want to avoid building your own machine. I would still recommend giving building your own machine a shot — it is much easier than it looks!</p>
		</div>

Two main concerns are: 1) there are user reviews saying that under Linux, there are bugs with PCIe. Some mentioned that there is no noticeable difference between x8 and x16. I guess they talked about the frame rate for gaming.  Not sure if this conclusion applies to deep learning.  Any idea?</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment even depth-2" id="comment-21729">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/459d084307987c1601cec626220736ee?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/459d084307987c1601cec626220736ee?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">new_dl_learner</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-09-30T15:47:55+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-21729" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-09-30 at 15:47</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hello, I have spent too much time on hardware selections. It is driving me nuts. I need some help. My current laptop computer is almost 10 years old. I am building a desktop replacement. I also want to use it for DL/ML research. As far as I know, latest CPUs such as the i7 7700K, i9 7900X and Threadripper do not support PCIe 3.0 16x16x16x16. Motherboards that support such quad PCIe 3.0 at 16x each only support older CPUs with LGA2011-v3 socket or the Xeon E5. These CPUs are at similar or higher price range than the ones mentioned above. Moreover, they are running at lower speed. I guess the dilemma is: Spending more on older technology for quad PCIe 3.0 16x16x16x16 vs. spending less on the latest CPU that only support two PCIe 3.0 running 16&#215;16. Any suggestion appreciated. Thanks.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-21729' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-21729", "21729", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to new_dl_learner'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="comment-21740">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Nikolaos Tsarmpopoulos</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-09-30T19:03:28+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-21740" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-09-30 at 19:03</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Dear new_dl_learner,<br />
The X99 motherboards with PLX chips (for quad PCI-E 3.0 x16) are no longer produced, they are out of stock in most places, hence, no delima here. As Tim has explained earlier, the CPU is not as important for Deep Neural Networks as the GPU. Also PCI-E 3.0 x8 is not much worse than x16. If you start with anything less than a Quad GPU setup, by the time you need faster data throughput new CPUs and GPUs will be available, sporting PCI-E 4.0, so you won&#8217;t be limited by PCI-E 3.0 x8.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-21740' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-21740", "21740", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Nikolaos Tsarmpopoulos'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment even depth-4" id="comment-21747">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/459d084307987c1601cec626220736ee?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/459d084307987c1601cec626220736ee?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">new_dl_learner</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-10-01T00:42:55+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-21747" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-10-01 at 00:42</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Dear Nikolaos,<br />
Thank you for the useful information.  My laptop computer is i7 2.66GHz (8GB 1067 MHz DDR3, NVIDIA GeForce GT 330M with 512 MB GDDR 3). Will that be sufficient for me to use it to learn about Deep Learning and do some work in this area before PCI-E 4.0 comes out? If not, what hardware do you recommend during this transition period?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-21747' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-21747", "21747", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to new_dl_learner'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="comment-21749">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Nikolaos Tsarmpopoulos</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-10-01T03:01:37+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-21749" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-10-01 at 03:01</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>You can start experimenting with Deep Learning using the CPU of your existing laptop and a compatible library. For example, Tensorflow is available for CPU. Start with the basics. </p>
<p>When you reach the point where you need faster compute capability, depending on your budget, you can put together a PC. At that time, you will know what the requirements of the software and of the models that you are using will be, so choosing the right hardware will be much easier than it is today for you. </p>
<p>No need to rush it, it doesn&#8217;t help building a supercomputer today if you don&#8217;t know how to use it for deep learning. By the time you need one, new technologies will be available and you&#8217;ll be in a better position to choose wisely.</p>
		</div>

		
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment even depth-5" id="comment-21763">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/459d084307987c1601cec626220736ee?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/459d084307987c1601cec626220736ee?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">new_dl_learner</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-10-01T14:07:17+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-21763" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-10-01 at 14:07</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Thanks for your suggestion. When can we build computers using PCI-E 4.0 parts?</p>
<p>Yes, Tim mentioned that CPU is not that important but it was in 2015. Not sure about now. Some people mentioned that DL/ML applications such as Tensorflow take advantage of multi-core, multi-thread CPU and recommended getting at least 8 cores. My laptop is showing signs of failing. Besides DL/ML, I also run engineering applications that would benefit from higher clock CPUs.</p>
<p>One concern I have is that in the GPU selection thread, somebody asked about the possibility of doing DL on computer with a Nvidia 750M GPU. Tim mentioned that &#8220;So a GDDR5 750M will be sufficient for running most deep learning models. If you have the DDR3 version, then it might be too slow for deep learning (smaller models might take a day; larger models a week or so).&#8221; Mine is an older laptop with GPU using 512MB GDDR3. So, it will take days to train even smaller models?</p>
		</div>

		
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="comment-21770">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/4cd3595dc3f96a219d6712dcfd478242?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Nikolaos Tsarmpopoulos</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-10-01T18:17:17+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-21770" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-10-01 at 18:17</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>PCIe 4.0 is reportedly due to be rolled out in early 2018. That means new CPUs, new motherboards, new GPUs. NVIDIA is likely to lead with the announcement of its volta GPUs, to be seen.</p>
<p>My understanding is that no matter how fast GPU and CPU you purchase, there will always be a model that takes days to train and another that&#8217;s too big to fit in your GPU&#8217;s memory, which is why nvidia sells Quadro and Tesla. </p>
<p>Hence, I think the bottom line is: use whatever system you can afford and justify for your education right now. By the time you need faster hardware, you&#8217;ll know what you need, what you need it for and what options are available at that time.</p>
		</div>

		
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="comment-24349">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a459075a72e478f3ca568c2a5a34314a?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a459075a72e478f3ca568c2a5a34314a?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Abdelrahman</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2017-11-25T22:13:07+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-24349" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2017-11-25 at 22:13</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim,</p>
<p>Thanks for the great article. I am planning to use 6850k for my deep learning box, with 1070 Ti, 1080, or 1080 Ti GPUs, planning to extend to 4 GPUs later.</p>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-32737">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2018-04-23T18:49:48+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-32737" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2018-04-23 at 18:49</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>It is mostly loading data and an SSD is only required for performance if you have very large input sizes. If you do not have that, you will gain no performance over using a spinning hard disk. However, besides DL you use the SSD for many other tasks, so if you have the money I would definitely go for SSD drives to make I/O work more comfortable.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-32737' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-32737", "32737", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-40722">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/e5944b7130c0c31b2d5ac6df0060b9db?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/e5944b7130c0c31b2d5ac6df0060b9db?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Angel G</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2018-08-03T19:35:59+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-40722" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2018-08-03 at 19:35</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim,  I&#8217;ve re read the comments and few questions rouse in my head.<br />
 1. How it has been decided that 16-bit floating point numbers have enough precision for the neural networks &#8211; doesn&#8217;t it reduce their recognition abilities ?<br />
2. In 2010, I trained a C++ coded CNN. I&#8217;ve noticed that if I run in more than 4 parallel threads it&#8217;s learning rate decreased (required more epochs) . The weights were updated concurrently by the threads using non-blocking(mostly)  atomic cmpxchg64 instructions. I&#8217;ve skipped all development until now.<br />
Now massive parallel architectures are used (in GPU) so I wonder how do they update/combine the weights in parallel without destroying the learning rate ?<br />
3. Does CUDA vs AMD matter if I implement the neural networks in the old school manner &#8211; without any SDK &#8211; Open GL shading language with floating-point textures.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-40722' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-40722", "40722", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Angel G'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-40855">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2018-08-06T17:51:58+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-40855" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2018-08-06 at 17:51</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Angel. Here some answers, suggestions:<br />
1. From my experience, 16-bit results are close to 32-bit results, but I did not do thorough testing. There is research that points in both directions (<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1511.04561" rel="nofollow">in my research </a>I show that 8-bit gradients and activities work fine for AlexNet on ImageNet). I think if you want to learn, experiment, prototype and do practical work, 16-bit networks are alright. For academic work which requires state-of-the-art results 16-bit methods might have insufficient precision.<br />
2. Again, you might want to read <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1511.04561" rel="nofollow">my paper</a> for an overview of synchronous methods. The best methods compress the gradient and send them across the network to other GPUs where everything is aggregated and synchronized for a valid gradient. Such methods work quite well. There are other asynchronous methods championed by Google, but they also suffer from the problems that you describe.<br />
3. Implementing in CUDA is much better because they have better tooling, a better community, and thus better support. However, we need more AMD code because it is not healthy if NVIDIA has more than 90% of the market share in deep learning hardware. If you expect that your software will be useful for many thousand others, AMD might be a good, ethical choice. If it is for a personal project which may be useful to dozens, go with NVIDIA CUDA.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-40855' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-40855", "40855", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-44021">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2018-10-10T19:52:27+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-44021" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2018-10-10 at 19:52</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>This blog post is a bit outdated. It seems that TensorFlow is using pinned host memory by default, which means that you are already able to do asynchronous GPU transfers. While I stressed it in the blog post, its actually not that big of a bottleneck for most cases. For large video data, it could have a good impact.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-44021' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-44021", "44021", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

			<p>So here is the build I am considering. I should say that my main goal is to learn deep learning as quickly as possible. I am planning on doing as many kaggle competitions (open and closed) as possible Can you please help?</p>
<p>GPU: 1 x GTX 1080 Ti + 1 x RTX 2080 Ti (I might add a third card depending on your recommendation)<br />
Cooling: Liquid (open loop)<br />
PSU: RM1000x ( I might go abit higher in terms of OC quality (higher tier) and power delivery (targetting 60-80% at full load for best efficiency, where expected maximum load is ~800W). I am considering getting an AT1200x instead</p>
<p>As for CPU and RAM, there are 2 options:<br />
Option A: (Higher CPU clock but Dual Channel Memory)<br />
CPU: 9900k with 16MB smart cache (not sure but estimated @~5.2-5.5GHz for all 8 cores)<br />
Motherboard: Asus Maximus XI Extreme<br />
RAM: 64 GB (OC to 4000MHz+)</p>
<p>Option B : (Quad Memory Channel but Lower CPU Clock and I think overkill core count)<br />
CPU: 7920x  with 16.5 MB cache (not sure but estimated @~4.7GHz for all 12 cores)<br />
Motherboard: Rampage VI Extreme<br />
RAM: 64 or 128 GB (depending on your recommendation) again (OC to 4000MHz+)</p>
<p>I really like option A because of CPU clock speed. However, if I go with option A, then I will be using a cloud service for large datasets. The advantages of option B is the option to expand memory to 128 GB and the quad channel. Also, not sure about the difference between the two motherboards in terms of multi-gpu pcie lane allocation (I don&#8217;t understand the specs)</p>
<p>So, do you have any comments on the builds?<br />
Which one would you pick?<br />
Where is(are) the bottleneck here?</p>
<p>Thanks</p>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-4" id="comment-44143">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2018-10-12T09:43:05+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-44143" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2018-10-12 at 09:43</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>For +2 GPUs choose the Rampage VI motherboard; if you settle at 2 GPUs then Maximum XI. I would also go for two GPUs with the same chipset, either GTX 1080 Ti or RTX 2080 Ti so you will be able to parallelize across GPUs. I would get RAM with a lower clock — there is almost no gain for OC RAM and it is quite expensive.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-44143' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-44143", "44143", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-5" id="comment-44147">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2018-10-12T10:07:54+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-44147" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2018-10-12 at 10:07</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>I think 32GB is good, but sometimes you need to write cumbersome memory efficient code — with 64GB you can avoid that most of the time. 128 GB is a bit overkill for most competitions I think. If you have 64GB and it is not enough then you can always spend some time optimizing your code. If you still find your RAM lacking you can also just order more RAM. I would start with 32 GB or 64 GB — you can always order more!</p>
<p>A good RAM clock will not help you pre-process much faster. This video puts it quite well: <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D_Yt4vSZKVk" rel="nofollow">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D_Yt4vSZKVk</a></p>
		</div>

		
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->

</ul><!-- .children -->

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-44222">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2018-10-13T13:38:37+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-44222" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2018-10-13 at 13:38</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Thanks for your prompt response!</p>
<p>Just a quick clarification on your reply earlier,  I am planning on expanding later to 4 x 2080 TI. So, in this case I would go with Rampage VI Extreme &amp; (9920x or 9940x depending on price) and 2x2080ti. However, the issue is that I am concerned about the number of lanes going into GPUs. Both of these CPUs has 44 lanes, which is not enough to run 16 lanes on each GPU. Does it matter (16 vs 8 lanes)?</p>
<p>Another option is to go with threadripper which has 60 lanes (again not enough for 4&#215;16), but at least I might be able to run 3&#215;16 + 1&#215;8.</p>
<p>Also, you addressed this before, but I just want to confirm, CPU clock is irrelevant. Basically, I am not losing anything by going down from 9900k @ 5.3 GHz to 9920x @ 4.7 GHz to even a threadripper 2950x @ 4.4GHz. right?</p>
<p>Also, is there a difference between using an intel cpu vs amd?  (Sorry if this seems like a very broad question, but I&#8217;m not sure which way to go; intel has higher clocks and worst value-for-money, while amd has better value and more lanes)</p>
<p>Thank you again for being patient with me! Choosing the build components has been a steep learning curve for me. I am really glad that I found someone to point me to the right direction.</p>
		</div>

	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/b1037ba60ce33d523d429242eefbe8e9?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/b1037ba60ce33d523d429242eefbe8e9?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Mohammed Sarraj</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2018-10-21T07:35:33+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-44838" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2018-10-21 at 07:35</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hello Tim,<br />
I am adding these questions to the list of questions mentioned above (just a reminder):</p>
<p>+  I am going with a 2x 2080ti setup for now, and I am going to be expanding in the future to 4x 2080ti. However, would I benefit from using NVLinks? If so, how is it going to impact things? For example, would I be able to double my memory? Would it it affect other bottlenecks?</p>
<p>+  Since, I am going to be using 4x 2080Tis and probably a 9920x (depending on your answer for the questions from the previous post), I am expecting to use about 1800 Watts. However, I couldn&#8217;t find any PSUs that are with that capacity. I am looking for a PSU with low voltage ripple (for overclocking purposes). However, I wasn&#8217;t able to find even a single 1800 Watt PSU in the market. What is your advice in this case? I&#8217;ve heard of the Add2PSU component ( <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=erHoq3DbwVA" rel="nofollow">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=erHoq3DbwVA</a> ). However, I am not sure how safe it is to use multiple PSUs on a single PC. What do you think?</p>
<p>Thanks</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-44838' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-44838", "44838", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Mohammed Sarraj'>Reply</a></div>

	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-44986">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2018-10-23T09:14:44+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-44986" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2018-10-23 at 09:14</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>(1) NVLink on RTX cards is currently limited to two GPUs only and it will not help you too much in that scenario for data parallelism. For model parallelism, it could help, but currently, there are no models and code that profit from that. So it might be useful in the future, but not right now.</p>
<p>(2) 1800 Watts is a bit much. You need about 275 per GPU and another 300 for the CPU which is about 1400 Watts. If you get a 1300 to 1600 Watts PSU you should be fine I think even if you overclock. There are some nice ones from EVGA; you can find them easily if you search newegg.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-44986' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-44986", "44986", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="comment-46559">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/e415d32515656cad0d8fb48e2f7298b3?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/e415d32515656cad0d8fb48e2f7298b3?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Haider Alwasiti</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2018-11-16T01:36:47+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-46559" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2018-11-16 at 01:36</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Your statement in 2015, is it still true with current frameworks? I used pytorch with fastai and all threads and cores are maxed out usually ( image training in resnet34) :</p>
<p>Needed number of CPU cores<br />
When I train deep neural nets with three different libraries I always see that one CPU thread is at 100% (and sometimes another thread will fluctuate between 0 and 100% for some time). And this immediately tells you that most deep learning libraries – and in fact most software applications in general – just use a single thread. This means that multi-core CPUs are rather useless</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-46559' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-46559", "46559", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Haider Alwasiti'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-46711">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2018-11-18T11:46:06+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-46711" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2018-11-18 at 11:46</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>I think it is partially true. Preprocessing still dominates CPU needs. If you do preprocessing while training you need more cores. However, you could also preprocess your data in bulk before training.</p>
<p>However, some frameworks also use quite a bit CPU in the background like TensorFlow. I do not have the deepest insights into this, but TensorFlows graph pipeline is quite sophisticated and might need more CPU cores to process efficiently. The benefits for PyTorch would mainly lie with background loader Threads.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-46711' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-46711", "46711", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-48891">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/aeeda603cb4059094ae0611678659a1a?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/aeeda603cb4059094ae0611678659a1a?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Brendan</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2018-12-14T07:23:56+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-48891" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2018-12-14 at 07:23</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hey Tim,</p>
<p>First I want to thank you for this blog, it teaches a man to fish rather than giving him a fish as the old aphorism goes.</p>
<p>I have a few questions related to hardware that I&#8217;m a little unclear on, and also that are pertinent as PCIe 4.0 slots are rumored soon. First a little background on my build, I&#8217;m going to be building a computer primarily for statistical computing before I begin a doctorate program in stats/applied math. This means it will first need to be good at serial processing which is why I&#8217;m entertaining CPUs that are overkill in terms of CNN needs (the type of neural networks I will be using). I do want it to be able to do CNN work as I am intrigued by and play around with that somewhat.</p>
<p>1) I&#8217;m looking between an i7 8700K and an i9 9900K. I was entertaining an AMD ryzen 2700X but I realized that I shouldn&#8217;t as that has a max number of lanes of 20, correct?</p>
<p>2) Should I wait for my build until PCIe 4.0 motherboards are released? All I see now are rumors but it is rumored that they will be released next year in 2019. Given that DMA is the main bottleneck here, wouldn&#8217;t it be beneficial to wait until PCIe 4.0 is available (31.508 GB/s more than doubles the performance of PCIe 3.0)?</p>
<p>3) If that is true, then would RAM memory speed actually be a factor? I don&#8217;t think so, as you stated your current setup gets over 50 GB/s for the RAM which would still be above the DMA bottleneck of PCIe 4.0</p>
<p>4) Even if PCIe 4.0 motherboards are released in 2019, they would still be compatible with the processors I mentioned above, correct? If so, then building my rig now wouldn&#8217;t hamper me as I could just upgrade the motherboard once PCIe 4.0 compatible motherboards are available. Is that right or are we unsure if there will be LGA1151 compatible PCIe 4.0 motherboards?</p>
<p>5) I&#8217;m looking at a GTX 1080 ti and a RTX 2080 ti for my GPU. I think the RTX 2080 ti is a little outside my price range, but I would be debating between a GTX 1080 ti with a water cooling block setup or an RTX 2080 ti without water cooling. Which do you think will likely perform better as the temperatures will likely hamper performance of the GPU with the stock fans?</p>
<p>Thank you again for this post and for your continued answering of questions in the comments. If you have time, I would greatly appreciate a response!</p>
<p>Cheers,<br />
Brendan</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-49145">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2018-12-18T11:47:30+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-49145" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2018-12-18 at 11:47</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Brendan,</p>
<p>1) The Ryzen 2700X would be fine for up to two GPUs. If you want more GPUs I would look for a different CPU.<br />
2) PCIe 4.0 will not help much with deep learning and I would not wait for it.<br />
3) Memory speed is not much of a factor. I would just buy cheap RAM.<br />
4) This is determined by the motherboard. For PCIe 2.0 -> PCIe 3.0 we saw that the new motherboards often supported only the most recent CPU sockets. I believe this could be the case for the new PCIe 4.0 boards too.<br />
5) A single RTX 2080 Ti on air should be fine. You should see a slight performance decrease but it is still faster than the GTX 1080 Ti. If you do not have the money for an RTX 2080 Ti, both a water- or air-cooled GTX 1080 Ti should be a great option.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-49145' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-49145", "49145", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-49058">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/cfb921722b7b2c4cb38b52317c009957?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/cfb921722b7b2c4cb38b52317c009957?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">david</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2018-12-16T13:36:38+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-49058" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2018-12-16 at 13:36</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi, I am a Computer Scientist but I have not done any project on DL before. Maybe later I will buy RTX Titan but not in the next three months. Could you please let me know the following?</p>
<p>1. Given a model and if I want to see how it behaves under different initial parameters, will there be a problem if my desktop has two GPU of different kinds (e.g. one GTX 1060 and one RTS 2080/2080Ti or RTS Titan)? </p>
<p>2. Am I correct that only when I do parallel training of the same network with the same set of initial parameters will I need to have GPU of the same model?</p>
<p>3. Those 20&#215;0 cards have Tensor Cores in addition to CUDA Cores. Are Tensor Cores helpful in speeding up the training in Tensorflow? What else is it good to buy RTX card now rather than GTX card?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-49058' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-49058", "49058", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to david'>Reply</a></div>

	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-49586">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2018-12-27T16:35:11+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-49586" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2018-12-27 at 16:35</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>1. You can use different GPUs for different networks. However, if you want to parallelize a single network across both GPUs they need to have the same chip, for example 2x RTX 2080 or 2x GTX 1060.<br />
2. Yes, this is correct.<br />
3. You will benefit from Tensor Cores in TensorFlow, but as far as I understand not all features of RTX cards are implemented yet and your Tensor Core code will be fast, but will not run at 100% speed. I think PyTorch has much better support for RTX cards, but it is just a matter of time until full features are implemented in TensorFlow.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-49586' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-49586", "49586", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim, Thanks for the great guild. I found you blog super helpful when I built my first box in 2016. And it is still worthwhile to come back for updates.</p>
<p>One question about GPU RAM. I am getting serious about CV competitions on Kaggle. And that entails using big pre-trained networks like Xception. I have a 1080 ti and use batch size of 16 for inputs image of size 256,256. On software side, I am using tensorflow.keras (mostly for multiprocessing augmentation) and raw tensorflow. </p>
<p>My computer would freeze every now and then so I have to force restart. And even before it freezes, it would get slower by epochs. First epoch would be 90s, next would be 120s and it just gets worse.  It also gets slower and more likely to freeze as I experiment more network structure by defining more models(clear_session() or tf.reset_default_graph() does not help)</p>
<p>I use &#8220;top&#8221; to monitor cpu/RAM, either of which seems to be the problem. I use something like &#8220;watch -n0.1 nvidia-smi&#8221; to monitor GPU. GPU utilization stays above 90%. But it does not really tell me much about memory as tensorflow automatically allocates almost of the GPU memory at start. I tried tf.configproto() to limit GPU memory used by tensorflow without much luck.</p>
<p>Do you have any suggestion as to how to diagnose this issue? Thanks in advance and happy holidays!!</p>
<p>Best,</p>
<p>Zhenlan,</p>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-49582">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2018-12-27T16:29:28+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-49582" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2018-12-27 at 16:29</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>It sounds like you have a memory leak somewhere in your code. First, check if you run out of CPU RAM and your computer is swapping RAM to disk. If that does not help try to debug TensorFlow further. If that does not help it could help to install the newest NVIDIA drivers. If this does not help try PyTorch and see if that works for you (PyTorch is much easier to debug in these cases). Good luck!</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-49582' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-49582", "49582", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi,</p>
<p>Thanks for the detailed post and also the enlightening discussions. I have prepared two builds which I am sharing below. Can you please provide your suggestions. I have some specific questions regarding the builds which I am providing with the build configs. But, before that let me provide my requirements/type of ML works I intend to do.</p>
<p>1. I am a very new assistant professor at an Institute in India. I will eventually get the money to procure 2 workstations with 4 GPUs (I am at least hoping 1080Ti) in each. But, that will take time and I want a decent build to get the ball rolling. For that I have already bought 2 1080Ti GPUs and a Samsung 860 EVO 500 gb around 3 months back when I was in the US. So, they are sitting idle now. To avoid this, and to get started, I want to buy the other parts of a DL machine from my pocket. My budget is around Rs. 100,000 [Rs is the Indian currency].<br />
2. The machine will be in the server room of the institute. So, the cheapest cooler [whatever noise level] and cabinet is what I would prefer.<br />
3. My student [only one at this moment] will run RL codes [both training and inference] on images. Later, I might do some classification work on videos [but this is a distant possibility at this moment, and I might be able to procure the servers with 4 GPUs by then].<br />
4. I don&#8217;t plan to expand this machine beyond 2 GPUs. My long term plan is to make this a student machine that will have even 1 GPU and the student can develop/prototype codes here while the stable code would run in the 4 GPU servers.<br />
5. My builds provide some prices which does not have web links. This is from <a href="https://mdcomputers.in" rel="nofollow">https://mdcomputers.in</a> &#8212; a local but reputable vendor. I could not find how to link their product pages to pcpartpicker. Otherwise, I would have done that. So, you have to believe my words about the price.</p>
<p>My first build uses core i5 9600K and a compatible motherboard. As my budget allows me to spend some more money, should I go for i7 8700K? This change along with a change of motherboard costs me Rs. 6000 more [still remaining inside the budget]. Core i7 processor supports hyperthreading. My student says, from time to time, he might use multiple threads for preprocessing in Tensorflow. Or, instead of upgrading the processor, should I just go for RAM upgrade to say a total 48 GB [and stick to core i5 9600K]? This will cost me around Rs. 12,000 more [and so I am remaining within the budget]. And later, I can pull out one memory when the system, ultimately, becomes a student&#8217;s developing machine with one GPU.<br />
Build with core i5 9600K &#8212; <a href="https://in.pcpartpicker.com/user/dasabir/saved/fgQ299" rel="nofollow">https://in.pcpartpicker.com/user/dasabir/saved/fgQ299</a><br />
Build with core i7 8700K &#8212; <a href="https://in.pcpartpicker.com/user/dasabir/saved/bD7J8d" rel="nofollow">https://in.pcpartpicker.com/user/dasabir/saved/bD7J8d</a><br />
While looking for the option of core i7 8700K, I came across core i7+ 8700 [https://mdcomputers.in/intel-core-i7-8700-bo80684i78700.html]. I see that this will cost me Rs. 11,000 more over my core i5 9600K build. I am not sure what is the difference between an i7 8700K and i7+ 8700 (other than the frequency/speed). Here is the comaprison link &#8212; <a href="https://ark.intel.com/compare/126684,140642" rel="nofollow">https://ark.intel.com/compare/126684,140642</a> . Will i7+ 8700 require different motherboard? It says the box includes NVME 3.0 x 2, does it help me? Also the i7+ processor includes a 16 GB optane memory. Will it be of any help (e.g., keeping the OS there)? Also does optane memory occupy PCIe lanes? Any suggestion on this would be great to have.</p>
<p>My second build is with AMD processors. I tried with AMD Ryzen 7 2700X. The price is coming around the same as the core i5 9600K build. It does have 8 cores compared to 6 cores for the intel processors, but does AMD have hyperthreading? I am not sure. Also it does not have MKL, is intel MKL going to be crucial for deep learning?<br />
Build with AMD Ryzen 7 2700X &#8212; <a href="https://in.pcpartpicker.com/user/dasabir/saved/3ddTBm" rel="nofollow">https://in.pcpartpicker.com/user/dasabir/saved/3ddTBm</a><br />
Though you say number of PCIe lanes are not that important especially with 2 GPUs, I just tried my luck with an AMD threadripper processor. As expected, it is overbudget. But, if you say, it is worth spending this much money, I might also go for it.<br />
Build with AMD Threadripper 1900X &#8212; <a href="https://in.pcpartpicker.com/user/dasabir/saved/73mhyc" rel="nofollow">https://in.pcpartpicker.com/user/dasabir/saved/73mhyc</a></p>
<p>Abir</p>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-49580">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2018-12-27T16:26:58+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-49580" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2018-12-27 at 16:26</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Either build is fine. You could buy a bit cheaper RAM which lower speeds — it will not make a big difference. If the ADM build is too expensive and you run only 2 GPUs I would rather good with an i5 or i7 build.</p>
		</div>
