			<p>Beginner who had some perishable credit on electronics vendor with limited computer parts supply. Got my hands on a evga rtx 2070 xc 8GB and a full atx case. Started the fastai course but the workflow with cloud resources got too annoying.</p>
<p>So i have my hands on the rtx 2070 already. Don´t want to waste too much of its capability for most beginner/intermediate use cases but do not have that much to spend. </p>
<p>the impression i get from the latest guide update is that even a i3 7100 or g4560 would not hamper the gpu or only slightly (and those cpu are really cheap). Have i understood it correctly?</p>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Yes a single RTX 2070 should be easy to utilize with an i3 7100. However, if you preprocess a lot of data you might still run into some bottlenecks. If you make sure that you have good quality preprocessing code you should be fine.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Other motherboards that do not support WLAN are fine as long as you get a USB wifi adapter. This combination might save you a bit of money on the motherboard. The i7 is a very versatile CPU — a bit expensive but it will show strong performance in any case!</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-49597">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2018-12-27T17:20:43+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-49597" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2018-12-27 at 17:20</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>The RTX 2070 cards that you chose might be prone to overheat in that configuration. I would pick a blower-style RTX 2070 card instead. Otherwise a good build. I am not sure though if you can easily find 3U or 4U racks that fit well with this configuration.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-49597' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-49597", "49597", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="comment-49293">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/0f1d5fb00de0019ca860dfd377fd024f?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/0f1d5fb00de0019ca860dfd377fd024f?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Fiz</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2018-12-21T16:27:26+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-49293" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2018-12-21 at 16:27</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim, questions on your comments &#8220;For good cost/performance, I generally recommend an RTX 2070 or an RTX 2080 Ti. If you use these cards you should use 16-bit models. Otherwise, GTX 1070, GTX 1080, GTX 1070 Ti, and GTX 1080 Ti from eBay are fair choices and you can use these GPUs with 32-bit (but not 16-bit).&#8221;</p>
<p>do you mean<br />
(1) on RTX cards running 16-bit models indirectly doubles the available memory for deep learning compared to 32-bit models, is that correct?<br />
(2) the facts in (1) are not valid for GTX cards, i.e. 32-bit models and 16-bit models makes no difference?<br />
(3) how to explicitly run in 32 vs 16 models when deep learning? Are there examples?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-49293' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-49293", "49293", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Fiz'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-49599">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2018-12-27T17:33:33+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-49599" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2018-12-27 at 17:33</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>1. It is not a straight doubling, but the memory requirements are much lower.<br />
2. You can have 16-bit models with GTX cards, but what happens under the hood is that all values will be cast to 32-bit before any computation. So the weights are 16-bit and the computation 32-bit for GTX cards. However, you should also see a good reduction in memory if you use 16-bit weights with GTX cards.<br />
3. In PyTorch is can be as simple as &#8220;model = model.half()&#8221; and you will run in 16-bit mode. In practice, it can be a bit more complicated depending on the model that you are running. You can have a look at NVIDIA&#8217;s 16-bit library <a href="https://github.com/NVIDIA/apex" rel="nofollow">Apex</a> that is built on PyTorch for more sophisticated examples.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-49599' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-49599", "49599", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>The computing power on two RTLX 2080 Ti is almost double that of the Titan RTX. Thus its a question of compute vs memory. If you want faster compute go with 2x RTX 2080 Ti if you want more memory go with the Titan RTX.</p>
		</div>

	<li class="comment even depth-3" id="comment-50724">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/8381b630c708a7a0342e3216b1cc9613?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/8381b630c708a7a0342e3216b1cc9613?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Nitin</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2019-01-18T20:36:42+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-50724" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2019-01-18 at 20:36</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>I have used two gpus without pcie bridge , these 2 gpus are now mounted on the motherboard , but i am still not able to use both of those gpus. Tensorflow starts to use memory from both but does not use the second one for processing.</p>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-4" id="comment-50953">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-50879">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/d1f61f528bf8dbc620af248feec623aa?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/d1f61f528bf8dbc620af248feec623aa?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Gurunath</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2019-01-21T21:23:02+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-50879" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2019-01-21 at 21:23</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>While you have mentioned that PCIe lines don&#8217;t matter significantly for a &lt;=4 GPU setup, I plan to use a setup with 8 GPUs (RTX 2080) for NLP, speech recognition tasks. Would the number of PCIe lines significantly affect the performance in such applications? What would be your advice on the number of PCIe lanes for each GPU in this 8 GPU setup for NLP and Speech recognition tasks?</p>
<p>Info: For example, our current NLP task on sequence-to-sequence model for a batch of 100 sentences, each restricted to 128 tokens (each represented by a  64-bit tensor) in Pytorch takes around 120-150 ms per iteration on a single GPU(1080Ti).<br />
Thanks in advance.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-50879' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-50879", "50879", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Gurunath'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-50955">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2019-01-23T08:37:00+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-50955" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2019-01-23 at 08:37</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>If you want to parallelize across 8 GPUs the PCIe lanes will matter quite a bit compared to 4 GPUs. The communication requirements scale linearly with the number of GPUs (if you use the right communication algorithm). However, if you run 8 GPUs on a regular 4 GPU motherboard you are also halving the PCIe speeds and you will have 4 GPUs behind a PCIe root complex. Since only one GPU behind a PCIe root complex can communicate with another root complex it means you need 8x the time to sent the same amount of messages between GPUs compared to 4 GPUs. So in total, the communication with 8 GPUs on 4-GPU motherboard will be 32 times more expensive than 4 GPUs on a 4-GPU motherboard. If you want to parallelize 8 GPUs efficiently, you will need 4 PCIe root complexes and this often means 2 CPUs and server-grade hardware (EPYC systems might be an exception, but I am not sure if those motherboards support 4x root complex setups).</p>
<p>If you do not want to parallelize a network across all GPUs, you will be fine — just note that with this system you cannot really do parallel training.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-50955' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-50955", "50955", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-52570">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2019-02-20T14:53:02+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-52570" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2019-02-20 at 14:53</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>1) Yes, but you will not be able to parallelize a deep neural network across those two different GPUs.<br />
2) If one of them has a blower fan you might be able to put the RTX 2080 Ti left of the other GPU. Otherwise, you can always buy a riser/extender if you have overheating issues.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-52570' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-52570", "52570", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-51168">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/0b677531e4a43c4402cde3b0a829c97c?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/0b677531e4a43c4402cde3b0a829c97c?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Bruce</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2019-01-27T14:14:25+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-51168" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2019-01-27 at 14:14</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hello!<br />
Maybe I am a bit confused, but can I have a config with more than one RTX 2070 at the same time? Because 2070 don&#8217;t support SLI (<a href="https://hothardware.com/news/nvidia-geforce-rtx-2070-gpu-will-not-support-nvlink-sli-but-why" rel="nofollow">https://hothardware.com/news/nvidia-geforce-rtx-2070-gpu-will-not-support-nvlink-sli-but-why</a>). Does it matter?</p>
<p>Thanks in advance!</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-51168' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-51168", "51168", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Bruce'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-52569">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2019-02-20T14:50:56+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-52569" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2019-02-20 at 14:50</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>CUDA code cannot use SLI for communication for GPUs. Instead, GPUs communicate via the PCIe network. Thus no SLI support is needed for parallelism.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-52569' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-52569", "52569", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="comment-51421">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/10d04c85e966be058f2c1033d1817a5a?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/10d04c85e966be058f2c1033d1817a5a?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Ryan S</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2019-02-01T08:34:44+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-51421" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2019-02-01 at 08:34</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hello Tim, I have a few very fundamental questions. I plan on using an NVIDIA Tesla P4 GPU on a server (let&#8217;s say Intel Xeon 16core, 128GB RAM, 2x10GbE etc.,).  From a popular manufacturer that has such a config, it states that the system can handle video analytics (like face detection) on 9 concurrent video streams @ 720p/15fps.</p>
<p>My question is:<br />
&#8211; If I run video @ 720p/3fps, how many concurrent video I may be able to handle concurrently?<br />
&#8211; If I run video @ 1080p/3fps, how many concurrent video I may be able to handle concurrently?</p>
<p>I know there are many factors related, but just as a ballpark, any suggestion if lowering the frame rate would help increase the # of video streams. Is this a linear equation of any kind?</p>
<p>Thanks!</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim,</p>
<p>Would it be possible to setup a system with a 1080Ti and a 2080 Ti and use them to perform parallel training?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-52036' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-52036", "52036", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Vishal Bajaj'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-52554">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2019-02-20T14:20:46+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-52554" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2019-02-20 at 14:20</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>This does not work, unfortunately. You need the same chip architecture to do GPU-to-GPU parallelization. You can do GPU-CPU-GPU parallelization, but that often yields no speedups.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-52554' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-52554", "52554", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-52149">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/06e15aa56ae03eaa101a6733c13986f0?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/06e15aa56ae03eaa101a6733c13986f0?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Mario Galindo</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

I want to buy an MSI Vortex G65RV with the following characteristics:<br />
Processor: Intel Core i7-6700K 4.0GHz 8M Cache, up to 4.20 GHz<br />
Hard Disk: 1 TB (SATA) 7200 + 256GB SSD PCIe 3.0<br />
RAM memory: 32GB DDR4 2133MHz expandable<br />
Graphics Card: 8 GB Nvidia GeForce GTX 1070 DDR5 VR Ready<br />
Connectivity: Killer ac Wi-Fi + Bluetooth v4.1, 2 ports Killer Gb LAN<br />
2 x Thunderbolt 3, 2 x Mini Display Port, 2 x USB 3.1 Type-C.</p>
<p>Unfortunately, the desktop only reaches: CPU i7-7700 and GPU 1080.</p>
<p>For which I thought about acquiring an external GPU:<br />
 GIGABYTE AORUS Gaming Box RTX 2070<br />
Which tells me the following: GeForce RTX 2070 with 8G memory and 448 GB / s memory bandwidth has 2304 CUDA Cores and hundreds of Tensor cores operating in parallel.</p>
<p>I know it will not yield the same to a card connected internally on the board. but I would like to know how the GPU communicates in those cases since the connection is through the Thunderbolt port if I am not mistaken, and I would also like to know how it will be the DL redeeming with CPU i7-6700k and GPU RTX-2070 with connection Thunderbolt</p>
<p>Thank you.</p>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-52540">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2019-02-20T12:47:30+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-52540" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2019-02-20 at 12:47</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Thunderbolt 3 is pretty good for communication and you should see only a small loss in performance (10%) for most application. This number might be higher if you (1) have very large input data, (2) a small neural network — this is not very common. So an eGPU should be fine.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-52540' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-52540", "52540", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Hi Tim,<br />
Extremely helpful article ! Keep it updated please !<br />
I wanted to take your opinion on buying a single GPU e.g. GTX 1080-Ti today priced around $808 vs buying two GPUs e.g. RTX 2070 (single GPU priced $527, total = $1045).<br />
Will 2 GPUs (RTX 2070) perform better as compared to single GPU RTX 2070?</p>
<p>Generally, does two slightly slower GPUs perform better for Machine learning projects as compared to a single high speed GPU?</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-52855' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-52855", "52855", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Farooq'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-53817">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2019-03-11T19:27:29+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-53817" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2019-03-11 at 19:27</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Usually, two GPUs that are slightly slower are better than a big GPU, because you can run multiple hyperparameter configurations of the same network on a GPU. Parallelization is also an option and is usually slightly faster than one big GPU. So go for the RTX 2070s!</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-53817' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-53817", "53817", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="comment-53740">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/924aa0dfa139fd7aab4b441c0a67319d?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/924aa0dfa139fd7aab4b441c0a67319d?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">David Knowles</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2019-03-10T14:08:55+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-53740" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2019-03-10 at 14:08</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Thanks a lot for the post, very useful. </p>
<p>Do you have advice on how bad an idea it is to have two different GPUs in the same box? I have an old GTX 980 that it seems a shame to waste so was thinking of running that alongside a RTX 2070 in a 2 GPU setup. I would potentially use the 980 for prototyping things while the 2070 is off training. Thanks!</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-53740' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-53740", "53740", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to David Knowles'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor even depth-2" id="comment-53823">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2019-03-11T19:39:42+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-53823" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2019-03-11 at 19:39</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>That is usually just fine. Make sure that you use software that is precompiled for different compute architectures (different GPU series) and you should have no problem.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-53823' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-53823", "53823", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	</li><!-- #comment-## -->
</ul><!-- .children -->
</li><!-- #comment-## -->

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-54646">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2019-03-24T16:00:47+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-54646" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2019-03-24 at 16:00</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>An RTX 2070 is great for prototyping. Since most of the time on Kaggle is spent prototyping it is not so efficient to dedicated resources for training. I would say, use your RTX 2070 also for training and if that is not sufficient (memory or training time to high) use the cloud for access to fast GPUs. This will be cheaper and more flexible.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-54646' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-54646", "54646", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2019-03-24T16:15:52+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-54650" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2019-03-24 at 16:15</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>It seems AMD CPUs are fine. I never had any problems with my AMD CPUs both at home and in the office. One issue might be if you want to use your CPU for some linear algebra (solvers and decomposition etc.), but other than that AMD CPUs are great.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-54650' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-54650", "54650", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment byuser comment-author-tim-dettmers bypostauthor odd alt depth-2" id="comment-54843">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/a2403083d31517f7ad848c67a51cf2d2?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Tim Dettmers</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2019-03-27T20:38:49+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-54843" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2019-03-27 at 20:38</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>Integrated GPUs are great but also expensive. If you find a cheap laptop with integrated RTX 2070 I would go for that. If you want to have multiple GPUs (internal + external) it gets complicated. I am not sure how this setup is supported. I would look online for other people who tried. In general, a single eGPU should also be great. It is also cheaper to upgrade the GPU without upgrading the laptop!</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-54843' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-54843", "54843", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Tim Dettmers'>Reply</a></div>

	<li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="comment-54938">
	<article itemprop="comment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Comment">

		
		<header class="comment-header">
			<p class="comment-author" itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person">
				<img alt='' src='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/851a5a955cf351bbc09d51112e1e2d24?s=48&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g' srcset='https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/851a5a955cf351bbc09d51112e1e2d24?s=96&#038;d=mm&#038;r=g 2x' class='avatar avatar-48 photo' height='48' width='48' /><span itemprop="name">Nick</span> <span class="says">says</span>			</p>

			<p class="comment-meta"><time class="comment-time" datetime="2019-03-29T04:11:18+00:00" itemprop="datePublished"><a href="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/#comment-54938" class="comment-time-link" itemprop="url">2019-03-29 at 04:11</a></time></p>		</header>

		<div class="comment-content" itemprop="text">
			
			<p>I feel this guide is becoming obsolete because it ignores alternatives to GPUs, like the Google TPU. There are conflicting claims but it does seem clear that chips which were designed for accelerating deep neural networks are going to be better than chips that were designed for accelerating graphics cards. There are at least half a dozen companies with TPU-like products in the pipeline, it&#8217;s not just Google.</p>
		</div>

		<div class="comment-reply"><a rel='nofollow' class='comment-reply-link' href='#comment-54938' onclick='return addComment.moveForm( "comment-54938", "54938", "respond", "121" )' aria-label='Reply to Nick'>Reply</a></div>
		
	</article>
	<ul class="children">

<p class="comment-form-url"><label for="url">Website</label> <input id="url" name="url" type="url" value="" size="30" maxlength="200" /></p>
<p class="comment-subscription-form"><input type="checkbox" name="subscribe_comments" id="subscribe_comments" value="subscribe" style="width: auto; -moz-appearance: checkbox; -webkit-appearance: checkbox;" /> <label class="subscribe-label" id="subscribe-label" for="subscribe_comments">Notify me of follow-up comments by email.</label></p><p class="comment-subscription-form"><input type="checkbox" name="subscribe_blog" id="subscribe_blog" value="subscribe" style="width: auto; -moz-appearance: checkbox; -webkit-appearance: checkbox;" /> <label class="subscribe-label" id="subscribe-blog-label" for="subscribe_blog">Notify me of new posts by email.</label></p><p class="form-submit"><input name="submit" type="submit" id="submit" class="submit" value="Post Comment" /> <input type='hidden' name='comment_post_ID' value='121' id='comment_post_ID' />
<input type='hidden' name='comment_parent' id='comment_parent' value='0' />
</p><p style="display: none;"><input type="hidden" id="akismet_comment_nonce" name="akismet_comment_nonce" value="340d83b05a" /></p><p style="display: none;"><input type="hidden" id="ak_js" name="ak_js" value="219"/></p>			</form>
			</div><!-- #respond -->
	</main><aside class="sidebar sidebar-primary widget-area" role="complementary" aria-label="Primary Sidebar" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/WPSideBar" id="genesis-sidebar-primary"><h2 class="genesis-sidebar-title screen-reader-text">Primary Sidebar</h2><section id="blog_subscription-5" class="widget jetpack_subscription_widget"><div class="widget-wrap"><h3 class="widgettitle widget-title">Subscribe to Blog via Email</h3>

			<form action="#" method="post" accept-charset="utf-8" id="subscribe-blog-blog_subscription-5">
				<div id="subscribe-text"><p>Enter your email address to subscribe to this blog and receive notifications of new posts by email.</p>
</div><p>Join 1,406 other subscribers</p>
					<p id="subscribe-email">
						<label id="jetpack-subscribe-label" for="subscribe-field-blog_subscription-5">
							Email Address						</label>
						<input type="email" name="email" required="required" class="required" value="" id="subscribe-field-blog_subscription-5" placeholder="Email Address" />
					</p>

					<p id="subscribe-submit">
						<input type="hidden" name="action" value="subscribe" />
						<input type="hidden" name="source" value="https://timdettmers.com/2018/12/16/deep-learning-hardware-guide/" />
						<input type="hidden" name="sub-type" value="widget" />
						<input type="hidden" name="redirect_fragment" value="blog_subscription-5" />
												<input type="submit" value="Subscribe" name="jetpack_subscriptions_widget" />
					</p>
							</form>

			<script>
			/*
			Custom functionality for safari and IE
			 */
			(function( d ) {
				// In case the placeholder functionality is available we remove labels
				if ( ( 'placeholder' in d.createElement( 'input' ) ) ) {
					var label = d.querySelector( 'label[for=subscribe-field-blog_subscription-5]' );
						label.style.clip 	 = 'rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px)';
						label.style.position = 'absolute';
						label.style.height   = '1px';
						label.style.width    = '1px';
						label.style.overflow = 'hidden';
				}

				// Make sure the email value is filled in before allowing submit
				var form = d.getElementById('subscribe-blog-blog_subscription-5'),
					input = d.getElementById('subscribe-field-blog_subscription-5'),
					handler = function( event ) {
						if ( '' === input.value ) {
							input.focus();

							if ( event.preventDefault ){
								event.preventDefault();
							}

							return false;
						}
					};

				if ( window.addEventListener ) {
					form.addEventListener( 'submit', handler, false );
				} else {
					form.attachEvent( 'onsubmit', handler );
				}
			})( document );
			</script>
				
</div></section>
